reviewText:
The first time I felt bad killing someone in Far Cry 2, it was a death I didn’t see coming. I’d seen plenty of unpredictable, often hilarious things happen as a result of my violent actions -- I once shot a driver who then rolled his truck into a zebra, over a bridge, and into a river. Moments like this get more out of hand in Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 4.

But when remembering my truly definitive Far Cry moments, and when asking myself which Far Cry game is best, I always think about Marty Alencar, the friend I murdered.

Marty was my first and best Buddy in Far Cry 2’s Africa. He was the man I rescued from a fiery plane crash. The guy who always brought me back to life when I took too many bullets, put a gun in my hand, and stood by my side until everyone around me died.

Far Cry 4’s Guns for Hire system operates on a similar idea to Far Cry 2’s Buddy System, allowing you to summon an ally instantly to fight alongside you. But they’re nameless henchmen, expendable fodder I used to deliberately detonate landmines and send to certain death for the sake of distraction. I never cared about any of them. I used them.

Compare this to Far Cry 2, where I relied on Marty, approaching him every time I stepped out the door, knowing he’d tell me he had my back, knowing it was true. Marty was a good man, always ready with another option when a mission wasn’t going to benefit me as much as it could. Yes, these “character traits” fed into the gameplay structure and story missions of Far Cry 2, but it convinced me that Marty Alencar was more than a Buddy -- he was a friend.

Marty dragged me out of the line of fire and into the bushes when a random group of guys jumped me on the road. Stupid. You never take the road. A gunner on the back of a truck mowed me down while I fell into my own misplaced Molotov flames. Marty hands me a pistol and opens fire. I find a couple grenades, knock the truck around, and finish the job. When it’s all done, I hear Marty screaming for help. I can’t see him.

By the time I find his blue smoke streaming out of the woods, he’s grunting incoherently. I kneel down, jab a regenerative needle into his stomach, and wait for him to head home. He doesn’t get up. He’s still wounded, so I put another needle in him. Nothing, but he slows down, and his eyes roll upward. One more needle. Marty’s head hits the ground, and he stops squirming.

I overdosed my best friend.

The wieght and impact moments like this have is why Far cry 2 is the real gem of the series and how Far Cry was meant to be. The pure unscripted brilliance.

reviewText:
As you can see, by my so far 1300 hours (6 man-months of work), I felt there was more to the game than what you could pick out in just a coupla hundred hours of play.  I found so many slight adjustments that occurred whilst I was playing, such as you came in the game in the dry season, as evidenced by the fires visible on the cab ride into town, plus the cab driver's admission that it WAS the dry season.  That meant that the flare gun and Molotov cocktails were at their peak efficiency for destruction, since when the wet season came about three hundred hours later, the grass turned green and your flame and smoke damage were quite a bit reduced.

Also if you timed the moon just right, you could pick a cloudy night for a most stealthy job and have a better chance of completetion.

I found out at 750 hours that after you ride shotgun on that weapons barge across the lake, and you warn the doctor, that you don't have to fight you way thru the town to make it out alive.  You could just hop up on the cart, climb the stall to the tarp above it, jump onto the roof of the clay building just behind the Dr.'s office and make your way to the swamp boats that were moored right there in the garbage cove.

I would pile cars up  in special preset locations and set C4 to explode as I approached the exits, and then had a Liberty Jeep waiting (those are the best armor rating, except for the 3 tonners, I have read others more informed than I say) to ride like a snowplow thru the enemy blasting away. Thank goodness for game saves, those made it possible for me to complete the game in many situations where I, in my mighty inflated ego, thought the only  way through was blasting away and running and dodging like a basketball player making way downcourt.

I do believe that playing the game on Master (Very Hard) is the only way to play, and you should be by the first five hours, unless you are a nubie, it gives the enemy some brains, and they go after you, not just wait to be shot.  Love the way they will ambush and surprize you, call you out.

That you can go back into the first area in FC2 after getting cooler weapons in the second area is a great idea.  Going back and blasting like no tomorrow is a nice way to past time.   Using subtrafuge, and disattraction, with drawing their attention to the other side of the camp and knifing the few left on duty station is a way of penetrating into some camps that you feel just have to be obliterated by grenade-launcher technicals until you realize there is another way, and another, and another ad nauseum.

There are just so many ways to accomplish each mission, with the one where if you kill everyone in the mine, except the bosses in the tin admin shack, they will ply you to let them live and you can  walk right into an office of the enemy with all of your weapons and just blast them to bits, which until then you thought that you needed to be searched and disarmed before entering the mucky-mucks hdqtrs.  The thumbs-up the dude at the door gives you when you arrive to fulfill the promise they gave at the mine is awesome, dude is like, no problem, bro.

If you drive a nade-jeep all the way up the narrow path to the safe house to contact your mercanary friend about the killing of the government minister of censory before having the dejay read the propaganda to kill the medical doctor in his rounds, you can step outside of the safe house right after the meeting and climb directly into the jeep without touching the ground, and blast away over the hillside into the resort area where he is residing with his finger on the cut-off switch in case anyone trys what you are gonna do.  I thought it was easy having a nade-boat fifty feet away in a cove ready to go a hundred feet to blast the resort, but being able to hop outside and complete her or his part of the mission within seconds is majical.

This is perhaps not so much a game as a sort of lifestyle alteration.

reviewText:
This game is not related to the original FarCry in anyway except for name, if you go into FC2 expecting the same story/mechanics/locations/characters as the original you will be disappointed.

That said this game really shines (or did shine back at release and the years after that) in the sheer vastness of it's open world sandbox" enviroment.

Almost 1.5k hours on record (I owned the disc copy years before it came to steam) and I have still not yet found every golden AK47; let alone explored every location in the southern "second part" of the game.

Best part of this game is the weapon degradation (why don't more games have this!??!) that will affect all guns over time and add to the immersion.

While the MP is not entirly alive all these years later I still do host a weekly get together for myself and a few pals where we mess around with custom maps/mods.

Out of all the FC games I would have to score this one as 7/10 only because I have not yet finished it!"

reviewText: Off-roading in Jeeps. Unlimited gunplay. Setting fires that spread with the wind. Hunting down your target with a machete. Firing a mortar into a pack of zebras.\n\nThere's a reason this game still garners respect and admiration, and retains a cult-following to this day. It's an, off the beaten path
date:
strategy-laced masterpiece. The gunplay is raw and satisfying. The environments are beautiful. The map is massive.

The main complaint thrown at this game is respawning guard posts. The reason so many people hated this mechanic is because they played Far Cry 2 like a Call of Duty title. This game is not about just pressing the X button occasionally in between set-piece action sequences. This game forces you to slow your roll, take out your map, and plan a route to your target. It simply wants you to take your time with it. This is part of the beauty of the game.

Each and every situation in Far Cry 2 has unlimited potential. Almost everything happens dynamically. You may have heard the term, emergent gameplay
recommended: being tossed around in the gaming press as of late. Well, Far Cry 2 was ahead of it's time for attempting to show the mainstream what emergent gameplay" actually is
hoursPlayed: and in my opinion

reviewText:
threw one molotov next thing I know Africa is on fire.
10/10 (old review)

{Please work with me as I go out of order in events because that's how it's going through my mind as I write this.}

Where to begin with such a great game? You could start anywhere really, the setting is in Africa, you enter the country (I forget if they say. [yes I know Africa is a continent]) hunting a man known as ''The Jackal'' an arms dealer and your mission is to eliminate him; to stop the gun trafficking in the war torn country, but things turn down south immediatly after your boots touch the ground you've gotten malaria (This... This was one of the annoying/funny things I found that happen in the game, I mean c'mon it's freaking Malaria no one really wants to black out in the middle of a gun fight, I mean when I did I kept screaming ''♥♥♥♥! ♥♥♥♥! ♥♥♥♥! Not now! Surely I have one more pill to keep me going!'' But alas I didn't and woke up a day later in a church now angry about the travel time I have to ensue yet again.) I digress through the events of the game you find new friends, new enemies, and many plot twist with these characters, and the currency in this game is Blood Diamonds which you find all across the map and from completing missions. If you read my little ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review from the beginning you'd understand what I mean, it's pretty ridiculous, what starts as a little fire now consumes your entire screen. Now then the combat in this game I thought was pretty well for this game because there was a lot of realism for the time for example your gun would jam and you'd have to unjam it in the middle of a firefight (now you could avoid this altogether by getting a new version of the gun from your gun stash) or you'd find enemies weapons that are so rusty that litterally sometimes after 5-6 shots after you picking it up it just keeps jamming up and you scream ''WTF'' (you will do this trust me). Let me think ah yes! The RPG's in the game quite fun instruments, but just as dangerous! You could shoot a dud and then be like me and run away screaming or sit there like an idiot... Your call... the other thing it would do is start you on fire and you can easily put it out by using the healing animation. Now then moving on to Multiplayer... Just wow the creativity of people's imagination just blew me away! People were creating maps such as D-day with such realism you could look into a history book and it look the same, I always loved those kind of people when it comes to games where you can create such things, I certainly wish I could have that kind ability or at least a little bit of it haha. Onwards we go though, the multiplayer back then was pretty fun people were nice and they also very team play coordinated (which I love in team based games instead of lone wolves {which can work depending on the game and game modes} and I don't know how it is now since I haven't played multiplayer again yet due to playing with friends with other games.
Finally my score of the game: 10/10 still. I enjoyed litterally every part of the game, the characters, the story, the twists, and also being able to find some crazy ♥♥♥♥ that goes on in here.

reviewText:
Date of review: 10.24.2014

Platform: PC



Released in 2008, Far Cry 2 took a sharp turn from the first Far Cry, and threw the player into a much more realistic, grim, fictional African country. Forget the super mutants and crazy scientists, and get prepared for arguably the most authentic game representation of an African civil war.

Story:

In Far Cry 2 you can choose to be one of 9 pre-created characters, and while the choice itself will not have any real impact on the outcome of the story, the characters have interesting backgrounds and the ability to choose definitely improves the immersion.

However, no matter who you choose, you will be a mercenary, sent to assassinate the Jackal, a notorious arms dealer who is arming both warring African factions, the UFLL and the APR… (the remaining characters will also show up in the game, as “buddies”, and they will help you throughout your progress). Of course things will go wrong, very wrong, and you will find yourself in the middle of a bloody war, AND sick with malaria.

The story is exciting, and unique. Forget the good guy(s) who fight(s) the honorable war against the evil enemy kind of stuff... In Far Cry 2 everyone is a corrupt, backstabbing son of a b****,  and as you progress through the main plot you will realize that there is no good or bad choice, there is only bad and bad, and there is nothing you can do about it. Definitely not your average approach, but you know you are dealing with something unique when you get a Nietzsche quote right at the beginning of the game…

10/10


Visuals:

Far Cry 2 could obviously not  keep up with today's AAA games in terms of graphics, but maxed out it still looks very good. The African wilderness is very well depicted and diverse, with deserts, vast savannas, and jungles, and lively with several forms of wildlife running all around the place. The towns are filthy and dilapidated, with signs of poverty and war visible everywhere. On top of that, Far Cry 2 also has a live day-night cycle which is not only visually pleasing, but also adds a lot to the immersion.

While I was more than satisfied with the visuals of the Dunia Engine, I did have some problems when enabling DirectX 10, which was causing seemingly random crashes on Windows 7 64 Bit Ultimate. On Windows 8.1 64 Bit Pro the problem disappeared…

All in all, nice visuals, with some technical hiccups here and there. Today's computers should run it without any problems even on maximum details (for reference, you can check test system specifications at the bottom of the review).

8/10


Gameplay:

Far Cry 2 follows the path created by the first Far Cry in terms of gameplay, but it also polishes and adds a number of new features to it. The world is truly open and huge (50 square kilometers) and provides a ton of things to do.

You get a decently long main story with varied and interesting missions, and plenty of side quest from weapon dealers (who will reward you with new weapons), from buddies (who will reward you with safe house upgrades) and from the locals (who will reward you with malaria medicine). And on top of that, you have a lot of miscellaneous “quests” as well, like diamond searching and outpost scouting.

You can probably rush through the game in 15 hours or so, but you can easily spend 50+ hours and still have things to do.

But this is an FPS, so what about the weapons? No need to worry, the weapons are also varied (from pistols and sub machine guns to assault rifles, sniper rifles, light machine guns and even exotics such as the flame thrower and the mortar) and provide several ways of combat. It’s up to you to decide whether you will try to dispatch your foes from far or in a bloody close combat. Stealth however didn’t really work for me, and as far as I can tell, the developers didn’t want to make it a really viable option… something I can understand in a way, this is a civil war after all. Still, it’s fun to shoot, the weapons are quite realistic (don’t expect an ArmA type of game though) and the flame thrower is really awesome, even if not very effective actually.

Still, this wouldn’t be a Far Cry without vehicles, right? Right! You also have vehicles in Far Cry 2, from small cars and modified assault trucks to boats and gliders… and while they feel completely arcadish, trust me, you will be thankful for them as the distances can be really huge.

Unfortunately however, Far Cry 2 has its problems as well. Some of the side missions become repetitive after a while, the weapons have a degradation system which is interesting, but way too fast, the AI is simply painfully stupid sometimes (although when it works, it will surprise you…) and… well you have the “outpost system” which is one of the most frustrating features I have ever seen in a game. There are dozens of outposts scattered throughout the map, manned by the soldiers of the warring factions who will shoot you on sight. While the concept does make sense, and clearing the outposts is fun at first, they will soon become frustrating because of their insane re-spawn rate… it’s really not fun to clear out an outpost, walk away a couple hundred meters and come back to find it fully manned again. Ubisoft, this was really stupid!

8.5/10


Sound:

In terms of music and sound effects Far Cry 2 is above average. While the soundtrack isn’t really memorable, the African tribal theme is pleasant and adds to the immersion, and the environmental and combat sounds are actually quite good. Unfortunately the dialogs are a bit soulless which sometimes kills the characters.

8/10


Replay value:

While the plot is linear and there aren't any choices which would significantly change the outcome (which was done on purpose as far as I can tell, because in the end Far Cry 2 is story oriented and has a very strong message to communicate), the game provides countless possibilities, and can easily suck you in, making the game worth returning to.

9/10


Conclusion:

Far Cry 2 is a very good game, with a unique setting, a unique plot, and a strong message which raises some very interesting moral questions. And while it might be a bit outdated by today’s standards, it’s definitely one of those games which you have to play at least once.

I really recommend it if you are willing to invest some time into it, and if you are interested in something different, something special. If you are looking for a simple “tunnel shooter” however, you might get somewhat disappointed.

8.5/10



Test system specifications:

AMD FX-8350 (OC @ 4.6 GHz); 8 GB DDR3 RAM @ 1866 MHz; AMD Radeon R9 280X (AMD Catalyst 14.4), Windows 7 64 Bit Ultimate / Windows 8.1 64 Bit Pro.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 - for me still the best part of the whole series.
After playing through it multiple times (during internet downtime) i can safely say: This game is incredibly awesome!

You start as an agent sent to an african country to hunt down an arms dealer. Too bad, you end up getting malaria and in need to rely on help of the local warlords. You help those guys out and get deeper and deeper into the fight between the different forces.

The game, as allready mentioned, takes place in a fictional african country. You have 2 very huge areas in which are you free to move around and shoot people and animals. You have a lot of different weapons to use, some which you can find, others which you can buy.
You get access to new weapons by completing side missions, same as malaria pills, which you need to survive. During your time you get to meet a few other mercenarys, some which get to be you friends and come help you in times of need.

The Story is generic, but enjoyable, same with the missions. The graphics are beautifull, the african setting totally stunning. Yo can spend an incredible huge amount of time in the game, if you e.g. play on a high difficulty, simulating maximum realsim. The engine does its best to help with that! The sound you are listening to during your playtime might be a bit generic but is very nice to listen to.

Multiple possible endings complete this wonderfull game.

10/10 Still the best Far Cry game i've ever played, plus one of the best SP shooters.

[Hint: i've heard mods make this even more enjoyable. I did not test that out though]

reviewText:
I've put in more than 40 hours into this game on the Xbox 360 version, as well as the non-Steam version, so don't mind the lowly 9 hours I've put into the game here on Steam.

This is a fantastic game, and I personally prefer it over Far Cry 3. I was a huge fan of the original Far Cry (no, not the one on Xbox called Instincts, but the very first one on PC!). It was a flawed but fun game, with glitchy AI but beautiful levels and an open world design, where you could do a mission multiple different ways. I was worried when Far Cry 2 was announced to be in Africa and not a tropical island like the first, and that Jack Carver wouldn't be returning. I bought Far Cry 2 anyway when it released on PC, back when games didn't always come with Steam keys.

I was immediately addicted. The game is very gritty, with just about everything out to kill you. It's definitely not for casual gamers.

Weapons start rusting and breaking after long uses, eventually exploding in your hand, damaging you and forcing you to scavenge for a weapon off the ground while enemies are shooting at you from all directions. Cars can start to break down, requiring you to quickly get out, pop the hood, and use your magical wrench to fix it all while enemies are driving down the road trying to find you.

Bones will break. Shrapnel will stab into your thigh. Bullets will require pulling out of your arm. You'll need to heal yourself, which uniquely has your character fix himself through multiple animations of ripping out large chunks of metal from his legs, bandaging himself, etc. It all looks fantastic and gives the game, as I said earlier, a very gritty feel.

The game is flawed, just like Far Cry 1. The AI is iffy. It's hard to stealth. The story isn't delivered very well. Everyone talks like they've got to get to the last rocket off Earth. There's respawning guard outposts (though you can easily go around them, to be honest). But even with all of that said, I still think the game is much more unique and fun to play compared to Far Cry 3. I love exploring Africa, it looks gorgeous. If you ask me, I think the engine they used for FC2 (Dunia Engine) looks much better than the slightly cartoon-y style FC3 had with the Dunia Engine 2.

I'd recommend the game if you're looking for a different, less casual type of FPS. It's got an incredible amount of detail, the weapons are fun to use, there's some very cool features like weapons breaking down, the healing system, and the way AI interact with each other (enemies will try to drag their friends away after they've been hurt, for example).

It's a very underrated game, and I hope one day we'll get another Far Cry like this. One that isn't afraid to be different and try new things.

EDIT:

I recently started playing Far Cry 4 on my Playstation 4, and I just wanted to say that if you were a fan of Far Cry 2, but sad that FC3 removed a lot of the neat ideas 2 brought with it, you should definitely check out FC4.

It feels like a mix of all the things I loved about FC3 and brought back a few things I missed that FC2 had, like fire realistically spreading (FC3 sorta had it still, but it didn't work well), being able to go to sleep to change to a specific time of day, and hell, even a certain character returns from FC2! I won't spoil who it is, but it took me by surprise, since he wasn't a particularly big character in FC2. He's also the first recurring character in a Far Cry game, other than one other character who returns from FC3. Seems like Ubisoft is starting to make the games connect a bit!

reviewText:
This game is absolutely great no matter what haters say.
Haters are mostly people who've played Far Cry 3 first, which has its positives, and while it's more cinematic than Far Cry 2, you just play to get over with it after a while.

The Cons:
Far Cry 2 only has 2 actual cons and they're both closely related. First of all, driving everywhere is mandatory, unless you use a bus station, which basically fast travels you to another bus station. However, you can't fast travel anywhere at anytime. The second con is related like I said, and it's the fact that you have to drive all the way to another underground station to get more Malaria pills. Malaria itself is an interesting part in the game and it adds to the difficulty and surprise since you might be taking out a huge army of enemies and suddenly feel the Malaria kick in. However, having to drive to an underground station to get passports and then travelling to another Underground station to give the passports and get the pills, is a huge detour that could have been avoided.

The Pros:
This game's positives overwhelm the negatives by far. The physics engine is absolutely perfect and it's undeniably better than Far Cry 3 and 4's since almost everything is dynamic. That means you can use fire for your advantage, unlike 3 and 4 where fire just spread everywhere randomly around the source of the fire. In Far Cry 2 since the environment is dynamic, by looking at how the wind blows (grass and trees' leaves can indicate that since they are moving n/s/w/e) you can actually use fire to your advantage and trap enemies inside a fire circle that's getting closer to them by the second.
Another notable pro is that Far Cry 2 has a great gameplay that makes sure you're never bored. Malaria, Weapon jamming, respawning camps (some people find them annoying but we could all see how dead the island was in Far cry 3 after all camps were captured), a great arsenal of weapons, and of course, much fun with the flamethrower. It's also worth noting that Far Cry 2 in Infamous mode is an extremely hard challenge for all players and it can generate Dark Souls level of rage, which means the game actually respects the player and doesn't just ask you to be a Rambo in Africa.

Overall, this game is great and the atmosphere are well as the gameplay itself show its true quality.
Also, no Uplay! 11/10.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is rather an anomaly amongst AAA releases, and - in light of Ubisoft's more recent games - a world away from their typical modus operandi in the way it presents an uncompromising and utterly standout creative vision, ridden all the way to completion.

It's not a perfect game - there are a number of features that are evidently only partially implemented and have little effect on gameplay (the buddy system, the reputation system, the malaria), and the story and characters are lacking to say the least. But, what it lacks in narrative it makes up for in atmosphere and pure creative integrity.

I've never played a game that so accurately recreates the FEEL of a real-world location as Far Cry 2 does Africa. Whether the sun is rising over the still river water in the morning, or setting over a fire in the dry grasslands, this game is DRENCHED in atmosphere. You can almost smell the dirt and feel the sweat dripping off you as you play. Aside from creating a living, breathing world (which, in my opinion, is one of the most important features that open-world games often fail to include), it shows that there was someone with vision that pushed the creative team to create a product that was not necessarily going to hold the hands of the player (unlike Far Cry 3 with it's HUD crammed full of indicators telling you what to do and when). For Ubisoft to make such a choice and release a game which may not have been accessible to every single walking, talking wallet is, in light of their recent history, utterly mind-boggling, and I applaud the team behind this game for their efforts.

Everything else aside though, the game is genuinely well-made - the core features all work wonderfully, with solid gunplay, responsive driving, and a well-designed sandbox that rewards exploration with many distinct and beautiful locales.

The enemies are aggressive and unforgiving, typically forcing you to plan your attacks and prepare the right weapons for the job - it's so rewarding when a plan comes together. Equally rewarding, however, are those moments when you're caught unprepared - perhaps you only have a sniper rifle, a pistol, and some molotovs, and are caught from behind by a number of enemies, so you start frantically flinging molotovs in the direction of the enemy who are somewhere out there in the bush, as you relocate. You find a new spot and look back to see the bush ablaze and enemies fleeing, some already dead in the fire. These moments of pure, unscripted tension and excitement are what makes this game far deeper than it would seem on the surface, and this is perhaps why this review is littered with anecdotes. Because this is a game that creates anecdotes organically.

Of course, with Far Cry 3 they made a number of changes that made it more accessible, but less memorable in my opinion - in favour of a realistic setting they crafted a cartoonish tropical island, in favour of a do-it-yourself mission style they filled the HUD with feedback and mission markers, in favour of challenging fights and impressive AI they put enemies in brightly coloured shirts who bum-rush you the second you fire a bullet, and on top of that they littered the world with meaningless fetch-quest items. It's not to say that I think FC3 is a bad game, but I find myself getting bored quickly every time I play it. Far Cry 2, however, is a game in which the fun one has is limited only by the player's imagination and creativity.

The thing is, in its quest for realism, and its lack of strong narrative, I find the game actually offers the player a freedom that few other games genuinely do. The side missions are typically pretty bland, yes, but the strength of the world design and the freedom that you're offered means that there are quite literally countless ways to finish them. So you need to assasinate a target? Perhaps you block the road with your car and lie in wait to ambush him. Perhaps you wait until night and sneak in with a silenced pistol. Perhaps you snipe him from a nearby hillside. Perhaps you trap him in grassland and set the countryside ablaze. Perhaps you stride in with an RPG and just blow him the hell up. Even the way you choose to get to the location is undecided - do you drive the quickest route? Do you take the long way off road to avoid the checkpoints? Do you hop in a riverboat and take a shortcut downstream? You're given a target on a map, and complete freedom to traverse a believable world from then on.

And even though I will criticise the lack of characters and story, the characters that are there feel like real, shady people. The main antagonist (although he is no Vaas) is enigmatic, and his cynical and exhausted outlook on the world becomes genuinely affecting as the game progresses, and I find that the thread of narrative that exists actually leaves you thinking about the real world situations that exist right now in so many African nations.

It's clear that have a deep affection for this game, and that may be taken as bias by some, but it's an affection that was hard-won from release day as I slowly got used to Ubisoft's take on the franchise, unravelled the features of the game, and then began exercising my complete freedom to explore and manipulate the vast and beautiful landscape. This is a testament to what a strong creative vision can do to a AAA release, and while it might not go down in history as a particularly successful iteration, I feel that Far Cry 2 is one of the most criminally underrated games ever released and I defy any player not to be caught staring in awe as the sun rays filter through the canopy overhead.

I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a dirty, gritty, realistic shooter in an incredibly immersive world that lays the tools on the table, and lets the player decide what to do with them.

reviewText:
A Good game on many accounts.

Farcry 2 is unique, fun, exciting and definately challenging. The enviroment is dynamic and beautiful, albiet sometimes locked in and small. The tactic of creating bush fires to devastate enemies has become a godsend for me.

Malaria is a topic all on it's own. Deadly, realistic and game-changing at times, it hosts a brand new, rarely implemented idea that is interesting as it is deadly.
Unfortunately, this concept is also extremely annoying and frustratingly good at stopping progress. You have to constantly backtrack to get new pills and it tends to pop up during important moments in conflict, costing you a lengthy retreat or a undeserved death.

Another issue i found was that the game feels.... crowded. You cant drive 500 yards without hitting another guard post (there are 63 in the map!) or enemy patrol. And once spotted, prepare to be tirelessly chased down and shot at until you are, injured and with a smoking engine, forced to pull over and face the threat. You can scout these posts and keep them from respawning soldiers, but it's a lengthy, time consuming process that takes away from the air of flowing gameplay and beauty otherwise found in Farcry 2.

When it comes to guns, theres a LOT. So much different weapons and tools to use, so little time. From flare guns to rocket launchers, you will never have to worry about getting bored. The weapon unlocking system is fun but a bit tedious, and it seems to be a magnet for the ever-so-present danger of malaria.

The story is less implemented and less of a focus, allowing you to create your very own path to find your conclusion. This may seem to make the game offset" at times but it also makes Farcry seperate from other "Go here
recommended: Call of Duty and Halo.\n\nVehicles are fun
hoursPlayed: relatively diverse
voteText:
and suprisingly fragile. It only takes a few wild bullets from a machine gun to turn your beautiful safari ride into a smoking husk of a truck. Return fire is not an option unless you stop the vehicle.
Gliders are fun and a great way to get from place to place. Be careful when getting off them though!

Map creator is absolutely astounding! Fluid controls and a large array of options can make anyone into a professional map creator. I've spent a good long time building maps and playing on others.
It is quite possible to never play the same map twice in mulitplayer.

All in all
helpfulPercent: this game has it's pitfalls
votesHelpful: but the pro's outway the con's. This game is interesting
votesTotal: breathtaking and unique. I love playing Farcry 2 and im sure you will two."

reviewText:
My score: 8.5/10 (with realism mod)Playthrough time: 27 hours (main story, many side missions, most main missions with buddy quests)

Pros:+Great looking open world design
+Approach each mission in the way you prefer
+Very immersive game (especially with realism mod)
+Excellent gunplay, combat is very engaging and fun

Cons:-A lot of tedious extra travel if doing all the buddy missions
-Game feels unbalanced without realism mod
-Story doesn't make all that sense all the time
-Speeded up voice acting sounds strange

Performance notes:Works well with Xbox 360 controller but I preferred keyboard + mouse
Graphics performance R9 280X, 1080P max settings: 60 FPS (V-sync) almost all the time

Main reviewFarCry 2 is a first person shooter you probably either love or hate. Some people have called it a central African truck driving simulator rather than a first person shooter, and it all depends on how you look at the gameplay mechanics. It has a lot going for it with the open world, letting you tackle the missions as you prefer. The graphics and the African setting looks great. The game has a lot of features that really immerse you in the game, as the lack of minimap, instead utilizing a map you actually have to equip as an item and look at.

The game puts you in a central African nation, where different factions are waging war at each other, and your mission is to stop the arms dealer supplying both sides. You have buddies" helping you with missions (giving you optional ways to tackle the main missions) as well as giving you side missions of their own. They will also help you out of trouble if you get shot down.

It's up to you to choose how to tackle each mission: get to the mission in an open world
date: utilizing buses for instant fast travel to a few set locations
recommended: otherwise the other vehicles available or going on foot

The story sets out ambitious but doesn't hold together all that well. Most of the game is standard missions that are somewhat similar. One odd thing is that the DVD release of the game required the developers to speed up all recorded dialogue to make it take up less space. This is also in the steam version of the game. The fast talking NPC:s sound really odd!

There are four things I got tired of while playing the game:

reviewText:
Yes, I recommend this game to anyone that wants a good playing game. It's worth $10. More than many of the other $10 games I have. Check out the videos on the store page and see for yourself. I've not tried mp yet. Not sure there is anyone playing mp?

As for online game play, I didn't buy it just for that. I got it for the single player experience, only. I looked and there is no one that I know of, playing online these days. If you want to play online, you'll have to create a LAN server and play with friends. I have none around me that play these games or, any games at all that I know of?

All-in-all, the game has a good SP experience if you like playing single player games. It will give you plenty of play time and it's open world to do as you please. Nothing runs in any perticular order, just play the game the way you want to, there's no time limits in it for missions or the like. Side missions are of your choosing and not mandatory. The game plays the way you want to play it. Your decisions are your own. However, your enemies are still your enemies.

There's several mods for the game and a map editor for it so, do as you wish.

By-the-way, you can launch your own dedicated server through the start window.

reviewText:
When I first played this game, I underestimated on how addictive Far Cry 2 can be. I just cannot stop playing it and kept going on for hours.


What the game did right:

This game is similar to its predecessor but expands the limited open world that the first Far Cry game was trying to construct on.  The environment is now far more diverse, ranging from dry savannahs to humid jungles with thick vegetation.  There is also a dynamic weather system in which fog can overtake the land or a rainstorm can appear and change the way you play.

Adding to its wide ranges of landscapes, I can argue one of the more tactical benefits" this game boasts is its fire.  A lot of games have a blaze kept at a constant size but FC 2 offers greater realism in that part. Throw a Molotov Cocktail at a dry patch of grass and see the fire consume the grass with its voracious appetite but in a humid climate
date: it will inflict little damage.\n\nThe A.I. of your enemies are no longer the same "dimwits" that got slaughtered in FC 1. If you're spotted out in the open or make too much noise near guard posts
recommended: they will come for you. They also converse with each other and try to protect themselves from the player which reflects real life. In one instance
hoursPlayed: a downed mercenary will be helped by another merc.\n\nStealth has been improved. If you're careful enough

reviewText:
Shoot people, start fires, drive cars, blow things up. This is about all you'll be doing in Far Cry 2 but when it's this much fun and so immersive, it doesn't really matter. Far Cry 2 is a stripped back version of what the current series is all about and if you don't mind spending 10 minutes driving to your next objective, in between suffering from malaria attacks, you will have a great time.

It runs like greased lightning on toasters as well.

reviewText: Heard a lot of negative press about this game, and while some of it was certainly true, the flaws were far from bad enough to ruin the game.\nI really enjoyed this, I can't really put my finger on why though. The wide open spaces were enjoyeble to wander through, and though there was no variety in enemy you could create your own variety in the tactics you used to deal with them. Weapon choice seemed to have a big impact on combat, you could try and pick them off from afar with long range weapons or maybe run and gun with a shotgun and some grenades. How about starting a fire and using the resulting confusion to take advantage of the situation? Maybe just take a different route and avoid combat all together. The environments were much better looking and more varied than I expected and although there could have been more variety in the missions, I never found them to be a drag as they usually made you explore new parts of the map.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is a open world first person shooter with some small RPG elements set in the African savannah.

You have a aim, killing the Jackal, the person who supply the African war groups with weapons and causes the whole country to suffer even more.
When arriving in Africa you get driven by a taxi driver to the main city Pala.
While driving through the magnificent looking landscape you see several things and also notice your Malaria.
You get a Malaria attack and get unconscious.
You wake up in a house in Pala and see your enemy, the jackal.
He decides who lifes and dies and he lets you alive.
After this you have to get out and get unconscious again after a while.
You get saved by a group called UFLL. There are 2 groups who have war against each other.
UFLL and APR. Who is the good and the bad have you to decide even though both are not perfect.
I personally prefer the UFLL. Only my opinion though.
On your way through the story you visit a lot of places and meet your buddies who help you.
I wont say more to dont spoiler too much.

The gameplay is actually very nice. I love the first person weapon handling.
It feels realistic and there is a big range of weapons to choose from.
All being buyable in the Weapon Store for diamonds.
Thats the currency of the game.
You can also buy upgrades for you and your weapon.
Your weapons degrade! Maybe too fast for some but for me its fine, especially with upgrades.
You can change them for free in your Weapon room and repair" them like that.
I wouldnt recommend using weapons of the enemies
date:
they are weak and in bad quality.
You often get quests to finish certain aims. The mission variety is fine even though not big.
But its fine for my taste. You mostly get diamonds or medicine for completing quests.
You can also find collectables in the game. Diamond suitcases with 1-3 diamonds in each and Jackal tapes.
There is a incredible amount of this stuff. Also there are 8 gold AKs in the whole world.
The difficulty is higher than normal. Dont try rushing over the enemy
recommended: this mostly wont work. You always have to watch out. And the health doesnt regenerate
hoursPlayed: at least not completely. You need some sort of medics to heal yourself and you cant carry unlimited of those.\nThe open world is extremely big and you have your feet

reviewText:
This is a game you either really love or really hate. Everything in the entire game is there for 1 reason only: to kill the player. Ranging from infinite respawning guard posts to jamming weapons and malaria (oh that malaria...), every freaking thing is hell-bent on killing you every step you take.

Should you buy this game, I have two recommendations:
Install a realism mod and up the difficulty a bit to at least hardened. Both this mod and this one are really good. Recently a new supermod in the form of this one was released.
Take the game at a slow pace. The faster you want to finish missions, the game, your enemies, or anything for that matter, the faster the game throws everything it has at you. And don't be mistaken, you will die.
Take it slow, plan your attack a bit. 99/100 times your plan goes awfully wrong, so all that you're left with is complete and utter chaos anyway.
Do yourself a favor and buy this game. Nevermind how much is wrong or broken, it's an experience you will never ever forget. (I've played through it 3x on my Xbox and 1st time on my PC now, I still enjoy it!)
voteText: 25 of 26 people (96%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
OK, and now for the review i have been waiting to do......

What can i say about this game, aside that i believe it's about as close to perfection as a game can get...???  From the AI, the weapons, the amount of immersion, graphics, story, sound, everything in this game just oozes awesomeness.

This was a game that managed to draw a fine line between what people enjoyed and didnt.  Either you absolutely hated it, or you loved it dearly, with no middleground.  Most of the complaints revolved around the respawning checkpoints, which didnt bother me because, well, IT IS a shooter afterall.  If you're playing a shooter and you're not shooting something, then it can get a little boring sometimes.

First on the discussion list is the story.  Loosely based on the short book titled Heart of Darkness
date:
the story has the player hunting an arms dealer named The Jackal who supplies two rival factions with an armory to start, and continue waging war against each other.  On your journey you aid both factions in search of information of the Jackal's whereabouts.  Now, this isnt a story that unfolds like you initially think it will.  Far Cry 3's story is very similar in context, but told in a more dude-bro lingo, while Far Cry 2 does so in a rich, yet immensly dark tone that will test what kind of man (or woman) you would become in this situation.  Considering that you're thrown into a real-world senario in a fictional African country, the story is constantly unfolding without the player even knowing.  Many games these days have taught us that the story is only told through dialogue or cutscenes, but this game has a story that unfolds with every bullet you fire, and every death you cause.  It's a morailty tale that might give each player the insight as to who or what kind of person he or she is, or will become.

The gunplay is some of the best i've personally encountered in any game.  From the sniper rifles, to the assault rifles, to my personal favorite, the 6P9 silenced Makarov, every gun feels rather unique in its own right.  Each sniper rifle has a different characteristic, the 2 rocket launchers each perform differently, even (most of) the pistols perform differently.  And, of course, everyone's favorite is unlockable very early in the game:  the flare gun.  Spreading fire was the key innovative feature in this game, and when done correctly is a very strategic tactic when taking on the numerous guardposts.

The AI is unscripted and acts accordingly to you.  If you haven't engaged the targets, they talk amongst themselves.  If they think someone is nearby, they will slowly approach the location of the disturbance.  Also, your reputation determines how aggressively the AI will combat you.  The lower your reputation is means the AI will hunt you down because they dont fear you.  The higher the reputation is the more cautious they are, meaning they may find cover or try to flank you.

The graphics and sound seem very dated in 2015, but for it's time it was top notch.  Some might argue that the graphics in Far Cry 2 are better overall than Far Cry 3.  When you factor in small details like shadow resolution, texture quality, and Ambient Occlusion, Far Cry 2 does have the upper hand over 3.

Lastly, the immersion plays a pivotal role in this game.  There is next to no regenerating health and health is restored using syringes or water bottles.  Malaria can attack you at any given point, although as your symptoms improve the time between attacks increases.  When very low on health your character performs a surgical technique
recommended:
in what is basically described as one of the coolest animations in a video game.  Gruesome, sure.  Cool???  You bet!

I've logged over 600 hours in this game on steam, and another 200+ on disk, and almost all invested in single player.  I can't even describe why i keep coming back to this game so much.  Maybe it has to do with the fact that this game allows my imagination to run wild in the combat senarios.  Maybe because the story is that engaging.  I don't know.  What i do know is that since this game came out 6+ years ago, i've only found 1 other game like it, and it still doesn't hold a candle to this sheer brilliance.

Advice for new players reading this???  Give the game some time.  Allow yourself to sink into the story and REALLY think about your every action and what it's doing to you.  Study how every decision you make affects YOU, not your character, but YOU.  And for the love of god, play with all the guns.  There's only 31 guns (with DLC).

9.8/10

reviewText:
Beautiful but empty world.

The guns are a blast to use but the knife is horrible. You can't stealth with a knife??

Driving is fun but not after hours and hours and hours of it. WAY too much back-tracking. The few fast travel spots are always out of the way and you're better off driving/running/boating which eventually makes travel an extreme burden.

Practically all the missions are fetch quests. Get mission, go out, do X, come back, repeat. I wouldn't mind this but the fact that you can't have multiple missions makes me want to cry because the game forces you to do them one by one.

Story is extremely bleh.

Enemy respawns becomes a pain. Enroute to location A, I clear out enemy post B, to make it to location C. On the way back (because the fast travel locations are rarely useful), enemy post B is full of enemies again even though I was just there 5 minutes ago. This is how a game tells you that your actions do not matter and have no effect on the world.

FC2 had potential and it's exhibited FC3 as they fixed most of the problems.

If you have played FC3 prior to FC2, DO NOT PLAY. You have been spoiled with all the fixed mechanics. I certainly was.

reviewText:
There are some aspects to Farcry 2 that i actually like more than 3.

The gameplay of Farcry 2 is pretty much standard like an FPS would be albeit with some addons and differences. You are able to use a primary, a secondary, and melee weapon along with a special weapon including grenades and molotovs. It is a big open world and your main means of travel is by various types of vehicles. To add a bit of realism, guns will jam and explode after awhile of prolonged use.

Unlike its predecessor you can have buddies that protect you and help you on missions. You can pick which character you want to be, though it doesnt really change the outcome. Also unlike its predecessor the setting is completely different as it takes place in Africa and not on tropical islands out on the pacific ocean. While alot of people showed disdain for this setting change, i actually liked the setting and enviroment.

The story of Farcry 2 is gathered via information when you accept missions or when you find cassette tapes left behind by the games main Antagonist The Jackal". Essentially the lore of this game is in the background and you have to research it and pay attention to understand whats going on.

Farcry 2 still holds up well in its Graphics Department for a game from 2008. The Dunia Engine makes use of fire elements burning the enviroments grass and trees
date: as well as showcasing a day and night cycle and weather effects not present in the previous game. As for the sound design the explosions
recommended: guns etc are all top notch while the voiceacting is pretty decent. A few music tracks caught my attention in this game; i really enjoy the calm music transition to the fast battle paced ones when a firefight is happening.\n\nMy only minor gripes with Farcry 2 are having to constantly get Malaria pills
hoursPlayed: and the long drives it kinda takes to get to some areas. Other that that i recommend playing Farcry 2."

reviewText:
This game is basically Africa Simulator 2008.

You play as some faceless, generic mercenary sent to some generic African country to kill some generic arms dealer. Problem is two factions of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are fighting over all the rusted scrap metal and rocks you see throughout the landscape. You are forced to work for both factions and no one seems to notice the fact that you're working for both of them until the end of the game. Like what the ♥♥♥♥, nobody in either of the factions noticed that the guy working for them just ♥♥♥♥ed up their generic bad dude grunts for the 50th time.

Also there's malaria, because some ♥♥♥♥wit in Ubisoft decided that running to the church each time you run out of your prescription pills to fight off your malaria induced seizures and doing some lame, repetitive mission was a good idea. Yeah, great job guys, real good.

Your guns rust and break and ♥♥♥♥ which is pretty neat because it makes using enemy weapons a gamble because they can jam and ♥♥♥♥ you in your ♥♥♥ in a fight. Instead you buy your own weapons using some sketchy black market and some blood diamonds you find sacttered across the countryside that 12 children died trying to mine in a Congolese slave mine.

The generic African country makes for a pretty dope map. There's deserts, savannas, jungles and more. Also thre's outposts. ♥♥♥♥ING OUTPOSTS. Every time you clear one the enemies just respawn. Like how many of these ♥♥♥♥ers are fighting here? How do they manage to return to each outpost 5 seconds after you just blew the ♥♥♥♥ out of it with an RPG? There's towns too but they're pretty lifeless, just more generic mercenary guys standing around.

There aren't a lot of menus in the game. You press a button to bring up the map in your generic mercenary dude's hands and you actually have to look down at it. It's neat but it makes driving a ♥♥♥♥♥. There's some fast travel but only to certain points on the map for all you ♥♥♥♥♥♥ who like driving 40 miles in a game just to get to the mission and die immediately to do all of that driving again. Immersion!

You also have some people you meet in the game which are called buddies that can come save you when you get downed by enemies. They can actually die and when they're dead they're dead for good, which is pretty neat. They also help you out in missions with different approaches and ways to earn more Congolese slave diamonds. Once again, the buddies are all generic mercenary dudes. They try to inject some character into them but it doesn't really work out. I only liked the old Yugoslavian guy out of all of them.

There are wild animals too like zebras and whatnot but they just stand around and watch all the dumb♥♥♥♥♥ fighting over nothing.

Anyway its a pretty sweet game, get the Fortune Edition because you get an OP ♥♥♥ crossbow with exploding bolts which is just sick. Basically the game has everything; war, exploration, jungles, gunfights, companions, generic mercenaries, a pretty cool story once you get into it, and infectious disease. Something for everyone and definately recommended for the best Africa experience in a game yet.

reviewText:
Pros:
+Good variety of very different weapons, and they are all fun to use.
+Beautiful graphics
+Great deal of freedom when doing missions and freedom to do things when you want to do them.
+Gun degradding, wound healing, and no pausing to look at a map add to the immersion.
+Always plenty of guys to shoot and generally good AI

Cons:

- GENERALLY good AI. On harder difficulties, they can see through vegetation unusally well, but not consistently. They're also bullet sponges if you don't use explosives, shotguns, and sniper rifles. Sometimes they are smart and try to flank you, other times they bum rush you like it's their first time playing a shooter.

- Voice acting is very odd; it feels rushed. Considering what kind of game this is trying to be though, this isn't a big deal because...

- ... the plot is more of an excuse to be shooting people in Africa than an actual story.

- Driving to objectives is a 'female dog' (thanks for the PG censorship on an M rated game, Valve) and a half with all the patrols and guard posts that respawn if you walk more than 100m away. I opt to go on foot most of the time becuase, aside from discovering more that way anyway, it's safer.

Objective score: 8/10


It's a tremendous amount of fun to feel like a hunter and methodically approach every conflict, but you don't have to always be stealthy. Constatnly changing up your play style is what makes this game so much fun. It's my go-to game if I just want to relax after a hard day. I like to take my time, slowly pick guys off one by one with the dart rifle, then finish off any remaining bad dudes with a shotgun. But again, I switch it up often.

Silly ways to have fun:
+ The flare gun is a one hit kill and magically kills everyone in a car, even though it doesn't set the car on fire nor directly hit anyone inside.

+The AS50 can shoot through more than one person.

+ Sneak up behind an enemy, place an ied, back up, *boom*.

+ I never get tired of sniping guys in boats. They fly out sideways about 5-7 feet in a perfectly straight line.

Subjective score: 10/10 - Would bless the rains down in Africa again... but fire spreads more easily when it's dry.

reviewText:
Many games try to be immersive, but Far Cry 2 really pulls it off. In this war-torn African country, you are a mercenary and everyone hates you, even the warlords who employ you. You'll need a stealthy approach, but there are no detection meters, only careful attention. You'll need to trek across a beautiful open world, but there's only a paper map to get you there. You'll need money, but the only people worth saving in this country have no money, and the mission will earn you $0 on completion. The guys who have money are first justifiable, then amoral, then despicable, but by now you're hooked, and besides, the arms dealer promised you a grenade launcher if you took out his competition.

Have you ever had to watch your friend die in your arms because you weren't fast enough at clearing out an enemy guard post, or because your gun jammed in the middle of a firefight, or because you had a sudden attack of malaria, or because you set the entire complex on fire and blew up the getaway car? You will, after you play Far Cry 2. Where Spec Ops: The Line is a self-aware jab at the player for playing an FPS, Far Cry 2 takes the time to engage you first, and trusts that you will realize what a monster you've become once the missions start being things like The enemy can't fight if you blow up their water supply."

I described this game to an African coworker and his response was

reviewText: This is one of the best shooters I've ever played, better than the games afterwards. The open world activities are structured in a very simplistic way, but achieving your objectives is anything but simple. You constantly feel like you're under threat of being attacked when you're outside, and you have to spend about 15 minutes preparing for each mission. Picking and replacing your weapons and maybe even getting new Malaria pills. There's a lot to contend with, you have to take cover and buy yourself time to heal yourself, you need to make sure your weapons don't jam, and you need to defend the buddies you bring with you because they absolutely can die, leaving them gone for the rest of the game. All of this means that pulling off the missions feels INCREDIBLY rewarding.\n\nHonestly I've never played a shooter as immersive as this, and yes the malria and guard post respawn issue is annoying, but not enough to break the game entirely. It's dynamic, it's dark and the world actually feels hostile to you rather than an open world playground. If you're willing to put up with its quirks, you'll find one of the most rewarding shooters of last gen here. They don't make 'em like this anymore.

reviewText:
Wow, talk about a game that misses the point. As an American male, I was raised on a steady diet of action movies and games that fed me exactly the sort of masculine power fantasy that I have come to expect from shooters.

From classics like DooM and Duke Nukem to modern masterpieces like Medal of Honor and Call of Duty: Black Ops, games have understood that the best thing to do is inflate my ego to as big as possible by giving me complete domination over enemies and pride of place in the narrative as I, the hero, destroy all evil and save the world.

These games understand that from the day I was born, I was given toy guns to play with and taught to idolize soldiers, sheriffs, pretty much anyone in a position of authority with a gun.

Which is where Far Cry 2 drops the ball. I mean honestly this game fails so bad it's like it tries to be the OPPOSITE of a power fantasy. You show up in Africa and immediately get malaria. You screw up your mission, nobody cares about you, your guns jam, you have to scrounge for cash, your vehicles keep breaking down, and everyone wants to shoot you. You have to pry bullets out your ankle or pull them out of your arm with your teeth, and you have to watch buddies bleed to death unless you shoot them.Fire will spread unpredictably and burn you to death. AND YOU CAN'T CURE THE MALARIA. You can just keep popping pills, but to get the pills you have to do favors for an underground resistance run by the people stupid enough to stick around while two militias fight over the country.

Instead of feeling like a badass when you kill guys, they cry out in pain, writhe around, and respawn 15 minutes later. You are a bad person, your buddies are bad people, and you get missions from bad people to do bad things. You deceive and kill people for no reason other than a potential meager profit. Nothing you do makes the world a better place and you never feel good about it or powerful when you do it.

So yeah, Far Cry 2, way to miss the point that basically every other FPS game in the world has understood. Other games realize that I can't get hard without getting a sweet headshot, but Far Cry 2 just makes me feel bad about shooting people. Honestly, what's the point of a video game that doesn't make me feel good about murder? That's like watching a movie where you don't get to see any ♥♥♥♥ or explosions. Lame.

Plus this game is set in Africa. Who cares about Africa? Why not set your game some place cool like a tropical island? That's what made Far Cry good. Far Cry 2 is brown and sad. Far Cry was green and blue and happy! It was like a sweet vacation where you also got to kill some dudes with some rad guns. That sounds perfect, not like the miserable slog through a hot, insect infested swamp or through a scrapyard with burning tire fires that Far Cry 2 gives you.

This game is basically Blood Diamond without the feel good message at the end. Did you get to see Jennifer Connelly's ♥♥♥♥ in Blood Diamond? No. Were there explosions in Blood Diamond? A few, I guess. But still. That movie wasn't exactly as awesome as something like The Expendables. And this game is no Duke Nukem Forever.

Thankfully it looks like maybe Far Cry 3 realizes where Far Cry 2 went wrong and has brought us back to the head to a beautiful island paradise
date: grab a bunch of sick weapons
recommended: and kill the ♥♥♥♥ out of some pirates to save your bros." Now THAT is a story I can get behind! And this time instead of African resistance fighters

So with its RPG mechanics (which are great because leveling up is a great way to reinforce the power fantasy) and its return to a hero I can care about instead of the horrific mercenary with zero morals that I have to play as in Far Cry 2

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is one of the best open world games out there. Set in a war-torn African country, there's a wide variety of places to see: from deserts, to deep jungles, small towns...

The story is pretty good. You arrive at this country in order to kill the Jackal, the guy who armed both sides of the conflict. Things go wrong, and you end up taking jobs from the different factions in order to gain their trust, and, in exchange, getting information about your target. Luckily, you're not alone in this mission; although the troops will shoot you on sight even if you're working for them, you'll still come across several buddies (foreigners, just like you) who will help you out during missions.

There's plenty of stuff to do in this game. Besides the main missions, there are different missions you can take, including taking convoys transporting weapons, assassinating certain targets, and helping your buddies out. Also, you'll encounter enemy outposts, and, although taking them out is fun, they respawn quickly, which gets tiring after some time, and you'll end up trying to use fast travel (which, by the way, is only available at certain locations, in the form of bus stops) as much as you can to avoid the outposts.

The environment, as mentioned, is quite varied, and the map is huge. You can move around it using different vehicles, including jeeps, trucks, quads, boats, to name a few. You can unlock safehouses on the different areas, and there's hidden stuff to look for.

Another interesting mechanic is the sickness level: your character is infected with malaria, and there's nothing you can do to cure it, you can only take pills in order to control it. While it's an annoyance most of the time (especially if you have a malaria attack right in the middle of a firefight), it's still an interesting mechanic. There's also weapon degradation, meaning that you'll need to get new weapons from time to time, or run the risk of a weapon jamming at the wrong time. Luckily, weapons bought at stores are always available at armouries next to them.

Well, in conclusion, this is a really good game, one you should really play.

reviewText:
In my opinion Far Cry 2 is the best game in the series. If you liked Far Cry 3/4 but found it too easy or dumbed down, you will love Far Cry 2. Lacking features such as crafting and such from the more recent games (crafting is too overrated), it gives you a gritty experience of guerrilla warfare in an African state.

I'd recommend playing with Dylans Realism Modification (gives the game an extra tweak to make you plan your attacks)
I'd also recommend installing Far Cry 2 Graphical Enhancement Suite (to make sunsets and the overall atmosphere look even more beautiful)

The game engine is solid, the only occasional physics bugs you will encounter will be when one vehicle crashes into another, or when you walk around the safe zones and the AI  occasionally gets killed by the physics objects. This can be hillariously funny, especially when the wildlife gets involved. (It doesnt happen often enough to be something to worry about, it's only happend to me about 3 times in my entire playtime).
I have never had the game crash, ever. Even with the use of Dylans mod and the Graphical ES.

The gunplay is satisfying, people complain that jamming weapons are annoying, however if you purchase your own you will rarely or even never encounter this. I rather enjoy the weapon jamming as it makes the combat more exciting and unpredictable.

There is also a multiplayer feature for the game which you could make use of if you want to fight some friends.

With a reasonably cheap price, and occasional sales, i'd definatly recommend picking this game up.

reviewText: Probably one of the most thematically difficult games to experience due to the graphic potrayal of real-world issues: conflict diamonds, arms races, disease-attrition (malaria), internally displaced persons/refugees, and ideologically-fueled factions fighting for control over scraps of impoverished landscape. Unlike it's sequel, FarCry 3, this game feels less cartoony and emotionally vapid because it keeps the player vulnerable, evenly equiped with enemies, and isolated in the vastness of the maps. This can be frustrating at times, but ultimately (I argue) makes for a more valuable experience. Your mortality is quickly equated with that of the world's other NPCs and inhabitants, and so the destruction, or implied destruction, of those lives is more profound.\n\nWhile FarCry 3 represents a huge step forward in gaming technology and is a worthwhile experience in it's own right, it's emotional impact and themes fell flat for me because of how the game held your hand throughout and superpowered the player very quickly with outrageous rewards for menial tasks. I played FarCry 2 after finishing the third game, and felt a much deep connection to the aesthetics of this one. Although I think it's fair to say that the plot is almost non-existant, and certainly not a coherent narrative than a series of similaraly motif-ed scenes joined by some key characters and locals; the plot only really comes together toward the end of each chapter" when the principle antagonists are reintroduced to the game after remaining shadowy figures
date: alluded to but not seen or felt.\n\nOverall
recommended: a fastastic game with some flaws
hoursPlayed: but one that has given me more pause to consider the real world than anything else I have ever played."

reviewText:
It took every part of my being to push through and finally see Far Cry 2 to the end. This is because it's not only mentally exhausting, but emotionally as well.

Let's get what it doesn't do well out of the way, because it doesn't do a lot of ♥♥♥♥ well. There's all sorts of fun things that people hate like weapon degredation, the malaria mechanic which gives you a vomit-tinged screen until you press H and pop a refreshing malaria-fighting Certs into your mouth, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ open world which is full of repetitive quests that revolve around shooting the other soldiers of fortune you're working alongside of, or shooting a man in a suit, or blowing up a truck that's driving around in circles. It's really, really ♥♥♥♥ing grindy too. The secondary missions don't offer much more than just your stupid mercenary friend calling you up in the middle of your mission to ask you to do something so he can be a bigger, more amoral ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for dollars than you can. All it is is you being an unpleasant little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for money to other unpleasant little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s also here for money.

Are you still with me? Good. Because it turns out that this game has so many flaws it has essentially developed Three Stooges Syndrome, the syndrome where it has lots of bad ideas yet they all don't end up killing the game, but rather strengthening it.

All of the things up there would normally have killed my interest in this game really ♥♥♥♥ing dead. And they did the last two times I tried to play it, all the way back in 2010. But today, the game clicks for me. I don't know whether it was the depressed state I was in or whether I've realized that AAA video game design has been so design-by-committee that this was the thing I ended up dying for. This game ended up satisfying something I wasn't aware that I needed than, say, Grand Theft Auto 5 or Saints Row the Third, which are just straight-up celebrations of how awesome you are. Far Cry 2 tells you to your face that you're just another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in a jungle with a barely functioning weapon, and that you won't matter if you live or die.

But also at this point in time, the mental state of your mind also is very, very helpful when getting into this game. In order to actually sit down and play it, you must learn to accept the environment that the game is forcing you into. Everything is ♥♥♥♥. War is constant. The missions suck. Nothing really works. You are accepting missions in order to make like worse for everybody. Your guns get dirty really fast. You're trading rough diamonds for all the guns you can get your hands on. Absolute ♥♥♥♥♥ in buggies and jeeps and cars will drive off the road to try and run you down for no other reason than you are there, and you are a target, and everyone hates you. Everyone hates you here in Africa, and if it means that you will die so that there's one less target to shoot, you're gonna get shot. The work is absolutely repetitive, the fast travel system is the worst, and if you lose your car because some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s blew it up because they were trying to shoot you while you were using your car for cover, you're gonna have to hoof it. You are a person in a ♥♥♥♥ tornado. And the ♥♥♥♥ tornado has everyone you know and love in it. And you all can't stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ into the ♥♥♥♥ tornado. And because you all can't stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the ♥♥♥♥ gets into your eyes and mouth and face and you're swearing bloody revenge on the people who keep involuntarily ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ into the ♥♥♥♥ tornado, and soon you're all at each others throats while your lives become nothing but ♥♥♥♥ and tornadoes and blood and broken teeth.

That's what it's like to play Far Cry 2. I don't recommend it for everyone. Hell, I don't know who I can recommend it for. It's a great game because it evokes that experience and keeps it consistent up to the end, but it's such an unpleasant experience that I'm surprised it got published at all.

Besides, didn't Spec Ops the Line do this sort of thing, but within ten hours?

reviewText:
It’s a great African driving simulator.

But really…

I had high hopes for Far Cry 2. I saw the great reviews it got. But only 5 hours into it I had to stop playing. It was a combination of complete boredom, frustration and knowing I’ve already experienced all the game would have to offer.

Far Cry 2 is a very open world game. After the first guided mission you are free to go wherever you want, which is nice. Except…

Here is the formula for every Far Cry 2 mission I encountered in 5 hours
+Drive to a place that has a mission available
+Drive to the waypoint on your map for that mission. Which is always far away.
+Get shot at driving through areas you’ve already cleared.
+Repair your vehicle.
+Take down a random vehicle with a turret.
+Repair your vehicle.
+Complete mission.

That’s it…that’s how it was for 5 hours before I knew that was all the game had to offer and show me.

I might have been able to push through if the missions were close to one another. But, there’s SO much driving in this game. I didn’t mind that in itself. The fact that it’s not even enjoyable really killed it for me. I thought after clearing a checkpoint it would be good from then on out…WRONG. Enemies always respawn everywhere. Which means you get in constant battles when you just want to drive through an area you already cleared. It makes me feel like I’m not accomplishing anything and gives me no incentive to kill enemies. I just resorted to flying through the checkpoints and killing any vehicles that gave chase to me.

Far Cry 2, in my opinion, commits several cardinal sins in video games.
+Respawning enemies
+Enemies that can hit you from a mile away, consistently. Even with a shotgun?!
+Enemies that can instantly hit you each time you break from cover
+Enemies that know your exact location

Pros
+Open world style of gameplay
+Graphics
+Good shooter at its core
+Capturing the African environment and culture
+Music

Cons
+Respawning enemies
+Extremely repetitive gameplay
+Too much driving around
+Enemy AI
+Didn't feel rewarded for doing anything
+Strange run on sentences with the voice acting


4/10

Far Cry 2 really does have some good mechanics and systems it employs. But the negative things I mentioned above far outweigh the positives. I couldn’t continue playing and therefore can only recommend if it’s on a big sale and you’re really curious. Otherwise, stay away.
