reviewText:
As much as I want to recommend this game, I can't. There are just too many immersion and game breaking bugs that will never be fixed.

I'll admit, I did have fun for a while. Sneaking into a heavily guarded fort on a rainy night, killing the target and sneaking back out after only killing one guard with just a knife felt pretty awesome. But there are just so many annoying factors for the majority of the game, and let me start off with the two biggest issues:

THERE ARE PROGRESSION BLOCKING/SAVE CORRUPTING BUGS THAT FORCE YOU TO RELOAD AN EARLIER SAVE.
And you have no idea when they occurred. I had this happen to me twice in one playthrough, but luckily I had many save files to fall back on and find the ones that still worked, which set me back 4 hours. I almost rage quit and I wouldn't blame anyone for doing so. Having that many save files is also annoying because it takes forever to open the load menu because each save is ~5MB. I'm not completely sure, but I noticed that when the door guards tell you to go look for a guy in captivity, your game is about to break. Look at the map to see where the buddy is, then reload a save that was before you talked to the guard and go find them on your own. I have heard of other bugs like key NPCs vanishing or just refusing to talk to you, but I did not personally experience them.

THERE IS A BUG THAT ONLY LETS YOU LISTEN TO 11/18 JACKAL TAPES.
Jackal tapes are the ramblings of the arms dealer you are sent to kill. The Jackal is the main villain. These tapes are the only way you can get inside his head and see why he behaves the way he does...and you can't get them all in the current state of the game. This is a pretty big part of the story that just goes missing, especially because those last few tapes reveal a lot about the character (because the majority of the game doesn't tell you anything story related). How do I know that? Because I looked them up on YouTube, the only way to listen to them all now.

The game crashes constantly with DX10.
Use DX9.

Enemies and supplies respawn after they go out of draw distance.
Go too far away and come back, and they'll all be there again. Not only is this annoying when you're trying to get somewhere that involves backtracking, but it makes you feel like nothing you do matters. It just wastes your time.

Enemies know exactly where you are the instant you miss.
Good luck trying to take out a base without save-scumming. The instant you miss one bullet, they all know your exact location and start closing in and shooting even if you used a silent weapon like the dart gun. This is a glaring flaw because you have to plan your attacks on every set of enemies. They can very quickly overwhelm, flank, and kill you on higher difficulties so you must try to take out as many as possible from range. Don't even think about turning down the difficulty, because...

Enemies are stupid.
Even if you crank the difficulty up, which gives the AI the ability to flank you and such, they'll still do some really dumb stuff. I once blew up a barrel from a distance and the AI decided the best way to investigate the situation was to gather around it. About 6 guys just grouped up and I shot them one at a time. They never took cover, just spun around looking for me. On easier difficulties they'll run" up to you
date: stare at you for a few seconds
recommended:
then fire. They seem to have overreacted to far cry 1 difficulty complaints.

Cell tower and arms dealer side missions are always the same.
There is absolutely no variety in any of these. The cell towers have you assassinate one guy always dressed in a suit with a desert eagle in random heavily guarded areas. Sometimes he's in a car. Sometimes he's in a cease-fire zone. The arms dealer missions are EXACTLY the same: it's always blow up a truck with a technical in front and behind it driving in a convoluted circle on one of the 9 map squares. Always. There is no creativity whatsoever
hoursPlayed:
and it's pure padding.

Most of your time will be spent driving.
Almost every mission will have you travel across the whole map repeatedly
voteText: and because of respawning enemy camps this can take forever. Good luck driving through an outpost because the AI will get in their cars
helpfulPercent: cheat by going faster than you can to catch up to you
votesHelpful: and blast you away. The only time you can "drive" past an outpost is when you go full speed in a swamp boat
votesTotal: the AI doesn't seem to notice/catch up in those cases. There are 5 "fast" travel points across the 9 map squares in an X shape
votesFunny:
but that's not enough and normally you still have to do a good bit of driving to and from them. Driving in-and-of-itself is annoying as well because...

Vehicles have horrible behavior.
They struggle to go over the smallest of obstacles and handle like arcade racers. If you manage to get your vehicle stuck on a 6 inch flat rock or in a dried up river bed while it's upright you can't push it off
commentsCount:
you just have to abandon it. But if you drive your open top vehicle off a 50 foot cliff and it ends up sideways or upside down after bouncing around a few times (not damaging your health at all) you can just go to one side and spam the use key to flip it upright. All of this is very immersion breaking.

The vehicle repair animation is stupid.
I realize you can't expect them to put in a completely realistic fixing animation where you rebuild the engine or something
column16: but at least have some variety. All you do is put a socket wrench on one nut and twist it for a few seconds. That's it. For every vehicle. If you get a repair manual

and even Jeep(TM)(R)(C)'s all have a magical nut that will instantly repair a vehicle to factory conditions when twisted. Who knew?

There are no civilians outside.

There are infinitely spawning mobs and clairvoyant AI in Cease-fire zones.

Weapon durability only applies to you.

reviewText:
Best game in the series. Far Cry 2 takes itself seriously, presenting the experience of being a mercenary fighting in the middle of a nameless African nation's civil war as a grim affair. Unlike the later games which glorify violence, Far Cry 2's tone is one of a much more mature nature.

It's still a game about being a morally grey character in a morally grey war, but it does it in about the most tasteful way it can be done.

I highly recommend using Dylan's FC2 mod as well, as it tightens up the gameplay and addresses the game's wonky AI checkpoints.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is an awesome game, but it have some mistakes,that are successfully removed in next game from FC franchise, Far Cry 3. Game looks really good. There is a lot of weapons that you can buy. You get diamonds as reward for completing mission. With this you can easy customize your weapons and cars. It is an awesome, great looking open world in Africa.

Single player: Single player is main reason to buy this game. As i said before, the game looks amazing. It have great environment - deserts, rivers, cities. Missions are great. I had only one big problem with single player, and this one is: enemy outposts ! You capture one, you go other area and when you come back - there are again enemies. Later, when you have a lot of weapons this is not such a big problem - but at beggining you can have some troubles with lack of bullets.

Multiplayer: Unfortonatly, MP in this game is DEAD.

reviewText:
I'm just gonna go ahead and say that FC2 is my favorite game in the series. I found Far Cry 3 to be casualized and easy. There was no challenge from start to finish and it follows the same Ubisoft open world formula from recent Assassin's Creed games. Far Cry 2 is vastly different and I prefer it over Far Cry 3 and 3.1, I mean 4 for a number of reasons.

I mean just the fact I don't have to climb any radio towers to see more of the map or having the map littered with collectable icons are great. The feel and sounds of the guns are also really good for a 2008 game. Every gun in FC2 feels unique and don't feel like a toy compared to FC3 and 4. Guns jam, they have recoil, they show signs of wear and tear, and more. They don't feel like brand new military weapons but rather feel like they fit the African milita setting of the game. Every gun in FC3 and 4 feel like they're brand new and the sound is muddy when shooting them. In my opinion the gunplay in FC2 is some of the best I've played in a first person shooter, and I play quite a few of them (check my Steam game list if you want).

The AI I think is pretty decent for a 2008 title. There are games released today that have far worse AI than this game. In Far Cry 3/4 if you're up on a cliff or a decent distance away and you take an enemy down via sniping then the others in the camp or nearby will always somehow zero in on your location. In FC2 the enemies will try to help their fellow comrades by carrying them to safety and search the immediate area, not instantly know which direction the shot came from like in FC3/4.

As for the malaria it never really inconvenienced me when out and about, and I thought it was a pretty nice touch to the overall setting. I also don't feel it artificially prolonged the game like say having a crap ton of collectables all over the map.

As for the story I'd have to sayit's not the best. In fact I enjoyed Far Cry 3's story more than FC2, but when it comes to the gameplay then FC2 for me wins easily.

I give it an 8/10.

PS. Don't mind the 2.6 hours on record. I played this game to death when it came out on PS3 and bought it on Steam a couple years ago on sale.

reviewText:
Cabela's African Adventure 2 is a thrilling joyride to the heart of the African soul and spirit of hunting through the eyes of a mute foreigner who has come to visit his old pal Steve Rambo, who has started a new life as a hunting instructor and a Nietzche fanatic. As you, the noble white man, enter the country, the atmosphere instantly contracts you with Malaria and you have to face the ultimate test of survival to find your old pal Steve Rambo.

In the game you hunt the most dangerous prey of all, Malaria pills. In the process you must cope with the locals who are  actually all foreigners too, but all the locals have left, so does that make the foreigners the locals? This is one of the mysteries the game gives you, the story keeps you guessing as you do work for two guys who hang out with foreigners all the time. Bill and Ted give you folders of diamonds instantly transferred to your International Diamond Account and order you to blow ♥♥♥♥ up, giving you the dough whether you actually go to complete the task or not.

They also warn that their men will also shoot you because it's that much of a black op, but aren't they all foreigners as well? Both the UFLL (United Females Lottery League) and APR (American Punk Rockers) mercenaries look the same, so how can they tell eachother apart? See, this is the level of deep story and imagery the game gives you. Overall Cabela's African Adventure 2 is a fantastic game about learning medical perscription, maintaining vehicles and dealing with the explosive tourism that plagues the country.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is one of a kind experience and although is quite criticized by fans of the franchise I find it to be one of the most underrated games I have seen.

50km2 of awesomness	Set on Africa, you take the role of a mercenary who finds himself in a middle of a war. The Government has been dismantled and there are now two factions trying to take control over it. Your goal is simple: kill the Jackal, an infamous drug dealer who benefits from the war selling guns to both factions.
In order to do so, you must shot your way to the Jackal. You can ally with both or just one faction which makes for a non-linear story; something really appreciated for those who value replay-ability.
Powered by Dunia Engine, the visuals are really well done and you will find yourself on savannas and desserts within a effectively designed world. The engine does a good job improving the stealth aspect thanks to day/night cycles that actually varies the way the IA work as well as includying dynamic fire propagation on the grass along others.

Inmersive and awesome to explore	As the franchise got as accustomed, the world is filled with cars, trucks, hang gliders, boats and ATV's. Throughout the story, you will need to take pills that help you to control your malaria. Oh, yeah! You got malaria at the very beginning of the story. Failing to take said pills (which runs out really fast) will make you pass out and you will have to restart the mission again.
There is not a big selection of guns on this one though. I have to note also just how minimalistic and inmersive the interface on this game is. You don't check the map by a popup window in front of the actual gameplay but rather, your character holds an actual map wherever you need it and so on with a lot of elements on the game. Those are little details I love to find given they improve the impression that you are really there.

It definitely has its problems, though	I hope you like driving, because oh boy, you are going to drive a lot. Not that it gets incredibly tedious. During your driving you will find enemies along the way which helps keeping things interesting. However, you are still going to drive a lot.
Likewise, to be considered a realistic game it's surprising how long it takes to kill enemies. Not everyday you see a regular person wearing nothing but a t-shirt get shot six times on the chest and still count the story, but enemies on Far Cry 2 sure can. Nevertheless, it works both ways considering you can walk to an enemy from a good distance while he is shooting directly at you and still kill him with a machete.
The story is great, with interesting dialogues and memorable quotes but I really could never put my heands on the multiplayer, something about Ubisoft's servers not responding when I tried to sing up. I have never heard of it being shut down but to be honest I haven't bothered to look up much on the subject. Multiplayer was just a feature in this game, singleplayer is where the fun part is at.
Playing this game on the Hardcore or Infamous difficulty mode makes it so much enjoyable, really. Because you can't get shot nearly as much as Normal you start making better strategies than just show up with your car in the middle of your enemy's base and start shooting everywhere like you were blind-folded.

So, should you buy it?	You're damn right you should. Far Cry 2 has to be one of the most enjoyable shooters I have ever played. An awesome game about exploring, surviving and killing so you can get a sweet, sweet revenge on everything the Jackal has put you and others through. Oh, and also, about driving. A hella lot of it. Let's also take a moment to appreciate the fact that this was (and probably will) be the last Far Cry without uPlay DRM. Anyway, despite all the flaws (which aren't that many, really) Far Cry 2 is well worthy of your money.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Far Cry® 2: Fortune's Edition
Original Release: 2008
Genre Tags: FPS; Action; Open World;
My Overall Grade: B
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 12-25 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Fans of the intellectual property; Aesthetes; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWMany people were disappointed in Far Cry 2, and it does have its flaws, but I still found it to be an enjoyable experience overall.  The game succeeds in being immersive and captivating, and the actual gameplay is exciting and has some novel mechanics. Also, there is an interesting story aspect imbedded in the main campaign. These qualities can help some people overlook the minor annoyances; others however may feel like it’s not worth putting up with them, especially if they aren't as interested in the narrative and atmospheric aspects.

I felt that the environments were well-designed and the gameworld was a pleasure to explore. The graphics are pretty solid, and the animations and effects are noticeably good.    Far Cry 2 definitely has a nice setting.  If you enjoy immersing yourself in foreign gameworlds, you should like this.

The gameplay is also pretty fun overall. There are a lot of good ideas and unique nuances in the game. Also, the combat can be exciting and the open-world allows you to plan your route of attack any way you would like.  There are some annoying aspects to the gameplay, though.  But there are some pretty awesome missions sprinkled throughout the game that make putting up with the annoying parts worth it.

As for those annoying parts, there are two main aspects of the gameplay that can become tedious at times. For one: the gun jamming. The idea of implementing mechanics where guns found on the ground have little ammo and jam frequently sounds interesting on paper, but it needs to be executed well. In Far Cry 2, there are times it winds up being far more annoying than interesting. And the other main gripe with the game is the extremely frequently respawning guard posts.  Clearing 5 guard posts every time you want to travel on the map gets old fast.

But both of these annoyances can be extensively minimized by just playing on easy.  Guns will jam far less often, and you will able to drive right through the guard posts instead of clearing them out every time. So I suggest you don’t play this particular game on a high difficulty.  You will only magnify the aforementioned faults with the game and allow them to overshadow the fun parts. And as I mentioned, there are some really fun missions in the campaign.

So if you would be interested in this kind of game, and feel like you would be able to enjoy the good parts, then Far Cry 2 should be something you consider checking out.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText: What's best about Far Cry 2?The true answer is that there is no one thing that can be considered best about Far Cry 2. Its brilliance lies in the fact that it is more than the sum of its already impressive parts. Essentially the game is a playground that caters for whatever mood players find themselves in. Want to storm into an enemy encampment in broad daylight John Rambo style, perhaps running a few unfortunate soldiers down with a MG-mounted Jeep before letting loose with your grenade launcher? Go ahead. Prefer to fast-forward the incredible day/night cycle to midnight by taking a nap in one of the Safe Houses and sneak in under the cover of darkness before slicing and dicing from behind with your machete? Be the game's guest.Ubisoft Montreal isn't, of course, the first developer to do open world shooting.But it is so well executed, so technically proficient that I can't help but feel it at least matches and in some areas even surpasses other games of the genre.After choosing from a selection of nine refreshingly un-clichéd mercenaries, ranging from a 45-year-old Mauritian to a 38-year-old Algerian you're thrust into an unnamed African country being torn apart by two warring factions.Your mission: To kill The Jackal, an arms dealer who's fuelling both sides of the conflict with weapons, and making a mint as a result. You immediately run into problems - malaria wraps its diseased mitts around your innards, forcing you to collapse as soon as you arrive in town. You wake, groggily, and find The Jackal standing ominously above you. He knows everything - who you are, why you're here and how defenceless you've become as a result of the malaria. In pity, he hands you a machete and a hand gun, and lets you live. This is where Far Cry 2 kicks off.Outside, all hell breaks loose. The United Front for Liberation and Labour (UFLL) and the Alliance for Popular Resistance (APR) are going at it in the streets. You make a break for it, dodging bullets as you head anywhere as long as it's away from certain death. But there is no escape - either you're shot or you collapse from the malaria. You wake in a slaughter house just outside town. A merc, one that you did not pick to play as at the beginning of the game but is determined by that choice, now reckons you owe him a few favours on account of him saving your ♥♥♥. From there, it's up to you what jobs you take on, whether it be paid work from the UFLL or APR, malaria pill jobs from various good Samaritans, weapon vendor jobs that unlock new purchasable gear, buddy jobs that improve your 'history' with the NPC mercs or assassination jobs dished out by a disguised voice heard from communication masts. What they all have in common, however, is combat, and it's here that Far Cry 2 initially frustrates.I'm used to developers holding my hands so tightly during game tutorials, and even beyond, that Far Cry 2 will at first jar with many due to the fact that it's actually pretty tough right from the start. Simply shooting stuff is difficult. Unlike the console versions, the PC version doesn't have a snap to target function when you zoom down the barrel of your gun. This is fine - the PC keyboard and mouse set up allows for a degree of FPS accuracy console controllers simply can't. But this doesn't stop your weapons, especially at the beginning of the game, from being, frankly, crap.You'll find the recoil offensive, the jamming so regular you'll tear your hair out and the enemies so hard to spot in your splendid surroundings that it won't be long before you grab a mouthful of dirt. The healing system doesn't help. Whenever your health dips you can inject yourself with magic hit point juice. That's fine, but when your health bar is almost depleted healing will instead trigger an animation where you gruesomely pick bullets out of the holes in your skin. The problem is that this animation, which takes about five seconds to complete, is interruptible by enemy fire. Some will applaud Ubisoft Montreal's approach. Some will criticise it. Whatever your opinion, persevere. Soldier through the difficult opening few hours, keep earning diamonds, keep reducing the recoil and reliability of your weapons with upgrades, and above all, keep experimenting, because it's only through experimentation that you'll realise Far Cry 2's undoubted potential.The save system differs from the console versions in that you can save absolutely anywhere and whenever you want. There are no checkpoints in Far Cry 2, at least not in the traditional sense of the term. Instead, you'll get a pop-up asking you if you want to save after you complete mission objectives, when you use the coach transportation system or when you go to sleep using one of the Safe Houses. The many guarded checkpoints will annoy some, but for others they will reinforce the feeling that you're never safe. Because the map is so big, you'll spend a lot of your time driving around. If you're going to stick to the road, you're going to run into at least three checkpoints along the way. Every soldier manning the checkpoints has a shoot first, ask questions later policy, too, making driving more a case of survival than sight seeing. The enemies respawn, too, so you can never once and for all clear enemies from that check point on that road you keep using to get to and from town.Obviously if you're a shooter fan you should buy this game. A simple glance at the score should confirm in your mind, if there was ever any doubt, that Far Cry 2 is nothing but brilliant.

reviewText:
It's not the violent slapstick and chain-splodes of the hysterically volatile camps, filled to the brim with ammo dumps and fuel tanks. It's not the moments of pure adrenalised catharsis, where, rifle in hand, you power through smoke and machinegun fire, enemies to the left and right. It's not even when you stride through the ruins, calmly putting down survivors by plunging a machete into their chests.

No. Its appeal is in the moments beforehand - when, from some lofty perch, you think of what's to come. You check your ammo. You reload your weapons. You heal up. You anticipate. It is the calm before the storm. You are the match before the flame. In the most player-centric world yet created, in a game that you know is about to surprise, delight and enthral you, standing still, waiting to strike, is one of the finest pleasures you can experience.

After playing Far Cry 2, I'm simply unable to go back to straight and simple first-person shooters. This game has executed my expectations. Would you, could you, go back to games with similar gunfights as this, but along a more rigid axis? I think your own expectations are going to rise dramatically. And I think you really should play this game.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is one of the best shooters of all time. Like any good story, it's loosely inspired by Heart of Darkness. And believe you me, the story, barebones as it might seem (no traditional cutscene until the very very end), is shocking and incredible. Trust no one, shoot everything that moves, you will be friendlier with your ingame buddies than your real life ones, all that good vidyagamey stuff.

Far Cry 2 avoids many of the flaws of its successor - a game I would best describe as Robinson Crusoe for somebody who wants a power trip. Not knocking its many successes (the animal system, etc), but many RPGs make the mistake of letting the player get away with pretty much anything in the lategame. Far Cry 2 is not an RPG. You will make decisions, but you're not in search of XP: you're in search of a better chance at survival, and if you're feeling lucky, maybe you'll try to keep your buddies alive too.

Far Cry 2 is an experience.I chose to disable the crosshair because muh immersion (note the presence of ironsights makes that decision slightly less punishing compared to, say half-life) and I highly recommend you do the same as well, because this game, despite having questionable graphics from the mid-2000s, works best when you're immersed and twitchy and prepared mentally for the worst.

Far Cry 2 gives you nothing. You have to earn every buddy, hoard every high quality weapon you own, build your reputation with the factions brick by brick. Regardless of your choice of APR or UFLL - pick your own lesser of two evils - your greatest enemy is the jungle itself. Your guns will jam and even break (usually when you need them most), the harsh terrain and many, many faction guard posts means that even a trip between two safehouses a mile apart must be planned and taken with the utmost caution, and don't even get me started on malaria. If you play Far Cry 2, prepare to be challenged.

Far Cry 2 is a first person shooter that does not encourage combat. Even one soldier is a very valid threat of death. You do have a safety net in the form of your buddies, but don't rely on it. It's almost always better to detour around or sneak past a guard post than to plow through it. Stealth is encouraged but not rewarded - you can stealth kill, but guards will almost always scream out upon death, meaning that a kill threatens you more than helps you. Even carrying a sniper rifle at all times (highly recommended) and engaging from a great distance carries great risk, from multiple guards jumping in jeep and running and gunning you down, or mortar strikes, or a random patrol invalidating 90% of your hard work. Recommendation? Be ready to move, always keep your health high, and your life is worth more than anything else, even (especially?) the mission.

Far Cry 2 will not leave you in the same place you began it. Many (most?) video games place you as the most important person in the world and give you all the tools to your success. This is not a power fantasy. This isn't even an underdog fantasy. This is hard work, and any reward will be in your head alone. You will be beaten down and beaten up, but if you beat the game, you will genuinely feel accomplishment and success unlike any game out there.

reviewText:
Hi everyone! Go to my profile to check out some of my helpful reviews!

Far Cry 2 is honestly the most realistic game I've ever played. Imagine Insurgency with missions and a good storyline. Mainly, all you have to do is start out fighting for one client, and from there you collect more, in which you get more missions, in which you get more resources.

The map is a greatly sized one compared to other games'. You have a map and a GPS to always use, that directs you to certain missions. Many of these are made to let the player use his/her own style, such as stealth, agressive, defence, or just plain old sniper from a long distance. The system of the stealth is mostly featuring missions like save the hostage, kill all the men without having a specific one notice, or taking/stealing a certain object smoothly. I, for example, on the hostage mission, enjoy going in, silent as possible, not being detected, killing some guards without the others noticing, and then saving the hostage. Then I shoot everthing.

The graphics are fantastic, as well as the multiplayer function, though my favorite is single player. The gameplay is tricky and fun at the same time, as well as the enemies (AI Units) are actually intelligent! This suprised me, when I tried to headshot one, missed, and they ran in different directions, to good cover, and one behind the hostage.

Also, the cars and planes are very well made. It is so realistic! No crosshairs in the game, no big texts on the top, but it just looks like you are looking from a first person view in real life. Another neat feature is the diamond GPS, where you can detect where hidden diamonds are and use them to trade for weaponry and other important goods that will need to be used to survive. My favorite part is that...

reviewText: This game is a hidden treasure that all players must have in their collection. There is so much realism, so much detail, and so many more features than Far Cry. It's unbelievable how amazing this game is, and also how underplayed it is. I've heard people say that it differs too much from it's predecessor to be an official sequel. Although it's made on a different engine and has a surplus of extras not featured in Far Cry, the basic elements are still the same: shoot mercs in a sandbox world set in an exotic locale.\n\nIf you never played Far Cry 1 and if you were to ask me I would say skip it entirely and get Far Cry 2. It has everything that most people would want in a game, with only minor annoyances. It's crazy how much detail is here: driveable vehicles, mounted guns, fixable cars, unlockable safe houses, weapon upgrades, uncontrollable wild fires, exciting action, riveting music, helpful allies, challenging AI, beautiful scenery, and to top it all off you have a bad case of malaria!

(with anonymous murder contracts, two warrying factions that both are your contractors as well as enemies, ...)

reviewText: ONE OF THE BEST FAR CRY'S TO DATE AND THE BEGINNING OF THE OPEN-WORLD FANTASY THAT IS  THE FAR CRY SERIES.  Not too heavy on story more for the explorer, but not too much depth where you lose yourself in the side-elements of the game,  you get back on track pretty quickly and the missions are challenging but dying in firefights is pretty lame, until you gain a few comrades' who pick you up instead of having to re-do your assault missions.  This one doesn't take much from the first Far Cry except the high expectations in graphics and gunplay is more refined in this one.  The Feature of guns wearing after a bit really adds nothing to the game...cept tragedy in the middle of a fight.  There really isn't anything groundbreaking or gamebreaking in this one, a light frills ride through the Exotic African flatlands and forests' and the desterts...One of the best game in the series, has the longest play value, but yet is nothing that you haven't seen before in an open world.  I Had fun with this one.

reviewText:
Finally got around to playing this game. The only reason i never finished it before is because I was annoyed with the malaria aspect but it turns out only to be a minor annoyance in the game. I finished Far Cry 3 before finishing Far Cry 2, although I started playing it years ago. I always knew I would come back to it and I am glad I finally did. I won't do any comparison to the original FarCry because that is entirely a different game, in my opinion.

I found FC3 far too easy, being able to track your opponents, even through trees and rocks nerfed the difficulty enough, and getting special superpowers as you level up only made it worse.

In FC2, you have malaria, which is like, the opposite of a superpower and became a hazard if you started having an attack" in the middle of battle. And also
date: you have weapon jams which happen randomly as your weapon wears down. A weapon jam might sound annoying but it is a little detail in the game that adds a little realism and extra challenge to the game which I can appreciate.\n\nYour "buddys" are randomly chosen from your character choices from the beginning of the game
recommended: each with their own look and dialog.  You also have the chance to get incapacitated instead of dying
hoursPlayed: getting revived by a buddy for a second chance to finish the fight. if you go down too soon after though

reviewText:
You are dropped in a war-torn african country, you have one mission. Kill the man that has been arming both sides.

The gameplay is simpley amazing. The gun-play is next level and the environment gives you a feeling that the country is in horrible conditions and help is a far cry away. The most complaints i hear about FC2 is the weapon jamming and outpost, but for me it makes it more real. The outposts makes you strategicaly move from point to point and the jamming can ruin a firefight for you. It all makes it more difficult to survive, and instead of holding your hand all the time the game lets you approch how you want to. There are a lot of unlockables, weapons and uppgrades to let you play how you want to. Either run-n-gun or ninja style, and it does this well. Lots of games offer this, But FC2 manages this in a terrific way. The only complain i have is that the missions are very similar, little variety. But the different playstyles is enough to keep things fresh.

All in all i would say this is one of the best games i have ever played. It is almost 8 years old, but is a though competitor for even the newest games.

Im giving this 8/10 bacon strips.

reviewText:
Rules of Far Cry 2:

1. You have quicksave. Use it.
2. Heal, heal, shoot, heal, kill, heal, quicksave, and carry on.
3. Keep distance between you and every living creature on the map.
4. Throw away your modified silenced shotgun and pick up that god damn rusty AK-47 and continue shooting.
5. Listen for footsteps.
6. If that Jeep doesn't have a mounted gun, then walk.
7. Reload, heal, shoot, run, jump, take pills, heal, run, shoot, reload, quicksave.
8. Turn around. Shoot.
9. Headshot everyone after you shoot them down.
10. Repair that car.
11. Make sure when you want to go steathy that your guns are silenced, it's night time, the moon is very dim or behind the clouds, you're not standing on leaves, you're wearing dark clothes, approach down-wind, and when using molotoves, make sure the temperature is reasonably high on a windy day. And then heal.
12. Pick up that diamond and buy some more bloody guns.

This game isn't enjoyable in the least. 9.5/9.5, would git rekt again.

But seriously, behind all the chaos and complete annoyance of just about every aspect in the game, this ended up incredibly dark and quite powerful. I never quite found this enjoyable to start off with, but it is not the average FPS with normal FPS concepts. I'm currently playing Far Cry 4 and will continue to for probably a while, but I cant help but come back to this gritty and unique shooter. I never quite looked at this the same again after learning of it's incredibly dark and corrupt meaning. The monster that develops from within you over time. The horrific nature of man.

reviewText: Far Cry 2 is the most epic Far Cry game I have ever played the story for this game is just amazing it really keeps you hooked in the open world just blew me away there is so many things you can do after you have finished the game and really we don't get much FPS open world games and I would say Far Cry is probably one of the best FPS open world games out there. This really is a huge improvement over the first Far Cry being the first FC game to have openworld it really has developed a lot of new features that the first Far Cry didn't have. FC2's multiplayer you can invite your friends to join you but watch your back as you never know who your true friends are and who might betray you! All the single player technical features are also present in multiplayer mode. In Far Cry 2 you have a chance to explore a war torn African state and you are forced to make deals with corrupt warlords on both sides of the conflict this game's story really keeps people entertained and makes them not want to stop playing it is just an amazing story. They have changed the gameplay features of Far Cry 2 so unlike the first FC game there will be a lot of things that are different about the game and with the Fortune's pack DLC you can get access to new vehicles and weapons that are not in the game unless you bought the Far Cry 2 Fortune's Edition. Overall I give this game a 10/10 it is just a fantastic game to have in your collection and I think this game is definitely worth the money. So I suggest you go and get this game bros I am sure it will not disappoint you in anyway at all!.

reviewText:
After having not finished the game after a year and a half I decided to pick it back up and finish it.

POSITIVES
-The ability to upgrade your weapons at gunshops, it was fun expanding my artillary and improving it.
-The choas, blew up one explosie barrel and the entire camp ends up blowing up really fun and cool.
-There are some memorable missions/events that can occur.
-The music.
-The weapon varity.
-The knife execution is pretty cool, when you down an enemy and go over to him with the knife you do a 'you shall not pass' execution style to him, pretty cool
-Varity of vehicles.
-It's a big open world.
-The Atmosphere
-The Jackal
-The collectable tapes, very interesting some of the things said and can learn more about what's going on. (17 total)
-The ending.

NEGATIVES
-Buddy missions are not really useful they are more tedious than fun. Maybe if they were able to make buddies set up and ambush and you lead them to an area, but was more like kill this one guy so another guy stays in this encampment so you can kill him there, but it would've been easier to do it the normal way.
-Underground missions, only time I did them was when I needed pills and even considered to not even get the pills despite it was something I needed.
-Drving, starts off alright then just gets really boring, and annoying.
-Stealth, stealth is very difficult to actually do in the game, damn near impossible actually. Kill a guy inside a house his buddy saw you through the building.
-Lack of ways to complete a mission, don't get me wrong blowing ♥♥♥♥ up is fun, but I would sometimes like to have a different approach to things like snipe them from a mountain completely invisble from them, there were only a handful of times in which I was able to do this.
-The missions, most of them are go here kill/destroy this come back and repeat, pretty much the entire game, would've like to see more varity, pretty linear.
-Dialogue, the dialogue was pretty bad, felt like I was listening to them talk on x2 speed, and sometimes it would glitch out saying get in here, but you would already be there/say nothing or when they would call on the phone and there's nothing.
-Collecting diamonds is useless, you make more than enough from the main missions and then some.
-The AI they could drive past you and then they would somehow see you and turn around as if they had eyes in the back of their heads.
-Decisions in the game didn't matter, same result.
-Guard posts, you could clear a post and go down the road and back all the enemies would've spawned back, very annoying wished they would've had a timer as to when they would respawn.

After almost 2 years I finally got back to it and beat it, the ending was satisfying-to me at least-but a good chunck of the game felt like a chore to do, that's why I left it unbeaten originally. So if you were thinking about buying it and can look past the negatives go for it, it has its moments.

One of my funnier moments:
Shot a guy down, but was still alive and was trying to get back up, shot a propane tank, as was it was spinning around and flayling around it hit him right in the head and his body just flopped down, was pretty funny to see it happen.

reviewText:
AUDIO:
The voice acting in this game is iffy. The Jackal probably has the best voice actor in the game because he actually sounds interesting to listen to. Everyone else sounds bored out of their mind to be talking and they are speeding through their dialogue at maximum speed. The soundtrack is mostly just bongos and drums and the like, mostly for menus and fighting and stuff. Not bad.

VISUALS:
This game hits the extremes of good and bad graphics sometimes. For example, the graphics look freaking wicked when the sun rises or is in the sky. It's a beautiful sun, one of the best I've seen and it makes everything look spectacular. In contrast, the game is very brown and dark green without the sun rays. It can get pretty dull to look at sometimes, but maybe that's what they were going for.

PLAYABILITY:
Since the game is open world, it gives you freedom to tackle your objectives how you want. It also gives you more than one way to carry out your objective. The guns are all pretty nice and all of them work well, which lets you develop a favorite. The malaria isn't really a problem. I don't care what everyone else says, I never once had a problem with malaria. It gets repetitive having to travel sometimes though, and hunting for diamonds can get super boring, especially considering that they are currency in this game and you kind of need them.

DELIVERY:
My playtime was the amount of time needed to 100% this game. That being said, it's large. However, 100%'ing this is very dull. The missions are mostly the same thing over and over; assassinate a target, collect a briefcase, etc. The strongest point of this game would be the buddies. I found myself growing attached to the buddies I got and it made the game much more enjoyable.

SUMMARY:
Don't spend all your time collecting those damn diamonds unless you REALLY want to 100% this. Take the main missions, the buddy missions, and carry out your goals however you want. Make your own choices and don't think too much. It's not a bad game by any means.

reviewText: There are three kinds of enemies that can kill you in this game: malaria (doesn't really kill you, but will knock you out cold if a symptom attack catches you without the much needed pills), blood-thirsty mercenaries just like yourself (who duke it out supporting dubious causes for a hefty payment in blood diamonds), and the CoD-ey, impatient, quicktime-event-trained, short-attention-span mentality you WILL have when you first boot up Far Cry 2. All the past years, games in the likes of Call of Duty, Medal of Honor et al. have all created a FPS playerbase with a tremendously short focus of attention, a shocking lack of thinking and planning tactics, and a complete disregard of taking your mind off the shootybanging going on in the foreground, in order to soak in the atmosphere in the background. Far Cry 2 is, apart from a solid shooter, a magnificent atmospheric game, full of engrossing ambience and breathtaking vistas that will provide with a cheap vacation alternative to sub-Saharan Africa, albeit in a much more hostile environment than you would ever wish for. The nature that surrounds you can be both an ally and an enemy if you don't treat it properly, as a vantage point you used meticulously to pick off guards in a distant outpost can become a death trap at any moment, should a raging wildfire cut off any escape routes. Propagating bushfire mechanics can be harnessed to cause chaos and mayhem to enemy positions, but can also uncontrollably harm your character as well. Getting from point A to point B in this game can seem tedious at first, as you will have to walk or drive to wherever you need to be, but as you get more and more used to the feel of the adventure, you will discover alternate routes, shortcuts and safe zones to better facilitate your travelling needs.\nDon't expect fauna to be a threat, or to have any intelligence. Grazing herbivores are all you are ever going to see, and zebras tend to one-bump-one-kill themselves on your car, even if you are fully stopped. A full time-of-day cycle and dynamic weather effects will paint a much more convincing picture of your surroundings as you comb through the map length- and widthwise.\nTL;DR- An incredible experience worth the price of admission, it is a must that you should not overlook, especially since it goes dirt-cheap on sales more often than you would change underwear.

reviewText:
Where to start with this game, it's definitely a step up from far cry 1 and I would put it quite close to or slightly better than far cry 3.

First I would like to add that it's a cool feature having guns rust and jam after a while. The terrain is very accurate to what Africa is, with both desert and jungle filling the maps. Very good graphics. It's interesting how you can choose your character with the only affect is that you don't appear as an npc in the game.

One of the problems I had with the game is that the story stretches out too long so I end up forgeting what im supposed to be doing in the first place. Enemies can also appear out off nowhere and kill you, sending you back to the last save (which happens alot when your on the hardest difficulty). I'm also a bit disappointed that none of the animals tried to kill you, we're in Africa aren't we?

The main problems with the game is the fast travel system because the only fast travel you have is the five bus stops in each of the corners and centre. The more you quick save the harder it is to load the game manually. (Unless you delete them which I forgot to do). The AI is sometimes dumb and occasional fires through walls.

I loved this game, but it is not for the inpatient. 8/10

reviewText: UbiSoft knows how to make games. The Far Cry series is no exception; in fact, it's probably the best series they've made so far. Far Cry one was good, for its time, but I didn't play it until recently. Didn't quite finish it, because the ending boss fight was a little too difficult. FC3 was the first I played of the series, and it was outstandingly fun. Yeah, it was a little too action-y, but man, did it have a good story and addicting gameplay.\n\nThen came FC2. WOW! Can't say enough about how good this game is. Love the Africa setting, love the environment you have to survive in, love the weapons, love the challenges, love the gameplay, and that desperate feeling that you're alone in a foreign country and you're trying to survive, and just barely doing it. My Top 5 favorites of all time keeps changing, and this one just jumped in there with the Batman Arkham games, Alan Wake, and the Metros to take its place among the greatest of all time. And I consider FC3 to be right in there too, along with Blood Dragon, as kissin' cousins. ;-)

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 heavily expands the appealing, basic formula established in Far Cry 1. I would call it the first modern Far Cry game since most of the hallmark Far Cry features come into their own in this title. The core of a Far Cry/Crysis game is fast paced, streamlined, semi-realistic, immersive first person military shooter in large open environments where the player is free to explore multiple approaches (stealth, close range assault, sniping, explosives, vehicles, turrets, or any combination thereof) to overcoming enemies.

Far Cry 2 also introduces a large open-world, non-linear mission system with multiple factions, weapon and equipment unlocks, safe houses and buddy companion-system. The central african environments are breathtaking and the game takes great pains to immerse the player in the environment. The HUD is incredibly minimal with most actions and situations being context sensitive and told through actual interaction with the environment. For example, rather than healing being simply invisible (the health bar just refills), you'll see your character inject a syrette in his/her forearm, reset a broken limb, or pull a bullet from a gaping wound in their leg. The map just doesn't appear on the HUD, you actually pull a physical map and GPS out. When your character suffers the affects of malaria, you're vision will blur and turn green and you'll have to pull out a pill bottle and swallow a pill to counter-act the effects. All these things effectively serve to immerse the player in the world, but don't inhibit gameplay. The enemy AI is also very sophisticated and will communicate with one another, actively hunt for you and attempt to surround you (or where they think you are), or even get scared and take cover or run. My primary grievance is that random encounters when traveling can be a bit to frequent and bypassing frequent road blocks and guard posts can get to be a grinding chore in traveling around the map.

The mission system that unveils the story is fun and engrossing. The story is not just handed to you, but the player will have to really pay attention if they want to figure out what is really going on. The interplay of the factions, the player, and their buddies is fascinating and keeps the game fresh from start to finish. The side missions do get a bit redundant though, which include destroy arm shipments, and assassinations. Luckily, the core Far Cry gun play is solid and doesn't get old quickly. It is fun when a situation goes from you getting a jump on a bunch of enemies to reinforcements showing up and surrounding you as you run short on ammo and having to fight for your life to break the encirclement and make a run for it. Which brings me to the buddy system which is rich and unrivaled in any FPS/RPG that I have seen. The system is rather organic and you really seem to build a relationship and history with your buddies who are fellow mercenaries try to profit in this little civil war.

All in all, there are few games I can safely recommend as must plays for anyone, but this is definitely one of them.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2: Buy it!
I am less than 10 h/ into the game, but I can say that it is worth however much money you get it for. The AI for the enemy's can be a little shaky, but for the most part you can actually use their purposly implemented features to your advantage. Scenerio example:

You spot an enemy in the distance, in a base camp. Your mission objective is far away, yet you can't resist the urge to make your own fun in this barren wastland. You get a little closer, while still remaining in the bushes and shrubs, and you finaly get close enough to where you think you can make an accurate shot. You crouch down, take aim and fire at their shoulder. You hit, and the rest of the enemies remain clueless as to who fired the shot. They rush over to the wounded souldier, and as they get there you make a dash to get with close range, and take out 3 enemy's with your shotgun remaining unharmed and get behind cover before any other enemy's can get a shot off on you. 3 down, 2 more to get an easy advantage on using the same method with a little more run and gun.

The enemy's caring" features as I would like to call them the feature I made a scenario about above. If you wound a souldier

Still, Far Cry 2 is great for some freelance warfare especially given its detailed open-world environment.

reviewText: It seems like the Far Cry series gets better and better with each entry. I got to play Far Cry 2 again with family sharing and It just reminds me how far Far Cry has come since the first entry into the series. Far Cry 2 hold true to this pattern being a good stepping stone for Far Cry fans and newcomers like to experience all Far Cry has to offer. No matter what far cry you like most be it, Far Cry, Instincts, Evolution, Predator, Vengeance. Paradise lost, 2, 3, or Blood Dragon you have to admit Far Cry 2 is a decent entry into the series. Let us hope that Far Cry 4 will continue the trend of improvement and give us much joy with the next installment.         1/13/14

reviewText: If you look at my profile, you can see that I've spent the majority of my time playing this. It is the perfect game for when you want to have fun, but at a bit more relaxed pace than defeating a boss in another game. It is great fun to burn and blow stuff up and the story is pretty good also. At first, it is easy to get your butt kicked, but once you get some decent weapons it is fairly easy. I also LOVE the beautiful views and it's a way to get a dose of sun on a rainy day. The only real negative is the lack of wild animals like tigers, etc. but they fixed that in Far Cry 3. I still prefer this one though. Tip: try to grab a jeep with a grenade launcher because once you have that, you are almost immortal. The big assault truck is very effective also. And make use of the open space with a sniper rifle. I also found the dart gun to be very useful because you can kill like four guys before assaulting a checkpoint, greatly increasing your odds. The first one goes down and it lures other guards over. Muahaha!

reviewText:
I played this game when it came out and I must say that although I was very impressed with the game at first, it soon became boring and repetitive.The mission structure is very similar-basically go and blow something up or free somebody etc.Characters are shallow and not interesting.The world seems kind of empty with nothing much to do than destroying camps and dealing with very annoying armored jeeps that follow you when you pass by.

Now 5 years later I bought a new powerful graphic card,found some great mods and decided to give it another go.
I must say that I'm very pleased with the game.What this game gives you is very unique experience and that is enough to cover all it's flaws.This game made me realise what I've long forgotten.It's that not everything has to be action packed,flashy story,indepth customization of everything,points,cover system....It's just simple and beautiful.It makes you appreciate the time spent just roaming the wilderness with nothing on your screen to destract you from beautiful world around you.Total immersion.We need to stop with consuming games like an always hungry fat kid and appreciate the atmosphere and experience.

You will often feel alone and kind of lost in this great world,which coupled with an amazing weather system,beautiful graphics and fitting background music makes the experience very unique.Sometimes it feels like a dream to me.Like you never really know what is going on but you just exist,just to watch that beautiful sunset.It gives you time for thinking between action parts.

And action is great and the whole weapon system is designed very well.From buying,upgrading to the shooting mechanics and wearing out including great jamming system and animations.The arsenal is also pretty big with plenty to choose from.

The other thing that shines is AI.Although they can act like idiots at times mostly they are smart and they will very often surprise you and flank you.They will also detect you quickly even if you just peak out behind cover to take a quick look.Just like IRL,they are not blind like in other games (Hitman:Absolution for eg) and there is no detection meter".If they see you
date: they see you.Your best bet for sneaking is to attack by night wearing stealth suit and even then it will not be easy
recommended: because if you are too close they will hear louder sounds such as bumping in objects or reloading etc. and come to investigate.GREAT STEALTH GAME right there.Using quick save and quick load is much recommended.\n\nAs I don't want to write a book here I will conclude and tell you to try it if you are looking for a trully open world game with a great action
hoursPlayed: juicy explosions and shooting
voteText: GREAT STEALTH possibilities and an amazing atmosphere.You will love Africa after this
helpfulPercent: or hate it.Whatever.What you will not find is many RPG elements and a great story.But lack of those gives the game its charm and keeps the focus on other things.\n\nWHAT I HIGHLY RECOMMEND is getting this mods from moddb:sproyds_FC2_SweetFX_config and VERY important DylansFC2Mod1.4 as it will basically fix the game.Just check it out even if you don't like mods(like me)Play on highest difficulty and enjoy!"

reviewText:
Before reviewing this amazing game, I decided to play it for quite a while. As of the time I am writing this, I have two hours. Most of my reviews haven't been helpful, and I really want this one to help people geniunely decide if this is a game they want to invest in or not. Let's start off with the basics.
Intro So you start up the game, and click new game. There are 9 characters to choose from, each from different nationalities with different voices, buddies (which I will go into detail of later), and ages. All the characters are male, though.
Difficulty Levels There are 4 difficulty levels. Easy, Normal, Hard, And Infamous.

On to the next thing..

Unscripted Player-Driven Events! Unfortunately for modern gaming, this is something most new games lack. Far Cry 2 is great for this kind of thing.

Something I Found on IGN

Marty dragged me out of the line of fire and into the bushes when a random group of guys jumped me on the road. Stupid. You never take the road. A gunner on the back of a truck mowed me down while I fell into my own misplaced Molotov flames. Marty hands me a pistol and opens fire. I find a couple grenades, knock the truck around, and finish the job. When it’s all done, I hear Marty screaming for help. I can’t see him.

By the time I find his blue smoke streaming out of the woods, he’s grunting incoherently. I kneel down, jab a regenerative needle into his stomach, and wait for him to head home. He doesn’t get up. He’s still wounded, so I put another needle in him. Nothing, but he slows down, and his eyes roll upward. One more needle. Marty’s head hits the ground, and he stops squirming.

I overdosed my best friend.

Something that happened to me in game (Not IGN)

When I was playing Far Cry 2, I was crouched behind a car. I fired off a few shots at a guy, and he was killed. I realised something; I was wounded! As my health was rapidly pouring away, I quickly healed myself, but while I was doing that, my car exploded and fell on me. Instant death.



On to gameplay and stuff!

Gameplay
The gameplay is quite hard. If you are a newcomer and download the RealMode mod and play on Infamous difficulty for the first run of the game? You will die. A lot. You might die even without the mod. This game is BLOODY HARD AS ****.  Pick up a enemy weapon? Well prepare for it to be unreliable as hell. Snipers explode in your arms without any notice, guns jam, deal less damage...
Recoil is a whole different thing. With weapons you purchase at the gun shops, they will do more damage, accuracy, etc. They also have a permanent good" condition. However
date: firearms you "borrow" from your dead enemies
recommended: are quite the opposite; With inferior range
hoursPlayed: accuracy
voteText:
and damage.

Wrap Up & Conclusion
This game has its pros and cons..

PROS
- Amazing openworld experience
- Great fun
- Is pretty old and still looks amazing
- Supports mods
- Player driven events
CONS
- wtf is a con there is none buy this game

All in all... BUY THIS DAMN GAME RIGHT NOW"

reviewText: I have played all of these games now and FC2 remains my favorite...  FC2 is set in the African bush with a SILENT protagonist of your choosing, which is  far better than listening to Jason Brody (FC3) cry about everyone dying.  The voice acting isn't the best but the game is not saturated with side missions, hunts, and racing sequences. There is no leveling up nor a mini map. You only collect diamonds and spend it on more ways to eviscerate your enemies. The game feels more tactical compared to it's bretheren and less story driven, the missions are host to some awesome and unforgettable gun play, Far Cry done right.

reviewText:
Worth playing for the first 10 hours or so, it's really great fun during that initial period.

The gunplay is great and the touches of realism are well executed for the most part, which combined with the well designed gameworld, all leads to a very nice sense of immersion.

Unfortunately after a while the game becomes extremely repetitive with pretty much only three types of missions, two of them being identical each time around (the gunshop and assassination ones), whereas the main story missions are also all very similar.

Some questionable design choices also really get in the way of allowing you to have fun, making the need to travel around during missions an absolute exercise in frustration and tedium.

The way everyone will shoot you on sight no matter what gets really ridiculous eventually, since you don't even need to be aggressive towards someone randomly driving around in order for them to start relentlessly giving you chase as if their life depended on it.

The way enemies respawn instantly after the area where you fought them is out of your line of sight (why not make them respawn until a full day has passed by?) practially makes clearing up the camps pointless. The few fast travel locations don't really help much in avoiding excessive driving around. Had there been more fast travel locations and the uber aggressive enemies were toned down a bit (or if they at least didn't respawn so quickly), I would've been more willing to put up with the repetitive missions, since repetitve as they were, they were still fun to play.

I can't say much about the story itself since I didn't see it through to the end, but it was serviceable at best during my time playing. Not sure if it gets more interesting eventually, but if it does it sure takes a while to get going.

Ultimately I decided to call it quits on the main story and side missions and decided to just muck around freely. It was a more liberating and fun experience, though the fun didn't last long since due to story reasons (the main character has malaria) you can't go around without checking your health periodically, which requires doing more repetitive missions and I couldn't be bothered with that anymore.

Nevertheless, as I said at first, for the first 10 hours or so the game is awesome and I don't regret buying it. If you have more patience to deal with repetitive gameplay and can tolerate some of the more annoying design quriks, you'll certainly have fun with this game.

reviewText: Still good, still pretty. I love Far Cry 3, probably my favourite shooter ever. Even so, I find that in some aspects FC 2 is better. For example, you have to view the map in real time, there's no pause menu map. I love this, very immersive. Also, vehicles and enemies don't show in any mini maps, which again helps. Basically, I like how this game makes you work for everything, and nothing is given free. One of the things I like most, though, is that days and nights are long. A day in the game takes 8 real world hours, which is better than in almost any game I know. One of my major gripes about FC3 was the ridiculously short nights.\n\nFC 2 has it's problems (instantly respawning outposts for one), but it's still an excellent game. Well worth the 2€ I paid for it. :)

reviewText:
Great FPS action set in Africa.

The environment is beautiful and deadly especially during firefights in the thick jungle setting where it is really difficult to track or spot the enemy.

Several aspects that set this game apart from others FPS are that the gun jams during firefights and sometimes breaks apart causing you to think fast and switch to secondary weapons. really adds a depth of realism to the game that most other FPS games lack. Wish the developers had added this for the 3rd installment which is one of my all time favorite games.

reviewText: Personally, this is one of my favorite games in the Far Cry series. The game has a gritty yet beautiful enviroment, taking place in what seems like a fictional central African nation. As for gameplay, the shooting mechanics are pretty solid, although controls at some points might be a bit clunky. The story is pretty straight forward, yet manages to be entertaining. Overall, I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a good open world first person shooter!

reviewText: Fairly good game, but IMO it is a bit over rated at least as a one player game.  The game got a bit monotonous driving and running to different spots far away on the map but there is fast travel and once you learn your way around it gets less burdonsome. The graphics and sound are very good considering when the game came out. The voice acting is rather poor, but if you dont care much for the 1 player then that doesnt matter. The AI in the game is really good and the enemies are quite smart for the most part. The AI is much better than a lot of games I have played even newer games. The story behind the game is just ok and the ending is pretty good and a surprise happens. I would give the game a 7/10.

reviewText: I've played alot of FPS games over the years, but I've poured more hours into this one than any other.  Creating your own maps and sharing them is much better and easy to share than what Far Cry 3 offered.  The multiplayer in this game seems to be dead, which is a shame because although the single player mode has one of the best FPS campagins I ever played (beats FC3 again for me), it's greatest feature was sharing and playing player made maps.  Played for years on the PS3 and only just bought it again on Steam to try and complete the single player again but with better graphics on my new PC.  If anyone knows a way to get the full multiplayer feature back with popular private server, let me know, that would be awesome.

reviewText:
It is hard to recommend this game because of how much of a pain it is, but it is also hard not to because of how fun it is.
Malaria aspect is interesting, along with the guns jamming here and there. The game is quite empty, you have to drive for quite a while to get somewhere, and if you die, start all the way back. You have to save often in this game if you want to get anywhere. Respawning enemies can be frustrating, but its not too bad. Overall, I think that this is a great, unpolished game.
Also, one of my Top 10 games of all time.
Another side note, I got this game from selling steam trading cards during a summer sale. Bought the game without any idea of what I was getting into.

reviewText:
The game is so dam long! Have not finished it yet!

EDIT: I still haven't finished it yet; however, this game is one of the most memorable FPS games I've owned in years. One of the first FPS games to introduced an in-game non-immersion breaking UI in which keeping count of ammunition, health conditions, GPS location, and danger was completely in the hands of the player's avatar. The storyline is superb, capturing the tension of a nation torn by Civil War and ruled by ruthless warlords, and yet still managing to thrust you into a position in which ambivalence is impossible.

Only downside to this game is the enormity of it all, the game was honestly too big for comfort considering it was single-player and at the time, AI mechanics where still lacking in many respects when compared to today's games. Great game still, probably best appreciated by fans/students of the industry.

reviewText:
I hope you like weapon jams, respawning enemies, ill-timed bouts of malaria and a world painted brown.

All of that aside, this is pretty fun.  Chasing down diamonds and shooting up shanty towns can get a little repetitive, but there's enough variation in weapons, unique vehicles and interesting locations to keep you playing through the dull story.

If you get it as cheap as I did, you won't be complaining.

reviewText: Have you ever thought about what canada would be like without gun control? Now you don't have to! Far cry 2 is the worlds most realistic post Stephan Harper administration simulator, featureing black people and sand. Lots and lots of sand. Sand. MMMmmmm delicious saaaand. There are black people. They seem to beleve you are the member of the kkk and therefore shoot on sight and attempt to run you over with dune buggies. They are also made of kevlar and tote guns that are held togeather with chewing gum and paper clips. Luckily for you your kkk connections allow you to obtain infinite amounts of firearms in perfect condition from a friendly black guy in a gas station. Im not sure why the other black guys just dont buy from him. Maybe its because he is selling to the kkk. I digress, another RESOLUTIONARY feature of this game is fire. Yeop thats right! FIRE. Never before in a game have we seen fire before.\n3/10 Would bang with caution.

reviewText:
Awesome game, takes some getting used to the non-hand-holding type of gameplay though. Especially if you've grown accustomed to games guiding you through linear experiences.

Pros
-Sweet graphics, even by modern standards
-Some of the coolest gun-play I've ever seen (Weapon durability, jamming, or just flat out falling apart mid-combat)
-Immersive enviroment & game mechanics (I.E. Malaria attacks during a heated gunfight
-Leaves you to your own devices in terms of progression

Cons
-Story is a little shallow IMHO
-NPC Dialogue's are a little meh, especially those of your 'buddies'
-Some game 'bugs', such respawning checkpoints with the enemies you took down no more than 60 seconds ago.

Summarized: Great game, if you want to experience a malaria driven mercantile Africa packed into an awesome shooter, mechanic-wise. Ofcourse there's some minor problems with the game, but nothing too major or immersion breaking in my experience.

reviewText: No game has ever ended for me quite the same way Far Cry 2 did. That is, I didn't see it through to the end at all, at least the indended end. What happened instead is that about halfway through, I accidentaly shot my sister-in-arms while she was bleeding into the dusty sub-Saharan soil, begging me for help. You see, when one of your buddies" goes down in a firefight
date: a plume of blue smoke will direct you to their location. You then have the option to either heal them with a magic syrette
recommended: leave them to their fate or
hoursPlayed: it turns out
voteText: blow their brains out right there and then. That latter option is denoted with the prompt "Press 2 for handgun". Clear enough
helpfulPercent: you'd think. Except I had been under the impression that "handgun" in this context would mean hauling the buddy to their feet and dragging them to safety
votesHelpful: while fending off remaining assailants with a sidearm in your free hand. Because that is precisely what the buddies themselves will do for you when you've eaten one too many helpings of cold lead. So when instead of lending a helping hand
votesTotal: I watched myself put a gun to my friend's head and pull the trigger
votesFunny: I was left agape. Literally agape. As in
commentsCount: my mouth was hanging open and I was staring at the screen
column16: for a good minute or so. After that
column17: I drove around aimlessly for an hour or so
column18: picking random fights
column19: absent-mindedly going through the motions to complete a side mission. After that
column20: I hopped onto a boat
column21: drove out to a rocky island in the middle of a lake
column22: climbed to the highest point I could reach
column23: dropped an IED at my own feet and blew myself to hell
column24: And thus ended the short and miserable career of Andre the Haitian. Definitely recommended."

reviewText:
Quick Review;
Graphics - 4/5 Decent for their time, but as we're developing, we're leaving it behind. However, still very playable for an average gamer.
Controls - 4/5 Very General, there's nothing hard with the controls but nothing new really, your average shooter/rpg controls.
Storyline - 2/5 I hated it. I think they did an original storyline, decided that a game this size needed a longer storyline and so did a lot of copy and pasting.
AI - 2/5 Poor. Once you wipe out a outpost/road checkpoint, apparently, all the guys twin brothers arrive 5 seconds later and have set up defensive positions. Fed up of having to deal with 20 guys every 100m down a road.

Good Point - If you're looking for a game which is easy to get into, plenty of fun weapons where you can burn and shoot some general guys, then you're looking at the right game.

Bad Point - If you're looking for something where you call fall in love with the characters and the gameplay. I think there are better shooters and better RPGs.

Recommended.

reviewText: Sent on a mission to find and kill a man, you play as a mercanary of your choice, who by chance just happens to get Malaria while arriving in Africa. After your target looks through your belongings and gives you a machete after some kinky time on the bed, he leaves and tells you to get a job. Since you're a loser that does what anyone tells you for raw diamonds, you  proceede to help two factions fighting eachother, and kill numerous African people made out of kevlar(pick a white character for extreme butthurt). You collect weapons at an alarming rate while commiting assassinations, and do not once question if you have a problem. Every know and then you look for a trusty doctor" who you save in trade for a unlabled bottle of "malaria medication(maybe this is all a big drug trip). Also people leave diamonds with trackers all over Africa(who knew!). Oh and people play multiplayer.\n\nMuch more beleivable than a rich kid part boy turned into a killer overnight(see sequel)."

reviewText:
It is hard to recommend this game because of how much of a pain it is, but it is also hard not to because of how fun it is.
Malaria aspect is interesting, along with the guns jamming here and there. The game is quite empty, you have to drive for quite a while to get somewhere, and if you die, start all the way back. You have to save often in this game if you want to get anywhere. Respawning enemies can be frustrating, but its not too bad. Overall, I think that this is a great, unpolished game.

reviewText:
I've gone back-and-forth about whether to give this game a thumbs-up or thumbs-down.  Ultimately, I decided to give it a thumbs-up because I *did* enjoy playing it.  However, in my opinion this is a game with some serious flaws.  I picked this up as part of the Far Cry franchise pack, so I don't regret buying it.

POSITIVES:

- It's a hardcore open-world sandbox FPS.  If you're into that, you will almost certainly enjoy much of the game.  Hardcore" here refers to variety of things.  For example
date: there is very limited fast-travel.  Expect to spend a lot of your time driving back and forth between the same places.  This game doesn't hold your hand or give a ♥♥♥♥ about you and your time.\n\n- Continuing the hardcore theme
recommended: you don't carry much ammo and your guns often jam
hoursPlayed: especially when you don't routinely replace them with brand new ones.  I enjoyed this part
voteText:
but some might see it as a nuisance.

- There is a very good variety of guns.

- The graphics hold up quite well.

NEGATIVES:

- RESPAWNING ENEMIES.  This is by far the worst
helpfulPercent: IMHO.  When you clear an area of enemies
votesHelpful: they will respawn as soon as the area is unloaded.  This creates some really awkward situations where your missions expect you to drive back-and-forth over the same area repeatedly
votesTotal: and you have to re-clear it (or painstakingly avoid it) each time.  It's entertaining for the first few times
votesFunny: but it gets really repetitive.  Early on
commentsCount: I died to these guys a lot.  Later
column16: I was just trying to avoid boredom by finding creative ways to kill them.  I don't *mind* enemies respawning
column17: but these ones are way too fast.\n\n- The AI is inconsistent.  Sometimes they spot you when you're hiding in the brush.  Other times
column18: they miss you when you are in the open right in front of them.  I can partially forgive this
column19: since it is an older game.\n\n- Gun damage is very inconsistent.  Five pistol shots to a bare chest at point-blank won't kill.  But a sniper rifle is always a one-shot kill.  I would be more forgiving of this from a normal FPS
column20: but FC2 is obviously a game that takes itself seriously and I feel like this detracts from the "hardcore" feeling for me.\n\n- The two sides in the civil war are completely interchangeable.  This is at least partially intentional
column21: since the game is creating a bleak
column22: mercenary-driven civil war where everyone is bad.  However
column23: the player hardly ever sees the two factions fighting
column24: and both sides seem to always want to kill the main character on sight.  While it's partly justifiable
column25: it also seems a bit lazy to me.  I feel like the game loses it's appeal a lot faster because of this.\n\n- The main plot feels somewhat railroaded.  For example
column26: you *must* work for both sides of the ongoing civil war to advance the plot (i.e. one side just stops giving you missions and you need to start going to the other side).  The ending was completely railroaded
column27: as well.  Some have argued that this is because the player doesn't have complete control over the main character.  This is supported somewhat by the journal entries he writes during the game.  However
column28:
it strikes me as a bit lazy.


Bottom Line: My enjoyment of this game was like a bell curve.  Early on
column29: I was very frustrated by some of the questionable mechanics.  By the middle of the game
column30: I had adapted
column32: and was having a pretty good time.  But by the end of the game
column33: the repetitiveness and plot-railroading got to me and I just wanted it to end.  There's a really good game somewhere in there
column34: though.\n\nIf it sounds appealing to you
column35: get it while on sale or as part of the franchise pack.\n\n"

reviewText: This game was designed to be unforgiving and harsh, and that's just the way I like it. Malaria gives you a sense of mortality that a lot of games tend to shy away from, and weapon malfunction is a great way to force improvisation. Even the high rate of enemy respawn has appeal; it's taught me to plan every mission in advance, and enemies that keep coming are the only ones that force you to keep yourself on your toes at all times. The UFLL and APR can call in as many foreign mercenaries as they want to; I'll keep cutting them down.\n\nI honestly don't understand why some people complain about these things. Especially traveling. Patience is the key to playing this game, whether you're traveling, sneaking through a camp, or tracking a target.
