reviewText:
This rivals STALKER as my favorite game of all time. As far as immersion goes, FC2 is unsurpassed. The game feels exactly like my real life experience in overthrowing an unstable African nation. It's hard, especially on the higher difficulty levels. YOu have to think about how to approach each mission, which works well because you have a variety of options. While most of the missions can feel repetitive after a while, it's fine because the actual combat is intense. You can never let yourself be distracted or opting for the mindless approach, as each (infuriatingly respawning) checkpoint can kill you, no matter how many similar checkpoints you've cleared. Even the respawning checkpoints work out to a greater point, nothing you do is improving the country, no matter how many nameless enemies you kill. It's not perfect, as I mentioned many of the missions are repetitive, but the gameplay feels as intense and dark as the narrative, and every aspect of the game seems to blend together into a cohesive whole.

Gunplay is absolutely amazing, with each shot deadly for both you and the enemy. Flare guns in particular deserve a special mention, as the fire physics are devastating in this game. Apparently during early stages of testing, the fires would rage out of control, spreading across the entire map and killing every single character. The developers restricted fire to spread to a perfect circle, but to be completely honest I never noticed that as I usually used fire as a temporary distraction to flush enemies out of cover or to cover my escape.

It can be frustrating to escape enemies in vehicles, as they'll chase you to hell and beyond, but now I'm just nitpicking. Nothing in the game breaks the immersion or flow, the map is an item you can pull out and look at while driving, and the entirety of the game reinforces the brutality of the setting and the fact that you're not a golden hero, magically fixing everything for the natives. Even the ending goes for the same, I won't spoil it but suffice to say, The Jackal (FC2's antagonist) is probably my favorite character in video game history.

reviewText: Despite a staggering number of design missteps (respawning checkpoints, wonky weapon degradation system, non-immersive ecosystem as seen in the total removal of predatory animals, malaria, and a story that ends up being a cheap cop-out) and story-related bugs, FC2 remains a special chapter in this now burdening series. There's something...nomadic about how you play the game. It might not have the most stunning visuals or the most interesting locale, but it's the means in which you can dispose of your targets that make this a keeper. Had Ubisoft made the game more interesting, less frustrating, and even more immersive then I think it would have been a sheer blast to play. As for what we got, it's merely a means of blowing off steam on a world gone mad.

reviewText:
Why I personally feel Far Cry 2 is still the best in the series:

1st reason: No Facetious Antagonist.
What I mean is there is no over-the-top drama queen playing puppet master over an already lucid reality. (Really, the psycho-male antagonist is getting old)

2nd reason: Its Not Afflicted By Action Movie Animal Predators!
Basically, youll notice in fc3 and fc4 (the same game just reskinned) that the friendly npc's and otherwise are completely negated by poorly scripted animal interactions. A badger has the same effect on the environment as a mountain lion. Its silly, it feels lazy, and it doesnt instill any confidence in the civilian/paramilitary AI.

3rd reason: ITS NOT JUNGLE

4th reason: The poorly received weapon damage system. Im sorry but if youve asked for an open world first person shooter to provide you with a proper sense of realism you will invariably have weapon decay. (Thats a given) It also adds a very interesting dynamic to the world; you are always conscientious to your gear and effectiveness.

5th reason: Malaria; I know, its one of the most hated aspects of the game mechanic. It also makes the game more interesting because you really do reach a state of panic at times looking for your medication. You really do feel more a part of the world because you are consistently affected by it and in a way that you cant always control (just the same in reality.)

6th reason: Its not copy and paste like the latter titles. Its doesnt force you to unlock the map in the generic ubisoft way (Assassin's Creed) and finally........ NO UPLAY!!!!  OMG NO UPLAY!!!!!

So there ya go, if you can get over the ai (or man up and mod the ai a bit with the realism mod) and if you can look past the more repetitive missions (your an idiot if you think the other titles arent repetitive) then youve got an underrated gem on your hands.

Thanks for reading!
NO UPLAY WOOOOOOOOOOO!
Puma~

reviewText:
Ah...Africa. Beautiful vistas and magnificent sunsets. Jungle and desert mingling in a never-ending dance of death. The smell of burning huts and gunpowder. I'm home.

I'll take any mission. I choose no side. I have no moral compass. I never read the dossier and if the malaria wasn't constantly tapping on my shoulder like Death's cold finger I wouldn't lift one of mine to get any passports for anybody.

I don't care about illegal gun shipments and if weren't for the promise of more fancy tools of destruction, that arms dealer would be bankrupt within a week. But I likes my guns. Guns!

I also likes my diamonds. My motto. Diamond's are a merc's best friend." More! More! Diamonds and guns. Guns and diamonds. And explosions. The odd pill or two helps as well. They should rename this Diamonds and Pills and Guns. Oh my!

APR? UFLL? CIA? Mi6? KGB? PMRC? I don't care. I don't even care if I ever find the Jackal. God bless him I say. More guns. Keep em' coming.

My only regret? The incessant crisscrossing of that map. Stupid bus system. Cars and boats and buggy's. Jeeps as far as the eye can see. ATV's and dune bugs. Hell....hang-gliders on random hillsides and 5 Fracking bus stops in the whole territory?  Did the Ministry of Transport design the service by  throwing a sixer and it landed on 5? Where's the taxi service? I've seen one taxi the whole game so far and
hoursPlayed:
that trip sucked. No. I didn't tip.

Well .... 20 hours of gameplay and I just hit the halfway mark of my missions. Back at it. I got my eye on a flashy new flamethrower...ooooooh baby!

"Someday this war will end." - LtCol William "Bill" Kilgore"

reviewText:
Good Game!  I really enjoyed the open world, and it has some great rewards for exploring.  Combat is excellent, giving the player a wide range of choices in how to approach a fight.

With that said, I do have a few critiques of the game that I'd like to share:
1.  Reputation:  This feature did not seem to help the player in any way.  I thought, when I saw my reputation going up, it might have an effect like giving me some leverage with the various militant groups.  Perhaps if my reputation is high enough, I would not need o fight my way through every checkpoint on the road, but no.

2. Checkpoints: Throughout the maps, different militant groups have set up checkpoints which the player must either avoid or take on in combat in order to get where they are going.  I didn't mind it at first, but it became kind of tedious.  It would have made sense in the game to allow the player to pass at least some of these checkpoints unscathed, considering that you are working with those same groups on your quests.

3.  Limited ammo:  Some of the more powerful guns understandable had limits on how much ammo could be carried.  However, it seemed a bit too severe.  Six darts?  Really?

4. Strange weapons system:  Having a warehouse with unlimited weapons and ammo was an interesting approach.  However, it basically made the whole weapon condition feature pointless.  If you are going to add weapon condition, and have weapons break down on the player, then it would make more sense to have the player repair those weapons, rather than giving him access to unlimited quantities of weapons in perfect condition.  It's like they had an idea, then they just gave up on it.

To go a step further, let me explain.  I like the weapons in the game.  I like the weapons in a lot of games in fact, and I grow kind of attached to them.  If I find a cool gun, I want to keep it and take care of it, and make it my gun, right?  At first I liked the fact that a gun might stop working, and I might need to pick up another one, but once I found my warehouse full of unlimited guns ... it all seemed pointless.

5. No Mutant Monkeys:  C'mon.  Where the heck are the mutant monkeys?  For nearly all of this game I was anticipating the encounter with mutant monkeys.  When I discovered the second map area, I became convinced that I would discover the lair of the mutant monkeys.  However, the mutant monkeys never came.

Seriously, the more I think about it, the more I resent the failure of the developer to add a simple underground lab filled with mutant monkeys.  I mean, how hard can it be?  And who wouldn't want mutant monkeys in their game, am I right?  It's a win, win.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is in my opinion the best Far Cry game in the series, mainly due to it's realistic setting, story and location. Lots of realistic weapons, vehicles and environments made this a really immersive experience for me.
The game itself took me a while to get into as it can be initially a bit frustrating, but once you get used to the world and its mechanics it's one of the best sandbox games there is.
Lots of people complain about checkpoints and enemy respawn, but you can easily avoid these encounters if you stay off the roads. I always carry a Dragunov sniper rifle with me and that can take care of any enemy in one shot from a safe distance.
If you like more realistic take on shooters and sandbox games, I'd recommend this game for you!

reviewText: You can hate this game as much as you like. It isn't the best game ever made, it wasn't better than all the other games released in 2008, and it has more glitches and problems than one would care for. There are 100 idiosyncracies left out of this game that would have made so much better as a video game, and still not look that much different, but . . . this game is meant to be any of those things. It is meant to be a story, a captivating story where you think you are hunting evil and you think you are helping out, but all the while showing you that no matter what you do, you're still just as destructive and dangerous as the evil that surrounds you. This is one of my favorite games even to today. Play it, it will keep you engaged.

reviewText: Despite a staggering number of design missteps (respawning checkpoints, wonky weapon degradation system, non-immersive ecosystem as seen in the total removal of predatory animals, malaria, and a story that ends up being a cheap cop-out) and story-related bugs, FC2 remains a special chapter in this now burdening series. There's something...nomadic about how you play the game. It might not have the most stunning visuals or the most interesting locale, but it's the means in which you can dispose of your targets that make this a keeper. Had Ubisoft made the game more interesting, less frustrating, and even more immersive then I think it would have been a sheer blast to play. As for what we got, it's merely a means of blowing off steam on a world gone mad.

reviewText: This game was designed to be unforgiving and harsh, and that's just the way I like it. Malaria gives you a sense of mortality that a lot of games tend to shy away from, and weapon malfunction is a great way to force improvisation. Even the high rate of enemy respawn has appeal; it's taught me to plan every mission in advance, and enemies that keep coming are the only ones that force you to keep yourself on your toes at all times. The UFLL and APR can call in as many foreign mercenaries as they want to; I'll keep cutting them down.\n\nI honestly don't understand why some people complain about these things. Especially traveling. Patience is the key to playing this game, whether you're traveling, sneaking through a camp, or tracking a target.

reviewText:
First and only Far Cry game I've played so far. A lot of the gameplay and shooting reminds me of Crysis 1.

Pros:
The shooting feels natural and sounds nice.
Driving feels natural and there's lots of variation. Pretty realistic, if your engine gets shot and starts smoking you'll slow down a lot. Bullets can shoot holes in windshields, etc.
I personally haven't had any crashes or bugs so far.
The open world is large and isn't too cluttered or too sparse.


Cons:
Pathing is a bit clunky. Don't expect to squeeze between tight spaces in gunfights or bunny hop up cliffs like in Skyrim.
Punkbuster hung up while isntalling from Steam and would never finish. If you don't plan on playing online you can go to your steam install folder and find the install and delete it so it never installs.
Alt-Tabbing resizes both the game and other windows. When you go back in the game pressing Alt+Enter resizes it back to fullscreen without any other problems.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2, although it's not even really a sequel to Far Cry, is an amazing game. Why did they call it Far Cry 2? I don't know. The only similarities between the two titles involve the driving mechanics and the shooting mechanics. Otherwise, they have nothing in common.

However, in my opinion, Far Cry 2 is the better game. While Far Cry had a more involving story, Far Cry 2 had a more interesting setting. The open world, fictional, war torn, central African country that your mercenary character arrives in is immersive and glorious. From savanahs, to jungles, to deserts and sand dunes, to valleys, Ubisoft Montreal packed everything you might find in a central African country into this 16 square mile playground. The towns are small and sparse, but the wildlife you find in between will capture your bewilderment. This, simply put, is a fully realized environment. And it's absolutely stunning.

On the story side of things, the only thing I have to say about it is that it could have been more inspired. Basically, you choose a mercenary at the beginning of the game, and you play as that mercenary. The rest of the mercs on this list end up being your buddies". Anyway

reviewText:
This game is my favorite single-player first-person shooter of all time. I enjoyed Doom back in the 90s, but other than that i am not really a fan of the genre. I find the mechanics somewhat repetitive - you are forced to kill everything, everywhere, spraying bullets around like you're in some kind of direct-to-video action flick. Even acclaimed shooters like Half-Life and Bioshock come across as cartoonish and tedious to me. Counter-Strike changed everything. A game where you only get a rifle and a sidearm, where every shot matters, where a bullet to the head means instant death and spending the next few minutes learning from people far more skilled than you. After playing Counter-Strike, every first-person shooter felt like a mindless kill-fest where stealth or tactics did not matter. The good news is those things do matter in Far Cry 2.

You are still pretty much railroaded into killing everything that moves. It is an FPS, after all. But stealth always feels like a possibility. The tension before the killing ensues, the time you spend crouching motionless in elephant grass, is a highlight of the game.

The enemies in Far Cry 2 are some of the most human i have encountered. It's why killing them takes a toll - they are a lot like you. If you have been seen - if any of your enemies spot you - the whole base goes on alert. Forever. They will lay down suppressive fire in your last known position. They will wall-bang. They will establish search parties. They will freak out and start getting paranoid over the slightest noise. If you are seen - or heard - again, expect to die. One or two shots from an enemy rifle will wipe you out. But stay perfectly still, crouched in the undergrowth, and the enemy may creep past just a few meters away. And, as they widen their net, you may be able to slip through and circle round. Inevitably, ♥♥♥♥ will go south. You are spotted and clipped, then running through the jungle, sliding to obscure their line of sight, spinning round to lob a grenade or to spray and pray. Mostly, you will die. It is ♥♥♥♥ing brutal.

I know some reviewers have complained about the mechanics of this game. Respawning bases. Deteriorating weapons. Malaria. I will admit i played with Dylan's realism mod and never tried it any different, but in Dylan's mod it all makes sense. You are sick and scared and stumble into the jungle with a pea shooter. So you see an AK, grab it, but it jams in no seconds flat. You see an unguarded jeep, jump in, then get hit by an RPG half a click down the road. The game teaches you these hard lessons in the first half hour. How are you supposed to survive in Ubisoft's nightmare version of Africa? Don't pick up jury-rigged weapons. Don't jack jeeps. Wait till dusk, get your belly in the mud and proceed to your destination at a crawl. Avoid the roads, avoid the checkpoints, scout your targets and look for a headshot. Value reliability over firepower. Value cover over speed. Value your life.

The story is grim. You play an opportunistic soldier of fortune in the midst of a civil war. Almost everyone is evil and corrupt, and the vast majority attack you on sight. Even if you try to minimize casualties on an assassination or sabotage mission, something will invariably ♥♥♥♥ up and the bodycount will rise. Or your next mission will require you to clean out a whole area anyway. Every time you hear a squeak you expect a technical to pull up and unload 50 cal into your back. Every time the sun falls on a certain pattern of leaves your trigger finger will twitch. And gosh, those hanging vines really do look like bodies sometimes, don't they? I loved Spec Ops: The Line for its simulated PTSD effects, but those were mostly scripted. Far Cry 2 plays it totally straight and your brain still goes there. ♥♥♥♥ is ♥♥♥♥ed up, man.

So yeah. The game is punishing. It's bleak. You spend most of your time holding your breath and crouched in the dirt. Every now and then you are awed by a herd of zebra crossing the savannah at sunset, or the majesty of a tropical storm, or the slow rising moon. And then a bullet ricochets off a nearby cliff face and everything turns to ♥♥♥♥ again. A lot of games have made an impact on me due to their strong narratives. Far Cry 2 is different. The plot is thin as a potato chip, but its unforgiving sandbox houses an atmosphere thick enough to haunt me offline. Best single-player FPS since Doom? For me, yes. Hands down.

reviewText:
I struggle to decide what I really think of Far Cry2. On the one hand, it's a really good pick-up-&-play with a great weapon load-out, decent application of the sandbox model & an interesting premise. On the other hand, the AI seems to have xray vision, you can't really pick a side & the game feels a bit incomplete on some of the details.

The premise is simple; you are a mercenary sent to a war-torn African country with the simple task of killing an arms-dealer who is selling to both sides & prolonging the conflict. At the time you arrive, there is a shakey peace, but you contract Malaria & fall ill in the local town. You are found by the arms-dealer, named the Jackal, who decides not to execute you, presumably expecting you die a rather miserable & painful death on your own.

You awake some time later with the ceasefire broken & that's where you start; escape the town & get put to work by a member of one of the two factions. The problem is, the game starts to break down even here as you can't choose one side or the other, or neither. On top of that, everyone shoots at you, no matter who you're working for. The excuse is none of the soldiers know which side you're on so shoot first & just forget to ask questions. In reality, the programming for random friend/foe AI was too hard, too expensive or would've taken too long. Or all three. Either way, it can really annoy. The other thing that really annoys me is the fact the AI seems to be able to perfectly spot you in dense jungle, even if you are stood still & behind bushes & trees. The fact you can't see them thanks to the same foliage makes it even more of a fight weighed against you on purpose. These flaws feel like the design team ran out of time to put these mecahnics in, but for me, the making or breaking of a game is the details that really pull you in, & Far Cry 2 feels like is misses that trick.

The game does have some upsides; the weapon load-out is well thought out both in what you can carry & what guns you have access too. There are plenty of weapons for stealth & a night attack where no-one hears or sees you until you kill them is very satisfying. The 1-man army load out will also work great if you're careful with timing & smashing a heavily defended check point without taking any hits is good fun. Vehicles handle ok & there is enough variety in the missions, even if it does usually end up requiring you to simply shoot everything. There is a 'buddy' system, where you can befriend other mercenary characters who assist you or give you missions, even rescue you when you're health runs out. The graphics make it a very pretty game & some of the effects are excellent. My favotire thing are the tape reordings of interviews with the Jackal, some are rather disturbing in how cold the guy is, the little details that help you invest in the world.

The story is basically two parts. In the first, you do missions for the two sides in no particular order, plus a 'resistance' group smuggling civilians out, you're then asked to kill one of the leaders. In the second part, the exact same thing happens again. Needlessly. It does make the world massive, with a huge area to explore, but it feels a little thrown together.

Far Cry 2 is so nearly there; allow you to work for one side or another, allow that to effect how you're seen by each side, make some checkpoints on the roads friend, some foe, some abandonned & make one half of the story cover the whole game & it's potentially a fabulous game.

It sounds like I don't like Far Cry 2, but in actual fact, I do. As a pick-up-&-play, for no more than a few hours, it's great. There's little thought required other than how you want to go about your mission & what weapon load-out to go with, it's a lovely game to spend time in visually, the number of guns you can pick from is wonderfully varied & there are loads of missions to keep you busy. But it's no more than that. If you can accept Far Cry 2 for those flaws, then you'll probably enjoy it as a kind of 'library title'; a game to play between the games you get heavily invested into. Because I am able to see & accept Far Cry 2 for what it is, I feel I CAN recommend it, but with the previso to not expect any real depth from it.

Just shut your eyes on the B-category story, and the annoying malaria pills, and enjoy what the game offers.

reviewText: FIRST: THIS GAME HAS FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT! BUT IT ISN'T LISTED! (I DON'T KNOW WHY IT ISN'T LISTED...) FANTASTIC game.  Atmosphere is its BEST quality.  Just running around the jungles, deserts, and savannahs is a joy.  Then you get plenty of good action.  And stealth!  VERY effectively-executed stealth gameplay.  The large areas and varied atmospheres give you plent of room to plan your strikes.  All animations and graphics are very good, even fitting realistic motions that a person's head would make!  The combat is fairly standard semirealistic shooting except for the large spaces, but the atmosphere and freedom make combat a discovery in the wilderness.  Discover and survive.

reviewText:
What I liked:
- Attention to detail: Wildfires spread, crappy guns jam, foliage conceals you. So many things are unexpectedly realistic.
- Novel setting: Very few games are set in an African landscape, and this one pretty much makes it a main character.
- Total immersion: There are no forced third-person cutscenes, and the HUD only appears when needed or when you press the Reload" key.

What I didn't care for:
- Buddies are fragile: You can only successfully rescue a near-death buddy three times. This means you have to metagame if you want to keep a buddy alive.

Recommendations:
- Don't worry about having played the first Far Cry beforehand; there are no story ties between that game and this one.
- Play it like Fallout 3 or Red Faction Guerrilla
date: not like Call of Duty or Gears of War. Explore
hoursPlayed: and approach fights tactically rather than recklessly.\n- Turn off the music; it's not bad music
voteText: but it causes you to miss subtle audio cues."

reviewText:
This is not as good as farcry 3, but it still is better, kind of, eh...

Want to travel to Africa and experience a gritty story with no heroes, tuly immersive gameplay, and beautiful vistas? This game nailed that, perhaps too well. Because the realistic approach in this game made you feel like a hard working ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, not a happy super hero with no regrets as in Farcry 3.
This game is probably one of the most dynamic and realistic game I have ever tried. There is no handholding and It is incredibly immersive, and difficult. Yet, I have not finished it, and I don't know if I have the time and effort to do so. Because this game is serious work. This is a game to come back to and play over time.

What is good?
No UPLAY

It looks fantastic, it really does. And runs well without the most amazing graphics-card. In some ways I think it looks better than farcry 3, because is feels more real. There are really beautiful vistas in this game that makes you stop and just look around for a while, over and over.

It is very immersive. You are always" in the game. No menus to constantly interrupt you as in farcry 3. The map is held in your hand for example. I really enjoy this interface-idea

reviewText:
Having already played far cry 3 and 4 i had a pretty bias/high expectations for this game but it did dissapoint in some areas. The story is fine but it's very linear style gets boring after a few hours and feels more like a call of duty campagin for example get the mission/ kill the guys and repeat. Athough its an open world game some points of the map makes you feel enclosed and forces you to stay near the roads. After 3 hours i got really board of driving everywhere, the game really discourages exploration in my opinion, the outpost can be scouted but the enemies never go away and that get annoying when you just wana get to your destination. the map lacks a lot of interative feature with very few side mission, unlockables, collectables, crafting, etc. in my 20 hours first play through i did very few side mission and barely explored after 3 hours. i will be generous since you can get this game for very cheap but i would not pay a full 60 for something that  in todays market the feels unfinshed.
Far cry 3 basically used the same formula but makes an terrific campaign and a immersive world with many things to distract you from doing the main story .

final verdict 7/10

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 ist eines meiner absoluten Lieblingsspiele, einfach weil es immer wieder eine neue Entdeckung ist. Ich muss immer wieder aufs Neue Wege suchen, wie ich hierhin komme um dann möglichst gefahrlos zum nächsten Punkt zu kommen.

Grafisch vielleicht nicht up-to-date und kann sicher nicht mit Far Cry3 mithalten, aber ich finde die Grafik immer noch sehr schon und genieße die Umgebung der Wüste, auch bei Nacht sehr schön anzusehen.

Ein absolutes Plus sind auch die Kommentare der gegnerischen KI, denen ich immer sehr gerne zuhöre. Auch ein ganz großes Plus gegenüber Far Cry 3, denn dort ist es immer derselbe Synchronsprecher der die einfachen Soldatenvertont.

Richtig gut finde ich auch die Verteilung der Diamantenkoffer, denn dadurch muss ich immer etwas haushalten und überlegen. ob ich mir das Gesundheitsupgrade wirklich jetzt kaufe oder lieber später, da mir eine schwierige Mission bevorsteht bei der ich schallgedämpfte Waffen brauche. Bezahlt wird mit Rohdiamanten, die man zwar überall finden kann, die Anzahl der tatsächlich enthaltenen Diamanten aber zwischen 1-3 Steinen variiert.

Der einzigste Minuspunkt ist leider die Physik oder was auch immer bei dem Spiel nicht stimmt. Teilweise werden Gegenstände oder Personen wie aus dem Nichts angehoben und fallen dann herunter.

reviewText:
What I liked:
- Attention to detail: Wildfires spread, crappy guns jam, foliage conceals you. So many things are unexpectedly realistic.
- Novel setting: Very few games are set in an African landscape, and this one pretty much makes it a main character.
- Total immersion: There are no forced third-person cutscenes, and the HUD only appears when needed or when you press the Reload" key.

What I didn't care for:
- Buddies are fragile: You can only successfully rescue a near-death buddy three times. This means you have to metagame if you want to keep a buddy alive.

Recommendations:
- Don't worry about having played the first Far Cry beforehand; there are no story ties between that game and this one.
- Play it like Fallout 3 or Red Faction Guerrilla

reviewText:
As far as I'm concerned, Far Cry 2 deserves to be remembered alongside the venerated classics of the genre; Half-Life, Deus Ex, Bioshock, and all those other semi-legendary shooters. But at the same time, it's not entirely surprising that it isn't remembered that way.

To use a really crappy pun, Far Cry 2 is, in many ways, a rough diamond. It might not shine, but it's just as solid and precious as any other of its kind.

Let's start with the good, and the first good thing right off the bat about the game is the setting and atmosphere. How many other shooters take place in sub-Saharan Africa? It's a brilliant premise that's rarely explored in the genre. A war-torn, hostile, exotic setting populated by power-hungry warlords and psychotic mercs? There aren't many other real-world scenarios that would work better as an environment in which to set a shooter of this style, and I find it much more memorable than the exaggerated, tropical setting of Far Cry 3. By Far Cry 4 I was entirely disinterested in the franchise, and never played that game or any later ones. So I can't say anything about them. Far Cry 2's fictional setting is very believable, and the originality and thought put into it is apparent from the get-go.

To go along with the great atmosphere are some genuinely impressive visuals, which might sound weird to those who have only briefly played the game. The vanilla color palette is just plain awful, but the effects, textures, models and shaders are all top-notch for a 2008 title, and the Dunia engine has a few nice tricks up its sleeve. A little tweaking with the Sweetfx shader suite goes a long way towards rectifying the brown, muddy colors and is absolutely essential to getting the most out of the graphics and the overall experience, and with the right tweaks the game has massive visual appeal to this day, even compared to some contemporaries like Crysis that are more well-known for their visuals. The graphics are stylized yet realistic without ever really feeling uncanny or too outdated. Again-aside from the questionable color palette-the care put into the visuals is apparent right from the start.

All this would just be academic if not for gameplay to truly make the game worthwhile, and FC2 surely delivers in that regard as well.

I've always considered Far Cry 2 to be a minimalist shooter, which might sound bizarre when you consider the massive, open world and whatnot. But at its core, there are only a few core elements driving the gameplay here. No shoehorned RPG elements, no crafting, very little NPC interaction, no player-influenced dialogue, not even much of a story. This minimalist, almost barebones approach to gameplay? Well, quite frankly, it's just plain fantastic. One thing I really disliked about Far Cry 3 was the degree of artificial progression in it. By which I mean the skill trees and crafting- this doesn't add flavor to the game as everyone ends up getting everything by the end and it just limits early-game creativity. One term that frequently comes to mind when I think about Far Cry 2 is emergent gameplay;" that is
date: progression that is directed by the player instead of the game. There are unlocks and upgrades
hoursPlayed: and there is a reason to get them

reviewText:
[Played on Hardest difficulty setting with music off]
If you're a fan of Far Cry 3 and are interested in trying this one out, be warned that it might not be what you're expecting.  It's more closely related to games like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. than any of the other games in the Far Cry series.  It's brutally unforgiving and slanted more towards realism and immersion than action-adventure.  The world is large, but exploration isn't necessarily a large part of the gameplay, as the only real purpose for doing so is finding diamonds, hidden tapes, and golden guns -- none of which are particularly essential to the experience of the game.

At its core, the game is about tense gunfights and missions, and the different tactics you can use to ensure your survival.  The game has a robust array of different systems that organically create compelling moments -- last second escapes into the jungle while bullets whiz past you, guns jamming at the least opportune moment and forcing you to flee for the nearest sign of cover, buddies arriving just in the nic of time to save you from an otherwise unwinnable firefight, enemies whom you thought you had killed crawling to their knees and shooting you in the back for revenge -- the list goes on and on, and I'm still discovering new possibilities after hours of play.  Playing with the music turned off increases the tension in the game IMMENSELY, as you never know if there's an enemy around you just waiting for the perfect time to blast you apart and ruin the last ten minutes of progress you'd made.  You'll find yourself checking every corner, listening intently for footsteps or enemy chatter, and cursing yourself when you inevitably miss that lone gunman who finishes you off as soon as you step into the open.

The narrative of the game is also smart and very sensible and aware of the topics which it brings up, which is a helluva lot more than you can say for most modern military shooters.  Don't expect to leave this one feeling like the hero.

tldr;
It's absolutely brilliant, especially if you're into S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-like games and emergent gameplay.

reviewText:
This is a very good open world FPS.  The strongest aspect of the Far Cry series has always been the ability to attack the missions/challenges in any way you see fit; Far Cry 2 allows you to decide how you're going to take on the bad guys.  Run N' Gun?  Stealth?  Snipe everybody (my personal favorite)?

The only negative about the game is the lack of Fast Travel between points you've already discovered.  There's a LOT of driving/walking/boating/swimming that you'll have to do in order to get around the world, but it's not so huge that this becomes a real issue.  You can get to the corners and center of the map via bus stations, but the rest of the time you'll be responsible for getting yourself where you want to go.

So get out there and start tracking down The Jackal.  He's not a very nice person, and no one will miss him when he's gone...

reviewText:
Far cry 2 is, let's say... less than ideal. Long ago I had even anticipated this game to be absolutely awesome, reality however didn't meet my expectations. The original Far cry at the time it appeared was a masterpiece that I enjoyed immensely. It was absolutely gorgeous, engaging to play and overall it just felt good. Far cry number two however falls short or gets you annoyed in several different parts. First of all when I started playing, I wasn't expecting it to be an Africa based awful driving simulator. There's way too much driving around in an open world that has little less activities to do than to shoot at everyone because everyone is extremely mad at you for existing. The world feels empty. How the AI works and behaves is questionable and because the enemy guys' bare chests are actually kevlar or something even sturdier you find yourself asking is this game really a game worth playing. I would go as far to say that it isn't. Too much repetition, too much boring driving and too much forced confrontations with foes that merely want to slow your progress in an annoying way (destroying the engine of your car so you have to stop and fix it).

It isn't all bad however. It brings up some interesting points in the story off how cruel a civil war truly is, the greed of mankind and all sorts of nasty things. The game can look pretty freaking beautiful at times especially on daytime. Some of the guns feel pretty nice to shoot until they jam or break completely and won't shoot anymore. I did finish the game and at the end I felt both relief and contentment.

There are just a lot more and better FPS games to be had than this. Don't waste your time. The predecessor of Far Cry 2 was a better game and so is the successor as well. Better to spend your money on something completely different. Or maybe similar but better if the type of game ticks well with you.

reviewText:
There's a lot to like about Far Cry 2, but it also has more than its fair share of problems. It really gets a worse rap than it deserves, even though many complaints about it are valid.

First off, the good. The game is absolutely beautiful. The CryEngine graphics look amazing, from the lush jungles, to the vast deserts, to the dilapidated villages and towns - everything is great. The character models, the vehicles, the water and waterfalls, the shifting weather patterns, the various guns - I can't say enough good things about them. The combat is visceral and satisfying, with realistic effects like guns jamming and breaking from too much use. The AI is generally smart - they communicate, flank, and call in backup, but it's inconsistent, too. Sometimes they stand in the open or leave cover when they shouldn't. Sometimes they have superhuman vision and hearing, other times they can walk right by you and not notice you at all. Overall, though, it's fun to get into firefights, and the game gives you enough leeway to decide if you want to fight up close or from a distance, quietly or loudly. The vehicles handle generally well, with the exception of the horrible hang-gliders, and there are a variety of fun ones to choose from. I really had a lot of fun playing the game for the first 20 hours or so - then the game's faults started to become more and more annoying.

I think the biggest problem with the game is the repetition. The game is far too repetitive to be as long as it is, or maybe it's far too long to be as repetitive as it is, but either way it doesn't play out well. The issue is that you literally do the same 4 or 5 missions over, and over, and over again through the entire game, all while having to drive insane distances to complete the missions, and while constantly having to clear checkpoints you've already fought your way through. Like I said, this wasn't a dealbreaker for me for the first 18 or 20 hours, but at that point I finally reached a major turning point in the plot, looked at my progress and saw that I had only finished about 50% of the game. The game then just pretty much shifted locations, but all the mission types stayed the same, and I decided that I was just getting bored with it. At that point I took a 2-month break from the game. That helped a bit, as I was able to come back in and finish, though still without the joy I had gotten from the first few hours when everything was new and fresh. The fact that the story is incomprehensible and the voice acting was absolutely painful didn't help, though, and made the game more of a chore than it needed to be.

All in all, it was a fun and amazing-looking game, despite its flaws. I got it cheap, and at 30 hours I sure can't say I didn't get my money's worth. I'd recommend it, just know that you'll have to be patient with it.

reviewText:

Alright, finally finished it. It became slightly repetitive towards the end, and the ending itself wasn't that great, but I had a good time playing it. Probably won't repeat it, but it's still recommended.
/Edit

I'm in the process of finishing this game and I'm having a great time.

To new players: Make sure you install the Dylan realism mod and then crank the difficulty UP a bit, because the mod will make you damage people more realistically (they won't survive direct headshots anymore, for example).

And to be clear, I absolutely LOATHED the checkpoints the first time I played, and subsequently hated the game. After some time away I gave it another shot and quickly got over it being annoying, simply by following the advice from this article: http://majorslack.com/games-tips-tricks/having-fun-playing-far-cry-2/

Taking it more slowly when approaching checkpoints on foot, or just cutting corners or taking shortcuts when driving on the roads, or getting ready to gun them down with the mounted weapon on your vehicle, will help you immensely with the checkpoints.

After a while it got so easy for me avoiding them that I started having fun by creating the most sadistic ways of taking them out, like wounding one guy in the leg to lure out others trying to help him, only for me to pick them off one by one with my trusty sniper rifle, or getting the grenade webbing upgrade and tossing a truckload of grenades into every nook and cranny I could find, blowing everything to smithereens and listening to the ensuing screams of terror.

Then driving my jeep away, looking forward to toy my way through the next encounter while enjoying the beautiful scenery around me as the sun came up or went down in the horizon.

As long as you FOLLOW THE TIPS IN THAT ARTICLE and install the REALISM MOD you're gonna have a game with awesome and gritty atmosphere which any other game will have a hard time matching.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Far Cry 2 is a solid game, with great graphics, a cool story, a realistic, open setting and... a lot of respawning enemies. It's pretty much the only downside to this game. The fact that you have to inject yourself, fix your car, that rockets fall down only a few metres away from you on occasion and that fire spreads across the land is all very unique and adds to the atmosphere. But like I said, the enemies keep respawning. And I'm not talking about the 'you close your game and the next you start it the enemies have respawned' kind of respawning. No, more like 'enemies respawn within 30 minutes or so' respawning. It gets very frustrating because at times you get the feeling that you have no influence on the gameworld, that you're doing practically everything for nothing. If you can just ignore that then there's a great game waiting for you here.\n\n[Rating: 86/100]

reviewText: I got this after Far Cry 3 just to experience more of the series. This has a different feel than FC3. More of a raw, gritty, type of atmosphere that is frustratingly fun. Good story line and a nice selection of weapons. Guard shacks always respawn so it's never safe" to just cruise down the road to your next objective. Random enemies patrolling in vehicles will constantly be a thorn in your side but that's part of the fun. Enemies aren't always easy to spot. They'll hide in the trees and shrubs and they're clothing will annoyingly blend in to the environment around them. I can't count the number of times I've nearly died just trying to figure out where the hell I'm being shot from. Nothing like thinking you have an area cleared out and then have a wounded mercenary sit up
date: pull a side arm and start giving one last ditch effort to off you."

reviewText: Jumping is crap and several diamond-filled briefcases are either impossible to get, or I lack the creativity and jumping skills to get them.\n\nWith that out of the way, there is no game like Farcry 2. It is a game about violence. It is not a game about violence. You are the good guy out to kill the bad guy. You are the bad guy out to kill the good guy. You have friends, or do you? There is a moral choice; there is no moral choice. If you don't understand my mutterings, play the game and you will. For a game that provides chaotic combat and satisfying action, it also provides its thoughts on war and human nature. A wonderful game to play mindlessly, and a wonderful game to play knowing full well what you're doing in game.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is tedious, but if you value immersion above being fast-paced then you'd be hard pressed to find a better game.

The empowerment you feel from playing the game comes from you persevering through mechanics that have been made more difficult than it is in typical FPS games by integrating real-world aspects, sometimes to unrealistic extremes. Playing through the campaign at max difficulty (makes you about as squishy as every NPC mook) with the music turned off (when you're on a far hill quietly picking off enemies one by one, hearing intense combat music play definitely throws you out of the moment).

-Your reputation" acts as your EXP level in the game
date: and generic NPC's react accordingly. Guards will tell you to f*ck off and frequently threaten you at the beginning of the game
recommended: but as you level up their dialogue will descend into professional respect and then to superstitious fear.\n\n-The HUD is very intentionally limited; the only onscreen effects are your health and ammo and they quickly fade when not in use. The map and compass have to be brought up like a weapon
hoursPlayed: and simulate a real paper map with pages of different scales. Sometime's it's a pain in the ♥♥♥ to be at the very bottom of a map section and not be able to see a decent area around you
voteText: but it's frustration with something that would be in real life
helpfulPercent: not frustration with some contrived immersion-breaking game mechanic so it only adds to the immersion.\n\n-You have to drive everywhere on the map but destinations are often close together and the geocaching side-quests
votesHelpful: constant threat of ambush
votesTotal: and the detail put into making the "HUD" map feel real keep transportation from being boring. It's a rush to be looking down at your map
votesFunny: hear a close gunshot
commentsCount: and jolt back to the road to see a patrol that just came around the corner.\n\n-Guns start to jam around after you fire your very limited ammo capacity
column16: but it forces you to plan ahead like a true professional and make full use of your 3 weapons slots. Necessity is the mother of invention
column17: and the situations where you're completely surrounded with everything but your pistol broken because you weren't efficient with your shots make the game memorable. Likewise
column18: the feeling of satisfaction when an outpost hit comes together perfectly because you stored the right backup loadout in your safehouse really seals the deal that you're a true professional and an unstoppable force.\n\n-Despite the game's difficulty
column19: it's very feasible to beat the game without dying. The PC's that you didn't choose to play as can be encountered in-game and and turned into allies
column20: and will rescue you if your health drops to 0. They're not invincible though
column21: and they needed to be protected then met in a safehouse if you want to be rescued again by them.\n\nFar Cry 2 quickly became one of my favorite games because of how it sucked me in
column22: made me feel weak
column23: and then let me slowly adapt to it until I truly felt like the hardcore motherf*cker that I was supposed to be playing. 10/10
column24: would recommend to anyone who wants to get absolutely submerged in a game."

reviewText:
Clint Hocking's a genius, but it certainly took me a few hours (across the span of about five years) before Far Cry 2 finally clicked.

This game is outright unfair toward the player, but that's kind of the point. The openness of game and its encounter design remain unmatched in the realm of shooters. Far Cry 3 seemed to learn all the wrong lessons, and the Assassin's Creedification of the series only served to clutter the screen with way too much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

Having your .50 cal sniper rifle fall to pieces in your hands, forcing you to pick up an unreliable AK from the body of one of the militiamen you've just dropped and wing the damned thing--it's just exhilerating.

Great game. Better than what came before and certainly better than what's come since.

reviewText:
Well, here is a guy, that recommends the game even though he rarely enjoyed it and stuck at the 21. main mission because of a bug, that doesn't let him shoot any gun.
I tried to load earlier saves but to no avail. After I got the 21. mission it came back again, so I had to quit.
Anyways here is my review:

+The graphics are decent.
+The environment is really beautiful. You got deserts, forests, mountains, rivers, cliffs. It is a joy to wander about.
+There is different types of vehicles, which we are able to fix.
+A good variety of weapons and upgrades, that we can unlock with our gems. The gems are gained through missions or searching.
+The map is big.
+Your old weapons and the ones that you get from your enemies after you killed them can break down or might not function properly, which I found really realistic.
+There are buddies, that let you finish the mission some other way and help you sometimes when you are on the verge of getting killed.

-As I said earlier, there are some bugs that stop you from completing the game.
-Literally three quarter of the game consists of driving. The map is huge and you have to drive to everywhere or use the bus. But there is only five bus stops in the game. They are at the four corner of the map and one in the middle, so not very convenient.
-The story isn't that interesting. Classical civil war story. (I can tell because it is my second playthough, I played it once when I was younger)
-The voice acting is horrible. The accents are poor and everybody talks very fast without intonation. So it is a little bit hard to understand them, if English is not your native tongue or if you're not very competent.
-There is two factions in the game, where we get our missions from. We do missions for both of them but even the soldiers of the faction, that we currently do the mission for, attack us because  it's a classified mission." Well
date:
I could say okay for a couple of missions but every freaking one of them is the same so it doesn't make sense and becomes annoying fighting the both.
-There are enemy posts that we can scout after we kill everyone in there BUT they respawn after 5 minutes so you have to kill them every time you pass by and believe me you will pass by a lot because the game is a freaking driving simulator. You can of course pass by without stopping and killing them but they come with vehicles to shoot at you so you can't actually run away if you aren't lucky. I mean it is good because it gives a challenge but it starts to get on the nerves after a while.

As I said earlier
recommended: I recommend the game even though I couldn't enjoy it that much but I feel like everybody should at least give it a try to see for themselves. I really don't know why I recommend it. :)\n\nSo this was my review. I hope you enjoyed reading it."
hoursPlayed: February 18, 2015

reviewText: Underrated. Way too underrated. Saddens me to see people crave FC3 and FC4 not knowing anything about their predecessor (get it). reviewText:
It builds itself on being somewhat realistic, instead of hyperstimulating like its sequels. Hindering mechanics allow you to live out your mercenary power fantasy while still feeling vulnerable,and most of the mechanics are handled in game rather than in menus, so there's very little pausing. At the same time, it remains far simpler in formula compared to similar titles, like Stalker. Much of the game's open world has you doing side missions which, while sticking to very repeated formulas, are still very enjoyable. The faction and story missions, which offer choices within them, are sadly often served to the player in a fashion that gives the player very little choice at first, for example, forcing the player to work for a faction he may not want to. Other than that, it is very open-ended, allowing the player to make any decision about loadout, and almost any story choice. This can lead to permanent consequences if the player is not careful. The end of the game, while linear, neatly ties up the depressing (for all the right reasons) story, which is memorable because it is told through a combination of dialogue and the unique faction missions. Most notable is the deuteragonist, the Jackal, and how you learn most about him through the tapes and the dialogue of other characters.
The stealth mechanic is something that is often brought up concerning this game. Many people say that stealth is pointless here, but I must disagree. It's not that stealth is futile; It's that stealth sometimes works in a very realistic manner, and sometimes the enemy can't tell when you accidentally almost step on his heel. Variable, yes, but I have not encounted the supposed clairvoyant AI this game has.
Cons:
-First, the AI. Having AI that relentlessly pursues in vehicles and takes cover when needed is one thing I wish more games of this style did, to make it feel dangerous, like there's really a group of lunatics chasing me. Then I saw a car full of baddies plunge off a cliff into a river, while I was safely standing several hundred feet away. Why they did this, I have no idea.
-The graphics. It's not the brown and bloom I have a problem with. In fact, I'd say it sets a very good scene for the atmosphere of the game, and even if you don't want it, you can turn it off in the options. My problem is the pop-in. Maybe it's my toaster of a computer, maybe it's just the game, but it kills my immersion to see everything from billboards to distant hills jump in and out of existence, while enemies and vehicles stay in perfect focus, when I move all of a hundred feet. Also, some of the textures seem stretched, but at least they covered it up with foliage.
-The sound. The music is too loud, while the talking is too quiet. This can be fixed in the options menu, but when I'm trying to have a talk with someone in a building while there's a firefight raging outside, and the voice of those outdoors are muffled, the voice of the guy talking indoors gets muffled in an identical way. Like, this dude standing two feet in front of me sounds like we're speaking through a wall.
-Invisible walls. I'm not talking about the edges of the map. The game world needs to end somewhere, and it rarely encourages you to go out that far. The invisible walls on hills, ledges, and fences where it looks like I should be able to jump over simply do not allow it. Why these could not have been covered by actual objects, I do not know.
-Ubisoft account requirement for a lot of the features. Multiplayer requires a Ubisoft account, as does the promotional content and mapshare (which is sad, because this mapmaker is one of the easiest to use and gives very fine results).
-Programming errors. Sometimes music tracks loop endlessly if a game is loaded under certain circumstances, requiring a trip back to the main menu, and then another load to the game.
The Jackal Tapes are also a bit bugged. Every tape I picked up after the one about the boy with the boots has been about the boy with the boots. Thank heavens for YouTube.
When I take a bus into some of the ceasefire zones, especially later in the game, sometimes a soldier on patrol in the town will just spontaneously die for no reason. It even happened to the APR doorman at Mosate Selao, and the game claimed I broke the ceasefire, so I had to leave and come back to make everyone once again nonhostile.

Other than that, the game is an experience like few others. If you want an open world game that gives you something to do, that makes you actually feel in danger, that punishes you for not taking it seriously, this is for you.

reviewText:
Clint Hocking's a genius, but it certainly took me a few hours (across the span of about five years) before Far Cry 2 finally clicked.

This game is outright unfair toward the player, but that's kind of the point. The openness of game and its encounter design remain unmatched in the realm of shooters. Far Cry 3 seemed to learn all the wrong lessons, and the Assassin's Creedification of the series only served to clutter the screen with way too much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

Having your .50 cal sniper rifle fall to pieces in your hands, forcing you to pick up an unreliable AK from the body of one of the militiamen you've just dropped and wing the damned thing--it's just exhilerating.

Great game. Better than what came before and certainly better than what's come since.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is the sequel of the FPS Far Cry, this time set in the heat of Africa. It involves hunting down ''The Jackal'', the feared arms-dealer that fueled the war between two nations. Meanwhile, you're also constantly fighting against your contracted malaria.

PROS:
+ Long gameplay
+ A very worthy game for its price
+ Good graphics, despite its age
+ Immediate freeroaming
+ Packed with the Fortune's Pack DLC
+ A good variation of satisfying-to-use guns
+ Lovable open nature of flora and fauna

CONS:
- The missions and various subjects (music, sounds, voice lines, etc.) are slightly repetitive
- The health system and certain damage sources are a bit odd/unrealistic
- The voice acting sounds like it is sped up somtimes

Definitely one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played.

My rating: 9.5/10

reviewText:
Can you say 'underrated?'

Yea, you'd better believe it, Far Cry 2 is the best title in the series, for me. Perfect? No, but neither is the rest of the series. Totally satisfying? No, but neither is the rest of the series. Dropping with atmosphere like the knifed fresh corpse of a wilderbeast drips that essential red elixir? You must believe it. And this is a quality that evades the rest of the series entirely.

You are [I can't remember I've played too many similar games], a face into which a video game camera has been thrust, itself belonging to a body which has been thrust right into the meatgrinder of a central african (I wanna say 'kinda Kenya but more sandy' though this may be entirely incorrect) civil war, complete with savage flora, savage fauna and savage hearts. You begin the game staring wonderously at the bump map'd face of a taxi driver as he drives you deeper and deeper into a threatening looking square of hell - dissapointingly scaled to accomodate the xbox 360 I believe, but certainly impactful - where he drops at a hotel. You get out, get to your room, get to bed and wake up with infected with Malaria and dodging bullets as fighting has broken out in the town.

You escape. You have no idea where you are. The landscape is alien and scary, the locals seem more like human big cats with AKs and a thirst for blood than video game villains, the roars of labouring car engines spark off immediate GTFO of here!" sprints for cover
hoursPlayed: a hot sun beats down on you like a express post migraine
voteText: and you eventually make it to a safe house where a bunch of uncaring locals welcome you to their collective deathwarrant and start giving you orders. You net some pills for the Malaria - things which will always stick with you and occasionally give you cause to run errands for the missionaries who supply them - and a rusty assault rifle and you're loose - free to do what you will

reviewText:
This game was quite a slog to me, and the only reason I finished was because I am a bit of a completist. It is quite a long game, especially if you finish all side missions. Playing on and off for a few weeks and using a map showing all diamond case locations, I got through the campaign in about 25 hours.

I think my main issue was that every mission was the exact same. Blow this up or kill that person. I do enjoy 'splosions and assassination missions, but nothing changes in the world as you go through the campaign, so playing them gets mundane quickly.

The world itself is large. I loved the day/night cycle and weather. The thing that aggravated me the most about traveling in this world was the rapidly respawning guard shacks. You wipe out everyone in the area, drive down the road for a bit, turn back around, and voila, everyone is back. It feels like an annoying tactic to make the game last longer than it should. I'd understand guards being there after 6 in-game hours or something, but just getting out of sight of the area shouldn't prompt automatic respawns.

Far Cry 2 was quite a change from the original. While I appreciated some changes, the lack of an engaging narrative and repetitive missions/opponents made this game more of a bore the longer it lasted.

5/10

reviewText:
A great core game clogged up by glitches and poorly designed filler.

PROS:

+ Guns are FANTASTIC! (Before entering real combat, that is.) Large variety. Animation's decent, sound effects are excellent, and they tear up landscape pretty good. Poorly maintained guns jam and misfire in varying ways. Firing guns in this game leaves me with a headache and ringing ears... in a good way.

+ Certain aspects are very immersive. You're stuck in Africa. You haven't much to rely on beyond your non-pausing map, health syringes, and safe havens. Ammo and health can burn quickly. Keep moving and stay alive.

+ Asthetically, the map is good. Feels like Africa based on the five or six Nationa Geographic shots I've seen.

+ As many have said, fire is fun. Tall grass and foliage burn up quickly and in large quantities.

+ Visuals haven't aged too poorly. Very serviceable considering the years this game has on it.

+ Some neat dynamic enemy behavior. They talk between each other during combat appropriate to what just happened. They'll sling their wounded buddies over their shoulder and run for cover.

+ The malaria pill fetching reminded me of Zombrex in Dead Rising 2... which was a better game I'd been reminded I could be playing.


CONS:


- Enemy AI sporadically changes between dirt dumb and brilliant. Enemies can miss shots within three feet of you, but nail you in your moving vehicle a hundred yards away. Enemies can not detect you when you crouch right next to them, but discover you crouched in tall grass from a hundred yards away. Weapons they nail you with across the map are pitifully inaccurate when you pick them up and use them youself. They can even detect you THROUGH COVER, often shooting through thinner walls nailing you perfectly.

- Not all guns do not behave predictably. Multiple close quarters headshots with 7.62 ammunition can serve to just stun an enemy. An entire pistol magezine loaded into an enemy's body still has him up and about shooting.

- The map is littered with enemy holdouts. Not a problem in Far Cry 3. When you invade these incampments in FC3, you can clear them out, permanently. In this game, killing everyone in the outpost means: They all respawn! Not even ten real life minutes later! Over sixty of these ♥♥♥♥ing things are upon every major road and water way. If you want to drive for more than two minutes, you'll run into one of these encampments. Your best bet is to floor it through them, and even that doesn't work well. Enemies chip away at your health every time you drive past. Often they'll scramble a vehicle to follow you. No firing weapons in vehicles, your best defense is to bail out, shoot your persuers, repair your car for the umptenth time, and keep moving.

- As many have said, Malaria is an arbitrary difficulty complication. Another example of where this game favors realism" over "immersion". Every 30 real life minutes you suffer an incurable malaria attack. To not pass out and restart at a safehouse
date: you need to take Malaria pills. You CAN NOT acquire these pills willingly! You need to progress through the story to get them! Should you decide you want to do the side content for a couple hours
recommended:
get used to passing out and restarting every once in a while.

- Not much to do outside of the main story. Side missions pretty much always consist of killing everyone in an enemy camp or blowing up a vehicle.

- Story's thread bare. That doesn't matter too much. What DOES matter pretty much every character is horridly voice acted. The actors sound like text-to-speech machines; monotone and rarely giving appropriate inflections. For some strange reason
hoursPlayed: the game often speeds up their lines as well. They talk as if commas and periods don't exist.\n\n- Random bugs. I've encountered bugs where unpausing causes you to automatically throw a grenade
voteText: one where switching to my primary weapon caused my character to start walking to the right for some reason
helpfulPercent: bugs where vehicles would automatically reverse when I entered them. They all fixed themselves when I restarted the game
votesHelpful:
but it was rather odd and annoying that they were there in the first place.


I wanted to enjoy this game. I was told "Far Cry 3 without the handholding." At its core
votesTotal: this game is solid. Little design flaws like braindead AI and the constant attacks from guard outposts every five minutes become incredibly bothersome when the game is littered with them. Stealth is almost nonfunctional. Loud combat is buggy but sometimes servicable.\n"Immersion" in this game boils down to something like a Grand Theft Auto game where cops won't come after you for murder but will give you a speeding ticket without fail. reviewText: I'm generally a fan of free-roam first-person shooters, but Far Cry 2 was a big disappointment. If you're a hardcore shooter fan that likes a challenge, solid gunplay, diverse gameplay, and refreshing mechanics, this isn't the shooter for you.\n\nNearly every quest boils down to drive to the other side of the map and kill some people / blow something up". There is no variety in enemies - you face thugs with low health and bad AI toting rifles

column17: and they'll do it whether or not anyone saw you enter.\n\nThe game certainly has its moments - the first time I was rescued by a buddy was one of the most memorable experiences I've had in gaming (but the buddy-rescue system quickly gets stale and sometimes becomes a nuisance when you have to babysit your buddy for 20 ****ing minutes so they don't get killed). The large and diverse landscape is a refreshing change from the scenery in most shooters - you certainly feel like you're in Africa. I found the unique realism elements - the map you physically hold in front of you in the game (accurately simulates crashing while looking down at the map!) repairing vehicles

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Fantastic Engine
+ Runs smooth even on weaker pc's
+ Excellent Graphics even in 2015
+ Large open world
+ You can burn the environments and start huge wildfires
+ Decent variety of firearms.

Negatives:
- Everything respawns, if you leave a camp 40 metres the whole camp will respawn and shoot at you again
- Change in difficulty just gives enemies more health.
- Roaming patrols will regulary shoot your vehicle every few minutes possibly leaving you stranded
- Cannot shoot from vehicles
- Story is very poorly executed and feels like an after thought.
- Game breaking bugs exist that may mean you cannot progress story.
- Very repetitive gameplay
- Little variety in vehicles/npc's
- Buddy missions are poorly implemented.
- Malaria
- Modding cannot fix the above

My suggestion is give this one a miss, My reasoning is that FC2 will likely frustrate you more than give you any type of enjoyment; should you choose to ignore my warning be gentle on yourself and use one of the realism mods.

FC2 was very close to something brilliant, but fell short in just a few areas which make it a less than enjoyable experience very quickly.

reviewText: FC2 is a game that tries very hard to be an open world RPG, with choices, secondary missions, buddies and upgradable weapons. Sadly, it's a failure: fake and useless choices, repetitive gameplay, zero story, absolutely no morals (you are not a hero here, you are a mercenary ready to kill for anyone who has money) and it's way too long (30-40 hours). The good thing? You have a lot of weapons, to buy.

reviewText:
The game delivers a cliché look at Africa as it's presented in popular media. It's a dull and beaten vision with no wonders to uncover or surprises to stumble onto. Though it looked great at it's heyday, the years have not been kind to it. The game has aged terribly having both the design and mechanics feel old and tired.

I can see how they wanted to create this huge open-world game but didn't really have anything to fill it with so they just cluttered the map with all the same stuff. As the result you'll get a game where you've seen it all after a couple hours of gameplay. It does have it's moments, like the brutal self-surgeries that you have to perform or the jamming weapons that make the battles feel more real but those sparks are drowned in the myriad of flaws the game has to offer.

Every...Single...Misson follows same pattern:
1. Get mission.
2. Drive to the other side of Africa.
3. Grind through endless guard posts.
4. Repair car.
5. Repeat steps 3 & 4 till you contract malaria from playing the game.
6. Take malaria pill.
7. Kill a village-full of sharp-shooters.
8. Save game or you have to do it all over again because there's no autosave.
9. Get new mission AND DO EXACTLY THE SAME THING ALL OVER AGAIN!

The Battles:
- A.I. always knows where you are, even if you switch positions.
- Enemies have perfect aiming, even from hundreds of meters away, in the middle of the night!
- You can not guess from what direction you are being shot at. You could not even tell if you are moving towards the shooter, or away from him!
- You get shot the very second you peek from behind a cover.
- Enemies who speak to each other sound like they are just around the corner even if they are far away.
- Enemies are able to hit you in the middle of the night, with a shotgun, from a hundred meters away, from behind an house!

The game's full of bugs too:
- Mission givers heads shake like crazy when you interact with them.
- Random guy fell from the sky to his death in front of me.
- In bar objects floating without table underneath.
- Misson givers voice and gestures occasionally out of place.
- A.I. shooting you from behind the cover.
- Fixed machine guns fail to hit targets at close range, rendering them completely useless.
- Enemy shooting AND hitting you while having his back turned towards you.

Verdict:
I think I would have loved the game back in the time when it came out but it just doesn't compete with anything the industry produces today. Consider modding the game which will improve it enough to look exciting for an extra couple hours. The 10 hours I put in this game feel like an excessive waste of time.

reviewText:
This is an awful game in almost every aspect... So let's try and summarise it...

- Since you are in Africa, and as we all know it, when you are in Africa, everything must be filtered through some awful brownish/yellowish colour to remind you... That you are in Africa... Or Mexico, or wherever... It is not pleasant for eyes...
- Enemy AI goes from completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mushroom IQ to ultra intelligent super computer/robot from far future with integrated infra red/night vision/cat's ears...
- About 50% of time fighting, you will turn around like an idiot, trying to pinpoint exact location of enemy who is shooting...
- Once you shoot at them, they are able to see you even if you are laying silently in 1 meter high grass...
- And, if that was not enough, once you clear out an enemy camp, return 10 minutes later, everyone are alive and kicking! ♥♥♥♥ yeah! :)
- Missions... Oh, side missions... Every mission is the same... They tell you some completely irrelevant back story, and tell you to kill/destroy someone... You go to the mission location, there are 2-3 cars and usually a truck going in circles (!?)... Destroy the truck, and TA-DA, diamonds are automatically in your pocket!
- Talking about cars... There are, I don't know, maybe 4 different vehicles in game... I cannot find any difference between them when driving...
- And talking about driving... Wow, since most of the map is awful brownish terrain, you won't feel like exploring... There is nothing to explore, world is ugly (except for few exceptions), you will end up driving from one part of the map to the other all the time... Especially since missions are almost always as far from as they can be, from the point you took them... There are some bus stations, but they are so rare, it's easier to just drive...
- Also, player character has a malaria... So, from time to time, you'll need to take pills, or survive through vertigo effects... It might be important for story, but I still have a feeling that it is too burdensome for gameplay...
- As, it is usually a problem with games, main character is a mute ♥♥♥♥♥♥...

And now for Pros;

- It has a QUIT button. I really tried to like this game, but...

Yeah, it's actually one of the games I cannot find any good thing about; it's boring, repetitive and full of little problems and bugs... It's obnoxious...

TL;DR: Don't.... just... Don't...

reviewText:
How to create a astonishingly beautiful world - to fill it with nothing worth playing
Well, what can be said about Far Cry 2 ? The follow-up to FC 1 - not developed by Crytek which should focus on the to-be-released first Crysis that would set new standards in graphics and enactment in FPS in the day, but Ubisoft Montreal instead  - which was a great sandbox/openworld shooter promised many things and many hands-on by Game magazines made me long for this game back in the day.
It should became some years later until I finally managed to get my hands on it during a steam sale and I was pretty disappointed after the credits rolled.

Strange thing is, the Ideas the developers had for this game sounded really great: A breathing, living, open world, choosing a side between different factions, a buddy-system, choices and consequences, degrading weapons (first FPS-game since System Shock 2 that had this mechanic at least from the games I know of), gorgeous visuals... I mean, what's not to love ? Well, Practice turned out different than Theory.

Well, first let's focus on the things the Game got right.

An open world with gorgeous visuals, day-and-night rhythm, great physics, realistic Fire, vegetation...
Really fun fights, great gunplay with degrading weapons, weapon jams, well-balanced that makes for a gritty, ruthless atmosphere
Interesting setting in a nameless african country in civil war with two different factions ...
Buddies" that come to help and give you new missions ...
clever AI for the most part...
Lots of missions...
A great staged kick-off into the game...
now the bad and the ugly:

... that feels not alive. Aside from some alibi-fauna animals the wolrd is pretty much empty. Where are the citizens ? How come I only encounter the same clone-rebells on the street ? It seems more like a great postcard idyll than a living
date: breathing world that goes it's way regardless what the player does.\n... that quickly becomes very stale because of lousy gamedesign. A country at civil war yet there are no citizens to be encountered in the world apart from a few refugees
hoursPlayed: a doctor and some others ? Just feels false. It doesn't matter and has no consequences for which faction you decide. Killed the villain on top of the organisation of the other group ? Doesn't matter

reviewText:
I've played through Far Cry 3 at least four times and recently completed a second play-through of Far Cry 4, so I thought I'd go back to Far Cry 2 since I’ve only played it once before. I've only gotten through a few missions now and I'm already sorry I gave it another shot. While the visuals are fairly impressive, there are so many aspects of this game that make it bad.

FC 3 did a great job of addressing the major issues with FC2 which, in when you compare the two games, really makes you aware of how bad FC2 is. The biggest problem is how long it takes to get anywhere. Traveling by vehicle speeds up your travel time, but the terrain is setup so you almost always have to go around any hills, even short ones. The map system is meant to mimic having a real map in your hand, but since you can only get a close-up view of the section you’re currently in, you can’t look around other areas to see if there is anything interesting you may want to explore. You also can’t add a waypoint to where you want to go, so when you’re traveling you constantly need to have the map deployed in order to keep visual track of where you’re trying to get to.

The ability to easily kill enemies isn’t consistent with logic. Headshots don’t always instantly kill an enemy, which I can understand if you’re at a distance and you potentially don’t get the shot dead on. However, standing right next to an enemy and shooting them in the head at point-blank range doesn’t always kill them instantly either. It would make sense that a shotgun blast to any part of the body should at least cause them to fall down, but I would frequently unload three shots at point-blank range before they tumble.

There are a number of other problems with the game, but just the combination of these two factors make the game difficult to enjoy.

ويلي بدو يشتريها يشتريها بالتخفيضات او من موقع خارجي أفضل

صراحة اللعبة فيها شوية مشاكل بتجيك وانا اجتني فيها كم مشكلة خلتني اسحب لفترة طويلة بعدين حليتها ورجعت كملت التختيم

عبي دمي او ذخيرة او قنابل او سيارة :)

من عيوبها قلة الكات سينس و ندرتها كمان يعني المشاهد السينمائية او المقاطع يلي بتطلعلك وانت عم تختم اللعبة

بالنهاية بنصح أي واحد بيحب ألعاب العالم المفتوح و الحروب يجيبها لعبة ممتعة :)

8/10

reviewText:
This game has a very interesting Premise, and could have a promising storyline. It has beautiful scenery and effects.

But it is little more than a console game ported to PC. You spend more time traveling (and clearing the same guardpost of people 5 minutes later if you have to turn around) than you do anything else.

The gameplay is unimaginative, the AI is pretty dumb and predictable (but not always), there is not much as far as interaction beyond shooting, and you have to grind to get any decent weapons.

It's a novelty. I played for about 30 hours and decided I really didn't care to keep spending 80% of my time traveling somewhere to get an assignment on the other end of the map and rescuing my idiot friends" who kept on doing things like trying to assault an entire convoy on their own and getting mortally wounded before I showed up.
In short
date: they should have tried harder. You'll have more fun watching youtube clips than actually playing it."
