reviewText:
I've played through Far Cry 3 at least four times and recently completed a second play-through of Far Cry 4, so I thought I'd go back to Far Cry 2 since I’ve only played it once before. I've only gotten through a few missions now and I'm already sorry I gave it another shot. While the visuals are fairly impressive, there are so many aspects of this game that make it bad.

FC 3 did a great job of addressing the major issues with FC2 which, in when you compare the two games, really makes you aware of how bad FC2 is. The biggest problem is how long it takes to get anywhere. Traveling by vehicle speeds up your travel time, but the terrain is setup so you almost always have to go around any hills, even short ones. The map system is meant to mimic having a real map in your hand, but since you can only get a close-up view of the section you’re currently in, you can’t look around other areas to see if there is anything interesting you may want to explore. You also can’t add a waypoint to where you want to go, so when you’re traveling you constantly need to have the map deployed in order to keep visual track of where you’re trying to get to.

The ability to easily kill enemies isn’t consistent with logic. Headshots don’t always instantly kill an enemy, which I can understand if you’re at a distance and you potentially don’t get the shot dead on. However, standing right next to an enemy and shooting them in the head at point-blank range doesn’t always kill them instantly either. It would make sense that a shotgun blast to any part of the body should at least cause them to fall down, but I would frequently unload three shots at point-blank range before they tumble.

There are a number of other problems with the game, but just the combination of these two factors make the game difficult to enjoy.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is a first person shooter that takes place in a war torn country in infamously war torn Africa.  And it speaks to me.  This game is truly a far cry (no pun intended) from the original; the first game being a sci-fi shooter involving genetic mutations that held a very 80's-90's vibe in its approach; but it is by no means a far cry in a negative way.  To be honest this game manages to successfully convey a message that I myself already more or less knew; whether or not it did so on purpose remains to be seen.

I have a lot of positive and negative experiences in this game.  The main negative is probably that it is a very long game that does a lot of repeating itself; clear a safe house, track a checkpoint, do a convoy mission here, an assassination mission there, rage at some OP patrol car with a grenade launcher in that direction and so on.  Despite this I managed to finish the game and walked away feeling like it was a great experience.  You essentially go through war-torn Africa on the hunt for an arms dealer whose guns are potentially further aggrivating a very intense and deadly conflict.  You get to see the decay and decadance caused by a society in conflict, one that is trying its hardest to decide whether it should be westernized or remain its own culture but unable to choose between both, and you make friends and enemies along the way.  But you realize as you keep collecting diamonds and using them to buy new weapons and equipment that you slowly are starting to lose yourself, and it's only by the end when you see everything coming to a standstill that you truly realize just how far you've come...and just how much you've lost yourself in the process.

I know that's pretty philisophical for a review, but this game has left me feeling philisophical.  It's honestly a great game to play.

Now before I close this review I do feel obligated to point a few things out, especially for people looking to play the game.  This game, while old, has the right kind of bugs that makes it YouTube gold.  Probably the most infamous bug in my playthrough was when NPCs wouldn't stand still and kept deciding that they were on a punching bag stand (in my first attempt to play the game I saw a bunch of villagers bobbing up and down and literally thought that they were doing some sort of ritualistic African jumping dance for some reason XD).  Less fun bugs includes the bug involving the Jackal Tapes (which you will find out in the forums), as well as the occasional crashes that occur in between saves (word to the wise, keep extra save files, becuase some people have had corrupted saves occur deep into the game), but there is nothing that's absolutely game breaking.  I will also point out that unlike future Far Cry games the animals aren't hostile and are more of an interactive element, which is a shame considering that I feel like a game set in Africa that didn't include at least one mission involving an African Safari Hunt was a missed opportunity.

If you've played any of the other games (3, 4, and Primal) and want to try something closer to the roots, or if you're into old fashioned shooters but want something less linear and more free roam than the original, Far Cry 2 is for you.

-Kerian

reviewText:
A bright gem in the world of FPS shooters, Far Cry 2 takes us to a place we all know, or at least the members of our family from generations past knew - the world of struggle, strife and corruption. It comes alive in spectacular style and is one of the most realistic of all the fictional locales used in today´s PC games. The guns, the glory, the greed all merge and create an authentic and powerful story. Driven by an excellent gameplay engine, Far Cry 2 enables you to fight in a variety of ways, from employing stealth to outright firefighting. You can kill you enemies silently from afar, using the vegetation as your cover, or engage in gun battles in a variety of ways. The hillsides offer excellent fallback positions and allow you to plan your next  move. Whether you want to pick everyone out in an area using your sniper rifle, or burrow  your way through their compounds and outposts, Far Cry 2 will offer you ample chances to do both.

This installment offers a wide diversity of of weapons,  manual loading, semi automatic  and fully automatic. Explosive weapons are also available. Some come with their own scopes, allowing you to sniper bomb enemy cars before, or after the driver and his fellow soldiers get in.  The grass and trees can be set on fire, allowing you to create a shield of fire to drive the enemies while you reposition yourself and shoot them before they can regain their bearings.

A serious game for a veteran player, Far Cry 2 is a haven for the creative killer, the adventurer and the explorer. Get it, if you really want to see the wild side of Africa in all its glory.

reviewText: I tried for hours, searching the internet, for fixes to a never ending series of problems with this game.  From glitches with characters and the environment all the way to a persistent buzzing I would hear over my speakers...there were far too many to fix and I eventually gave up.  This game is unplayable...  The most game breaking glitch was having characters who, once talked to, would move and thus ruin the speech script.  Ever have a character say one line, move and thus reset itself?  Thereby saying that one line over and over and over and over until you found that one exact sweet spot for it to finish the sentence and start the next sentence, only to have the character move its arm or turn it head and thus repeat the same problem?  That is what happened to me...over and over and over again...  Ugh...  I applied fix after fix to encounter more and more problems.  The opening scene where you are driven around in the taxi was the first problem.  The NPCs would get in front of the car (while literally BOUNCING around the screen) and thus stop the entire sequence.  Only several reloads and pure luck got me through that.  Add in all the glitches with that persistent buzzing I would hear over the speakers (read around, it is a common problem) and the game went from frustrating to ANNOYINGLY frustrating.  All in all, if you luck out and get the game to work for you...you are fortunate.  As for me, I am truly and greatly disappointed with this game.

reviewText: Far Cry 2 is a pretty game, even today, with an expansive world of reasonable variety. Though players can attempt to tackle the game as they would a sandbox actioner, Far Cry 2 requires a more measured response. There is a lot driving to do, but it feels real to do so. The environment is a harsh and unforgiving place, just as you may expect. Yet, that every living soul outside of a safe zone wants to kill you (and even those in safe zones would love an excuse to kill you) is slightly less 'real'. At the start of the game, your driver negotiates a trade so as to gain passage through a checkpoint. Sadly, that kind of mechanic is for cutscenes only. The only toll is paid in bullets and blood. While exciting at first, the realisation that when next you pass through those enemies will have returned to fight again, can become frustrating. However, those issues aside, the game is rich and fluid. FPS fans will squeeze a lot of fun times from this game, though they may never finish it.

reviewText: It's nothing like Far Cry 1. This game is.. interesting. It has a lot of cool elements, and a lot of not so cool ones, but the game did a lot right. The story is kind of boring and falls apart almost directly after the intro. The game is highly open world like Far Cry 1, but that's where the similarities end. The game has major AI problems, don't trust Ubisoft. If you walk up behind an enemy, and hit them with your knife, and completely kill them with no one in sight or nearby, all the enemies in the area will know where you are right away. You cannot sneak around enemies, you cannot fool them into thinking you're in another spot. The graphics look nice, the gun play is solid, and the health system is fairly cool. The game just really feels dull at times sadly, and could have used a less linear feel. The quests in the game felt almost randomly generated and lacked any personality. Almost no characters in the game besides the man you're hired to kill have personality. Overall, 8/10.

reviewText:
A bright gem in the world of FPS shooters, Far Cry 2 takes us to a place we all know, or at least the members of our family from generations past knew - the world of struggle, strife and corruption. It comes alive in spectacular style and is one of the most realistic of all the fictional locales used in today´s PC games. The guns, the glory, the greed all merge and create an authentic and powerful story. Driven by an excellent gameplay engine, Far Cry 2 enables you to fight in a variety of ways, from employing stealth to outright firefighting. You can kill you enemies silently from afar, using the vegetation as your cover, or engage in gun battles in a variety of ways. The hillsides offer excellent fallback positions and allow you to plan your next  move. Whether you want to pick everyone out in an area using your sniper rifle, or burrow  your way through their compounds and outposts, Far Cry 2 will offer you ample chances to do both.

This installment offers a wide diversity of of weapons,  manual loading, semi automatic  and fully automatic. Explosive weapons are also available. Some come with their own scopes, allowing you to sniper bomb enemy cars before, or after the driver and his fellow soldiers get in.  The grass and trees can be set on fire, allowing you to create a shield of fire to drive the enemies while you reposition yourself and shoot them before they can regain their bearings.

A serious game for a veteran player, Far Cry 2 is a haven for the creative killer, the adventurer and the explorer. Get it, if you really want to see the wild side of Africa in all its glory.

reviewText:
This is quite possibly one of the best in the series, maybe even the best. Far Cry 2 brought on a new era of gaming, seeing as advanced graphics came in, better 3D modeling, and really a full on objective with other things you could do in the vast free-roam map. I would really like it if people understand this game is realistic, and if you cant go with realistic FPS's, then you don't know a FPS when you see one, Far Cry 2: Best FPS Ever.

-Realism
-Gun jamming, rusting, scratching, etc.
-Great visuals for the time, really made people want the game.
-Takes a few more bullets for you to kill someone.
-Buddy system, great thing to have when you die trying to save your other buddy.
-Overall, get. this. game.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is worth every single penny spent on it!

The driving bits get a bit tedious after a while as well as the Malaria attacks, but the game was enjoyable all the way to the end.

The graphics are nice, the selection of weapons is mostly Cold War era weapons (AKM, G3, FAL etc.) wich is a plus in my book. The combat feels nice & you have lots of ways to approach the outpost you are about to ruin. The weapon you are using may misfire if it gets too old wich is a nice feature.

This is mainly a Singleplayer game but there is also a Multiplayer mode thats really fun. Theres still a small but dedicated community playing, so theres a good chance youll run into the same people more than a few times!

The story is good with lots of symbolism, although at times it feels a bit confusing as to whats going on.

All in all, the game is not without its flaws such as constantly respawning enemy checkpoints & the aforementioned driving bits, but if you manage to see past these flaws, you have a really great game! Its the kind of game that you either love or hate.
But would I recommend it? Of course I do! If you ever have the money to spare or its on sale, I say buy it!
At least just so you can try it out.

Sincerely
// Anton

reviewText:
One of the top 5 games I've ever played. Far superior to Far Cry 3.  Certain aspects of this game make me want to hate it, but in turn, drive me to beat it, to be better. Strangly enough, since any other game I would just lower the difficulty or uninstall and call it a crappy game. Not this.

Finished the game, doing all the missions and bonus missions in 30 hours on Infamous. Don't play it on any other difficulty or it will ruin the game. Realistic in certain aspects which is great, such as getting killed in one shot and jammed weapons in a firefight. That might not seem fun, but it forces you to become a better player. Scavenging for supplies, ammo, and health is great. You don't carry hundreds of rounds or 10 rockets as in other games. You have to preserve your ammo, and your time.

Didn't like driving everywhere, although it adds to the realism. The buddies really added to the game. You have to play to the end to find out why. One of the best endings in any game. Hundred times better than Far Cry 3, whose ending left me saying wtf with three question marks. Far Cry 2's ending ties together the entire game, and is drastically different from any other game.

At the end of Far Cry 3, I felt as if I wasted my time, although it was fun. Both endings had no closure, and one of them was plain stupid. It wasn't realistic in many aspects. Far Cry 3 ruined it completely with its voice-over and cutscenes. Far Cry 2 made me feel as if I was in Africa for 30 hours, fighting the fight. At the end of Far Cry 2, I felt as if I died. And you know what, it was worth it.

reviewText:
It may be worth noting that I've only played Far Cry 1 before playing this, and have yet to touch the other two, (just purchased Far Cry 3 but played this while waiting for the download).

This game is phenominal! I remember fondly the first Far Cry game back in the day and how it's AI amazed me. Getting flanked in the bushes while fighting other soldiers in front of me. That was years ago in FC1. This... is amazing.

Even though I only have a couple of hours on record (13 so far, although only 4 recently), I can see me playing this game for a long time before I move on to the next in the series. Definately worth the buy!

reviewText:
I finished only the first act (there is 3 overall). I can't make myself play any longer, this game is really tedious and poorly written, hence there is nothing what could keep me going.

This game is ok shooter. But it's not so action filled to actually enjoy the game solely because of this, there is too much gaps in between. The gameplay is rather slow and consists mostly of you driving from point A to point B through copy-pasted enemy controlled checkpoints (which are everywhere) to do your usually absolutely meaningless business. Every action starts from you driving at least a couple of minutes. Don't waste your time cleaning checkpoints, they will respawn as soon as you turn the corner.

Quests are all stupid fetch quests and main quests are no different. Story is so disjointed and sparse I was lost in the beginning because game doesn't take time to explain you anything. The only source of information about the situation is your journal, which consist of 1 (one) entry in it, and accidentally" heard 10 seconds dialogue between bosses when you come to them to take another go-kill quest. Trough the first act Jackal appeared twice for about 1 minute total
date: saying some cryptic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. That's about all the story I got. This game is extremely poor on content."

reviewText:
I believe I made it roughly a third of the way through the main “story” of Far Cry 2 before moving on to greener pastures. Had I been an early adopter to the title, I think it would have blown me away with the size of the playable area, the complexity of ways to approach each obstacle, and that awesome fire spread. However, I found that instead I was frequently infuriated with the enemy AI constantly pinpointing me in a bush at midnight a mile away and I quickly grew tired of the amount of tedious travel required to get from any point of the map to the other.

Upon release I’m sure this was a must own title, but with the availability of Far Cry 3 and the (hopefully decent) soon to be released Far Cry 4, I don’t think this game has much to offer anyone anymore.

Certainly not a terrible game if you can pick it up for a dollar, but nothing to jump at.
voteText: 38 of 78 people (49%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
By far the most boring game I have ever played.

I'm still amazed I managed to complete the campaign, despite hours and hours of unbelievably tedious and repetitive missions given by some of the the most uninspired and poorly voice-acted characters in the history of gaming.

It's a shame too, because the world Ubisoft Montreal built here was remarkably beautiful.  But such beauty can hardly be appreciated when it's guarded by dozens of outposts populated by ever-respawning enemies who will always shoot you on sight - regardless of your current allegiance to their faction (!!!).

Add to that the fact that fast-travelling is very limited in this game, and that most missions require you to go from point A to point B using the same routes over and over, and you got yourself one of the least pleasant experiences you could imagine as far as first-person shooters go.

Honestly, I can't stress this enough. Avoid Far Cry 2 at all costs. If you're planning on going through the entire series and are afraid you'll miss out on important bits of story, don't worry: these games aren't connected in any way.

reviewText: Far Cry 2 is a stellar example of a game that appears to have a lot going for it, but isn’t actually worth your time. The open world design feels barren, needlessly large, and pointlessly shoehorned in. Everything in the game boils down to binary decisions. All of the guns feel wimpy and samey. The one-note mission design and unrewarding treasure-hunting collectathon prevents anything interesting from happening within the world, making the entire experience feel rote. None of the characters have any personality, and the plot isn’t memorable. Even the more impressive technological feats, such as fire and the day/night cycle, have little impact on gameplay. At best, Far Cry 2 is generic, boring and forgettable.

reviewText:
This game is made infuriating by the enemies who have perfect aim and will hit you from hundreds of meters away, behind foliage, during the night. There are enemy camps littered all over the map and you can't just drive through them; not only will the enemies start shooting at you instantly, they will even give chase. You can clear out the camps but as far as I can tell they get repopulated as soon as you leave.

You have to constantly stop your travels to deal with the camps, and clearing them out isn't even a challenge, it's just boring; it does however make exploration feel like a slog, which is not a good thing in an open world game.

At one point I was exploring the wilderness during the night, far away from any camps, when all of a sudden a jeep came at me from nowhere and three guys started shooting at me. Not only is this frustrating but it's also immersion breaking, which is sad because the game really tries to provide an immersive experience. I liked that you have to use a physical map and that the camera stays first person during driving.

If the enemies would be less aggressive and they couldn't see you through foliage this game would be a lot more enjoyable. At this point the best thing about it is that it doesn't use Uplay.

reviewText:
1-3/2016 Original Review:

Picture Dead Island.  Now, take away all the zombies, skill trees, interesting characters, and set the game in Africa.  Hey look, you've got Far Cry 2, a game with a meaningless protagonist who loves doing people's chores!  I get why people could enjoy this game, but I really didn't.  I have yet to finish the game and I'm dreading having to press on.  Here's some pros and cons to help you understand why:

Pros:
-Absolutely beautiful atmosphere/map.  Looking out over a desert, lake, or bayou at sunset is amazing.
-This game's multiplayer was my childhood, and the custom maps feature is awesome.  Playing escape maps with friends online holds some great memories for me.  Unfortunately, online play for this game is near dead now, but if you can get a chance to play some custom maps with friends they're fun.

Cons:  Oh god, where do I start.
-Gameplay wise, get ready for some repetition.  Talk to an NPC, get a quest, drive to the other side of the damn map (or use the poorly implemented quick travel system), shoot people or blow something up, rinse & repeat.  It feels like a sin for a game with such a vast environment to feel so slow, dry, and outright boring.
-This game is literally driving Simulator 2009 edition.  You have to drive so much, only to be interrupted halfway to your destination which feels 35253 miles away by some random mercenary who thought it'd be tactical to literally ram the hell into you.  This occurs WAY too often and gets extremely annoying.
-The game is divided into two acts.  The problem with this, is by the end of act one the game feels like it's ready to end.  But it doesn't.  It goes into act two.  This literally made my jaw drop.  I was so ready to be done with this driving simulator.
-If you're looking for a good story, don't come here.  In the beginning of the game, your character gets an idea in their mind of what they want to do.  Without spoiling anything, I'll say that at literally EVERY opportunity they get to carry out their objective, they're hindered physically (in pain, can't move, etc etc).  Total bs.  If this was the main goal of the game, I'd go to think they'd lift a finger a little more.  I think at the point in the game I'm currently at I can see why the protagonist might be changing their mind about killing the Jackal, but since our character doesn't talk we have no way of knowing their intentions.

Overall if you're a fan of the Far Cry series give this a whirl.  Otherwise stay away, stay far away.

5/10



1-7/2016 UPDATE:

I've been trying to finish this game, and oh has it been hard.  Not gameplay difficulty wise, but hard as in difficult to sit through this p.o.s...

This game is a perfect example of where a company threw the golden rule of games out the window: Gameplay over Graphics.  This game is gorgeous, but the gameplay is dry and repetative, not fun at all no matter how many different ways there are to approach missions.  This is because they're all the same exact thing, as I discussed in my older review above.

This game crashes constantly for me.  I was able to deal with this, up until now.  I have a few different save files that I've been making throughout the game just as a safety, and boy I'm glad I did.  I was at 88% game completion on my primary save, and I thought, I haven't saved in a while, I better save before end game!  Guess what?  I went to save, the game crashed, my heart sank.  No
date: I thought to myself , please don't let my save be corrupted."  Sure enough
recommended: it was.  Back to 73% game completion for me.  I get to do all those repetitious missions over again.  Woo-hoo.  I may add more comments when I do manage to finish this glitchy pile of crap.  But
hoursPlayed: until then

reviewText: After about a day of playing this, I went to Google and entered how to have fun in Far Cry 2".  And then I reflected on what a bizarre thing I had just done.  But for such a good-looking game
date: the fun seems to be hard to find.  I even considered that that might be the point; actually contracting malaria in a war-torn hellhole where you must kill or be killed wouldn't actually be much fun.\n\nThe game felt repetitive far too quickly for my tastes; you accept a quest from somebody
recommended: then drive from point A to point B (walking is far too slow.)  Along the way you'll likely pass two checkpoints on the road; no you can't avoid them by travelling off-road.   Each checkpoint has a few goons who would like to kill you
hoursPlayed: so you kill them.  Then you arrive at point B
voteText: where there are a few goons that would like to kill you
helpfulPercent: so you kill them.  Killing everyone at Point B usually accomplishes the quest goal
votesHelpful: so now you must just return to point A
votesTotal: except that those damned checkpoints have already repopulated
votesFunny: so you need to murderdeathkill their residents over again just to get back.   The majority of the game
commentsCount: as I found it
column16: was shooting my way through the same checkpoints over and over again.\n\nPart of the misery of the situation is that you will spend a certain amount of time trying to fight with crappy
column17: unreliable firearms.  You will be able to purchase reliable guns that perform well at your safehouses
column18: but for some reason you are unwilling to bring enough ammo for all the butchery that a typical quest demands
column19: so at some point you will end up dropping your well-maintained and functional firearm in favour of a fallen foe's rusted-out jam-prone piece of scrap metal.  You will then have the joy of finishing the quest with this vaguely gun-like object
column20: because continual weapon jams in difficult situations are an essential part of the experience.\n\nThat's my Far Cry 2 experience: repetitive
column21: unrewarding shootouts

column23: and malaria.  Subjectively

reviewText:
I know it's not fair to compare a game made in 2008 to one made four years later. But I started by playing Far Cry 3 and enjoyed it so much I thought I might as well try it's predecessor. Not a good idea. Number two stinks.
It lacks almost everything that makes FC3 a great game. FC2 has a dull story line, and most missions are exact copies of earlier ones, especially the side missions. Example: to unlock weapons you have to blow up a convoy coming from the east. And then one from the west. And south. And yes, dealing with the convoy coming from the north is exactly the same; they drive around in circles, you blow the lorry to smithereens and you're done; you can proceed to the next mission. Public transport is the best choice to get there, as driving a car or boat takes about 10 times longer. That's because every 100 meters you have to deal with two homicidal maniacs in a car or ten of them at yet another road block.
You have a choice of nine to pick your main character from. It doesn't matter much which one you pick. Every character in the game has a personality as flat as roadkill at a monstertruck show.
The feeble attempt at a story line is hard to follow for someone who's not a native speaker, like me. Everyone speaks as if they've just done an ounce of speed, and even the subtitles have a hard time keeping up. From what I picked up, the story basically goes like this: first you work for this person, then you work for that person, then you work for another person, then you kill one of them and another person appears. You work for that person too, and then for another person and then you kill one of them and another person appears. Repeat until everyone dies. Game over.

So, no. I do not recommend buying this game, even though the graphics are pretty awesome for a game made in 2008.
I do recommend Far Cry 3 though, which was fun, entertaining and trippy.

reviewText:
If you are reading this now and wondering if you should spend money on this game, please don't. For the whole duration of my playthrough I was either bored to death by the unnecessarily long drives and dull combat, or kept wondering how such a fundamentaly flawed game was released by a experienced company as Ubisoft.

The graphics are technically decent if compared to other games from when Far Cry 2 was released, but they did not age well. The map is huge but you can hardly tell any difference from the places you go apart from the 3 basic biomes (desert, savanna and jungle). Everything is bleached by a clear brown fog, even the jungles are a dull brownish color.  Almost every building on the map looks like it's part of a shanty town and the very few urban settings are minuscle and lame.

Sound is mostly mediocre, with a few very annoying sounds playing all the time like some metal banging from the regular cars, or a weird tire screeching sound that's played every other time you get shot (!). The few musics are unremarkable at best. The voice-over dialogues are terrible, the actors seem to have been rushed into reading their lines as fast as possible.

The story is terrible and almost non-existent, wasting an excelent opportunity to delve deep in such an important and completely overlooked theme that are the civil wars happening in Africa. The player character is despicable and so are almost everyone you get to interact with throughout the game and you suspension of disbelief is constantly broken by the lack of sense on the assignments given to your character. In a few moments the game seems to give options to the player, but soon after you learn that your choices mean nothing and the story follows it's pre defined path.

But the worst of all is the gameplay. 70% of the time spent playing Far Cry 2 involves driving, a few times even walking large distances devoid of anything but the infamous ever respawning enemy guard posts present at every other road crossing. The main missions are very repetitive and are limited to driving to a certain spot, killing someone/taking or giving an item/destroying something and then going somewhere else to repeat this pattern until the mission is completed. The side missions are utterly repetitive and often send you all the way across the map. And to add insult to injury, every now and then you need to drop everything you are doing to go fetch some malarial pills, which is probably one of the dumbest repeteable side quest ever on the history of videogames.

Bottom line is, if you have money to spend on a game, there are many other better options on Steam, so do yourself a favour and skip this one.

The malaria management is a pain in the ♥♥♥ and adds nothing but annoyance.\nThere are some good things like the buddy system and fire mechanics but aside from a few good points, the game is largely disapointing.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is a handful of good ideas buried under one of the most repetitive games I've ever played. Given the recent trend of reviewers re-examining it and declaring it some sort of misunderstood masterpiece I decided to buy it again (I'd lost my disk ages back) and give it another go. As I remembered it mostly consists of driving a vehicle backwards and forwards around the same parts of the map with the same 3-4 annoying AI troops respawning in the exact same areas and attacking you. If killed they'll simply respawn in their checkpoint ready to chase you next time and ignoring them simply results in them following you forever.

Degradation is a nice idea but once your weapons have degraded you have to DRIVE BACK to the arms dealer again since picking up extra weapons from dead enemies is worthless (they are always in horrible condition). To even get weapons in the armoury you have to:

A. Do a side mission to unlock the weapons for purchase (more driving to get there and back).
B. Find diamonds to pay for the weapons (even more ♥♥♥♥ing driving).

You do get small moments of fun now and then. Stealth, for example, sometimes works brilliantly but just as often the AI decides to spot me at random and then everyone in the area will magically know your position. I've got nothing against harder stealth but STALKER did it better even with its flaws. Some of the missions are fun too but most are fairly forgettable firefights.

The game would likely have worked much better as a series of linear missions with a semi-open map for each (i.e. Far Cry 1). As usual open world here just means repetitive and empty.

Buddy mechanics and the general atmosphere are the only good points but all the atmosphere in the world couldn't make up for the complete boredom of actually playing this game.

Finally to add insult to injury the game is buggy as ♥♥♥♥, particularly the tutorial. Activating the DLC is an annoyance also. You might have to spend 1-2 hours hunting for fixes and replaying the unskippable intro/tutorial until it works (10+ minutes every time). As mentioned above the AI also varies between being completely blind and cheating depending largely on their alert status.

reviewText:
Hey all, remember Far Cry 1? That was great.  You were in a big ol' open world, and you could find these shots that gave you animalistic super powers like leaping and attacking.  You took shots and they made you like unto a God.

Far Cry 2 is similar, except now when you take shots they are anti-malarial shots, and the awesome benefit they provide is that as long as you can find them and take them you don't die! So awesome! I love driving around the map, fighting off the stupid AI and searching around for green vials that let me play the game awhile longer.  It's like playing an old arcade game, except instead of running out of quarters, your character just runs out of the will to live.

It's really my own fault though, I mean Far Cry 1 had super powers, and I just assumed Far Cry 2 would as well, or at least maybe not a constant life threatening illness.

Let's forget the maleria for a second, even though the game never does, is the rest of the game good? No.

Here's, honestly, my biggest gripe... ok, second biggest after the lack of super powers as given in the first game... ok, third biggest after they took away those powers and gave you a debilitating illness... So, my third biggest gripe is just how boring this game is, namely, how long it takes to get anywhere.  They gloat about this giant island that you get to sandbox around in, however it seems that half of it is covered by impassable mountains.  You want to go someplace literally two inches away on the map? Have fun driving around the mountains for ten minutes to get there.  Want to do some awesome off roading and just ramp yourself over the mountain like in, literally, EVERY OTHER ♥♥♥♥ING SANDBOX GAME? Too bad friend, because you can't drive there.  Unfortunately your off-road mountain-jeep can really only handle the dirt roads.

Ok, I'm getting bored just remembering playing this game, so I'm out.  I just couldn't in good conscience leave all those positive reviews below without doing my part.

reviewText:
The game works as intended no crashes etc and the game engine is great.

There are many other examples... Only buy this game it if its really cheap and you really love this type of game, the over simulate the real world type of game.

reviewText:
I finished it the other day. I would not recommend it. The entire time I was playing, I was praying for it to be over so I could move on to trying Far Cry 3 (which I finished a little over an hour ago).

Lemme list some grievances with FC2.

1. It's an open world game and there's no fast travel or quick means of travelling except for bus stations in opposite corners of the map. You have to drive miles upon miles, having to stop every half mile because there's enemies every half mile that you have to stop to kill. Even if you drive past them, you'll still have to stop to fix your car and they'll probably get in an armed jeep and chase you anyway. You have no idea how tedious that got. I swear half my play time (28 hours as opposed to FC3's 18 hours) came from driving to mission locations.

2. The enemies every half mile respawn, so you have no hope of ever escaping having to constantly stop - nor is there any motivation to engage them (save for the ones that chase you in vehicles that you HAVE to get out and kill).

3. Weapons wear down. While this was an interesting concept, the weapons wear down way too quickly. They go from brand new to exploding in your hand in like a day.

4. Everything is too grayish or brownish. The game made me feel like I was colorblind sometimes.

5. For some reason your character doesn't talk in FC2 even though your character talks in FC1 and FC3.

6. There wasn't much story to be had, relatively speaking.

7. The game would give you choices here and there that wouldn't make any difference. The same cutscenes would still play either way.

Anyone thinking of getting FC2, do yourself a favor and skip over to FC3.

reviewText:
I waited to finish the game before writing my review in the hopes that it would change my negative output on it...But it didn't.
When I first played the game (at this point,a minor peeve).I was already put off by the voice acting,which was flatter than a 180 degree angle.Some of the characters spoke as if commas and periods were never invented.Thankfully however,not all.
Next was I was shocked over the level of graphics and physics.Despite being released in 2008,I'd mistaken it for a game that was released in 2005 or 2006.The water in the game seemed as if there was no effort put into the animation as a whole.
But most appallingly of all,as a person who considers himself a ditz for a good story,was the lack of a good narrative. Characterization was endangered if almost non-existant and events unfolded for the sake of formality it would seem. Things seemed to happen just cause.Other things seemed to happen just so there would be an excuse for another thing to happen without any true relevance to the plot or character development.
The potential for the story,as I've said,is depressingly wasted,unexplored and unexpounded despite innumerable opportunities.Generic guards and soldiers disabled any potential for flavor in this so-called civil war.Similarly,the missions were repetitive regardess of who you side with in the game.Any difference is purely aesthetic in nature.The most I could get in major difference were tiny morsels of gossip about the faction's background and the war itself.There was no true point in choosing a side in the world's factions.
Furthermore,events that would seem major to me would happen suddenly without any rising action,falling action or any form of hype whatsoever.Couple this with repetitive gameplay and mission objectives and you end up with dull,wasted surprises for the player.
I want to emphasize the lack of characterization among nearly all characters.They would either just do as they would be told despite being major characters or they would suddenly commit acts that would seem weighty if not for the lack of hype around it.The only thing separating them from the random mooks was the unique character models and the names.I could find more autonomy in a ballpen.Events were almost always too sudden for me to appreciate the deep potential in the story.
All in all,it was a pain for me to play this game.Every hour spent on this game was agonizingly dull and every tidbit of potential in the story I could find was like a droplet of water to a weary desert traveler.Never before has get it over with" been my objective to play a video game.And again
date: my main issue was the poor narrative and the unexpounded story.If not for that
recommended: then all else could be forgiven.\nDespite the negativity in my review
hoursPlayed: there are 3 aspects that I enjoyed.\n~I loved the ability to choose a player character.\n~The buddy system allowed variety.If ever I (somehow) get the urge to play this again
voteText:
it would be because of this.
~The reputation system and how it affected the AI in relation to a firefight with you.
The buddy system offers some tint of retribution and the African Landscape is beautiful if lonely and littered with the occasional random dead body.
Thank you and have a nice day :)"

reviewText:
This game is one of the worst FPS games I've played, ever

Constantly respawning enemies that repopulate bases after 2 or 3 minutes that must be fought constantly and are boring to fight.
Completely broken stealth mechanics.
Completely pointless malaria angle that forces you to do boring missions.
Completely repetitive missions that are essentially the same thing every time.
Completely awful mapping system that obscures where you're going.
Completely awful gun wear mechanics that enemies never ever suffer from and ensure that you can't pick up enemy .weapons and expect them to work.
Completely awful hidden package huntign that is forced on you to afford good equipment.
Completely awful driving where you ened to drive 10-15 mins for a 4 min mission.
Completely awful buddy system that leads to unskippable cut-scenes galore.

Do not buy it.

reviewText:
This can be considered a rant.

Far Cry 2 may be the worst PC game I've ever played.

The only thing that worked as planned was buying it on Steam.

My issues with the game began in the options menu.  I immediately change the graphics options from the default of minimal to settings my computer can easily run.  Then I made the mistake of telling it to run on DX10 instead of DX9.  The game immediately crashed and when I tried to load it, all I could see were fragments.  I could not even tell where my cursor was, let alone change back to DX9.  When I tried to update the GamerProfile to DX9, it didn't help.

Uninstall, reinstall.  Only the game wouldn't let me uninstall.  Every time I exit out of FC2 Steam says it's still running despite my Task Manager being clear of all game related tasks.  Force close Steam.  Open Steam.  Uninstall.  Reinstall. Oh and get this, when I go to delete local content through Steam, it launches the game.  When I close the game again, then the content is gone.

That worked and I was able to get into the game and NOT click on DX10.

Then I started a new game.  Graphic issues all over the place.  Water changing color rapidly, NPCs bouncing up and down all over the place, I can see a guy's teeth flicking over his face.  No matter how I changed the graphics options, the problems persist.  Online forums were no help either, just a bunch of people like me complaining.  Also seems like those who contacted Ubi didn't get much resolution to the issue either.  Yes I know what you're going to say, What are your sys specs and is everything updated?"  My system is incredible and everything is updated
date: no hardware issues.  I'm a super nerd.  Yes I even verified the cache and everything Steam suggests. Yes the game is updated too.\n\nNow we come to gameplay.  This is stuff I'm not sure is bug related but may just be terrible production.  NPC talk faster than I can think.  I have subtitles on and I can barely pass my eyes over all the words before they leave the screen

reviewText:
I feel this is a difficult game to review in 2015, it's a  game that I feel wouldn't be loved if it was released in todays industry.

The original game  FarCry was quite a difficult game to complete, there's very little in terms of aids to help the player in  FarCry and FarCry2 takes a similar stance.

There's no indicators to tell the player where they're taking damage from, if they're in stealth or not and there's no ability to tag enemies. For me these things only adds to the immersion, it's more brutal that way but for a lot of players not having those indicators would leave them feeling frustrated or that the game is broken.

There's no minimap, you need to get the map out from your pocket to have a look, once again for some people this only adds to immersion but to others it's just awkward, I guess it just depends on the type of player you are.

The biggest flaws with FarCry2 are the fact it's an open World 1st person shooting game that fails to deliver a decent open World to explore and at the same time having sloppy weapon mechanics and for those 2 reasons I wouldn't recommend FarCry2.

I've spent over 30 hours with FarCry2 on the PC and there's aspects of the game I really liked.
Visually I find it very pleasing, the setting and atmosphere are rather nice.
The fire mechanics I feel are the best in the series and creating mass scale fires to clear out check points never got old.
Plant physics, so they move when you touch or drive over them and branches will drop down if you shoot though them.
The vehicles although extremely bland to drive with awful sound effects have had some nice little touches added, they get dirty when driven in the jungle and the level of destruction is greater than that in FarCry3 in terms of your car falling apart, lights being smashed, bumpers or bonnets flying off.

But in the end FarCry2 feels empty, the map is lifeless and barren. There's no civilians who live there, it's pretty much you and everyone else is your enemy. The check points you clear and even other locations will have guards re-spawning, so it's this never ending army and it's not even that they  re-spawn hours later, they do it with in a couple of minutes and it feels cheap and breaks the immersion.

The auto-save system doesn't work very well, you often have to go back an hour in to game after you die. There is the option to press F5 and do a quick save, which is great if you remember to do it every 10 minutes but you're meant to be immersed in the game, not thinking about saving.

An open World game should entice you to explore and FarCry2 doesn't. A 1st person shooting game should have solid gun mechanics and FarCry2 doesn't.

FarCry2 has a nice physics engine, it's an enjoyable African grassland fire simulator but that's sadly all it has to offer.

reviewText:
I have come into Far Cry 2 from the unusual perspective of having finished Far Cry 3 recently beforehand, and I have been extremely disappointed by FC2 so far. It's clear to see where Ubisoft have made improvements in FC3 that ruined its predecessor.

The game's setting and feel is great; it really captures the feeling of a central African country. But that's where the good ends, unfortunately.

My first gripe was the impossibly good AI that can shoot me through undergrowth from 300m away with no problem, and outposts full of guards that instantly turn all their fire on you with unerring accuracy the moment you try and snipe someone. FC3 handled this much better with panicking pirates that fire wildly in your general direction when you snipe them and have far more realistic (i.e. worse) awareness, accuracy and line of sight. I accept that I'm not especially good at FPS games in general, but I find this game punishingly hard, even taking that into account.

Enemies are also extremely bullet-spongy, which is disappointing from a game touting some degree of authenticity and realism in its setting. Even the most basic African militia or mercenary seems to be wearing a kevlar t-shirt and takes about 10 rounds of 5.56mm to the chest to die.

Next is the crazy respawn rate of enemies. There are times where I've cleared out a guardpost, only to find the enemies shooting at me again from it once I'm barely 100m down the road. I can only assume this wasn't playtested by QA at Ubisoft.

Within the first hour these critical game design flaws had killed the game for me. Although I was able to find the useful Dylan's Realism Mod" to reduce the enemy HP and awareness slightly
date: it still didn't get rid of the incessant enemy respawns that lead to a lack of permanence and meaning in your actions.\n\nFar Cry 3 did everything better except vehicles
recommended: which in FC2 actually handle like
hoursPlayed: well
voteText: vehicles; as opposed to FC3
helpfulPercent: where vehicles are made from rubber and roads lined with goose fat.\n\nOverall though
votesHelpful: Far Cry 3 highlights what a wasted opportunity Far Cry 2 was - get FC3 instead."

reviewText: I can only recommend this game in one way. And that is to provide a learning expierence on how not to make a video game. This game has got to be the WORST example of a video game I've ever seen. It fails in every aspect. It fails to create any interesting characters, it fails to engage the player, it fails to be fun, it fails to be interesting, and it fails to be memorable. The only thing this game does is infuriate the hell out of you. This game is really a gruesome and downright unfair survival game. You have to spend your time driving in an ugly environment for hours, getting shot repeatedly by enemies who can drive at mach 5 while you're locked to a cruising speed. You have to tend to your malaria (I'm not kidding) which is hard because medicine is scarce. Enemies can see you 600 meters out and instantly assume you're an enemy and ruin your stealth approach. And the game has no sense of level design. It's seriously just, Drive here

reviewText:
This is one of my least favourite games of all time.  A vast open world was certainly exciting at the time of release, but once you find yourself covering ridiculous amounts of ground, wiping out an entire camp of enemies only to find they have miraculously respawned when you drive past again five minutes later, it gets boring fast.

I found the driving frustrating, especially with the frequent stops at the aforementioned camps, and the game's handheld map - whilst an interesting idea - obscures the screen and interrupts the game in a way I didn't care for.

One saving grace of the game is the shooting.  It's very satisfying, the guns have a sense of weight and recoil.  They also jam often, until you get better weaponry, which is a nice touch of realism and serves as something of a progression system.

There are also a few things that this game brought to the table, such as environmental damage.  The way fire spreads through the grass is quite impressive.

All in all I can't recommend this.  There are so many games of this kind that provide a better experience.

reviewText:
Having played the profoundly satisfying Far Cry 3 less than a month before this, I can't tolerate this game's shortcomings.

I find myself mashing 5 to get my bearings, staring at the map rather than the lush surroundings. Firefights are painfully basic and the sprawling map makes me feel horribly lost. The narrative is hampered by some of the flattest, least immersive voice acting I've ever heard.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f6ggpdU4gFs

NPCs bounce around erratically, the game's default settings are bare minimum, you spend the game fighing a debilitating disease, and the seemingly endless number of enemies spawn from any direction and can wipe you out befor you can get your bearings and figure out where the hell they are. Everyone is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and out to get you and every time I've died I had no idea why or what killed me.

Avoid this dated piece of crap and start at Far Cry 3.

reviewText:
Ok I am %62 done with this game and I can give you some details about it.

First off I think my mistake is that I played FarCry first which was great, and then FarCry 3 which was awesome.
I was expecting the same awesomeness with FarCry 2 but I find it more difficult and I am less tolerant with it.

You see, fast travel kind of sucks in this game and missions are most of the time at the total opposite ends of the map. So if you are in the bottom left corner to accept a mission, expect to go back way to the top of the map.

Unlike FC3 when you liberate a post, it is not the scenario here. There is always bad guys. You can't get from point A to B quickly and quietly, unless you go offroad, and even then, it takes longer.

When you come into the game, I was not exactly sure what my objectives were. I had to go on the internet to give myself an idea. It was later after wasting time with side missions that don't really matter (Radio Tower missions) that I eventually learned that I have to get missions from the town and buddies (not real people or your online friends) that you encounter during the game.

Then it started getting interesting. But still the fact that fast travel is not great and posts are always fill with bad guys, makes it redundant and a bit frustrating.

Now I am not saying the game sucks. I am saying my mistake is that I was thinking of FC3 benefits and how I wished FS2 had it. I am even more sure that if I played them in order, I would be enjoying FC2 a lot better than I am now

Given that. I do not fault the game. It is what it is and I am sure that anyone playing it will have a lot of fun.

But don't do my mistake. Play FarCry 2 before you play FarCry 3.

Jeep Simulator® 2008©

reviewText:
A hardcore Far Cry 3 prototype set in wartorn Africa, for better or worse.

PROS:
- The Jackal
- Resourceful AI
- Satisfying gunplay
- Minimalistic but interesting story
- Bleak but gorgeous African setting
- Generally strong voice-acting
- Memorable buddies
- Beautiful at day

CONS:
- Far Cry in name only
- No leaning or proning
- No playable female character
- Many underused gameplay gimmicks
- Backtracking, lots of backtracking
- Lack of meaningful story choices
- Uninteresting side-quests
- Dubious story moral
- Ugly at night

reviewText:
The shooting is fine, but that's all in fardrive 2.
All mission feel the same, go there, shoot it and go back.
Rinse and repeat (even the mission animation/talk is the same).
Outpost are extremely annoying and don't bother to see if an npc is an enemy or not, they all are except in yellow zones.
Thus shoot first,.. and .. well keep shooting until the game is finished. Ignore any diamonds while you are at it, it's not worth it.

The game is also pretty linear in a sense, there is only the road, don't think to go offroad as the smallest stone will brick your car. There are almost no alternative routes into key areas (e.g. a base, village etc), no creativity there whatsoever.

So if you  like to torture yourself by playing this game, like I did, then do yourself a favor and use Dylan's Realism Mod!
http://www.moddb.com/mods/dylans-far-cry-2-realism-mod

It even makes stealth slightly a viable option.

reviewText:
What is Far Cry 2?

Far Cry 2 is a game that is great in theory.

Far Cry 2 is a game that is terrible in execution.

Far Cry 2 is a game that is awful in mechanics.

Far Cry 2 is a game that is bad in pacing.

Far Cry 2 is a game that is great in aesthetics.

Far Cry 2 is a game that excels as using games as a form of art, not as thought neutralizers.

Far Cry 2 is a game that is ready to talk politics, ideas, and discuss storytelling.

Far Cry 2 is a game you should play at least once, to see if you'll get into the swing of things or not.

Far Cry 2 is like nothing else.

Far Cry 2 is unique.

reviewText:
Grade for singleplayer: 2/10
Grade for multiplayer ?/10

In short:
This game is not an enjoyable adventure. Instead it is extremely frustrating game with predictable storyline, which gives the player almost no ways to affect how the story is going to proceed.

Full Review:
First I would like to talk about the gameplay, which is very frustrating as I said. Most of the missions the player takes part are relatively identical to each other and are somewhat booring. This especially apllies to missions required to make new guns available. The worst part of this game though are the transitions between the missions. To travel to location of you mission you have to travel trough large amount of roadblocks that are guarded by hostile militia. Clearing these places is very repetitive. You have to keep clearing these roadblocks troughout the game. Even if you had just passed them there are new soldiers there to wait for you return.

You can't even enjoy driving your car because these roadblocks are so close to each other that you would almost be faster on foot. On high difficulty levels these roadblocks are actually quite difficult to clear, which increases the frustration even higher. If this isn't enough there is more. Sometimes those militas appear behind your car in their own vehicle and eliminate you with just few bullets before you can do anything. Additionally those militias suck incredible amounts of bullets before they die. To summarise. most of the time you are not really playing the game but instead clearing the extremely annoying and repetitive roadblocks.

Next about the Storyline. As I said the storyline is very predictable as I said. I wish I could say more but I would spoil the plot. What is possibly even worse is that although the player is allowed to make choices during the campaign, these choices result in identical or almost identical outcome.

Next the multiplayer:
I barely touched the multiplayer so i can't give much insight into it, but from the brief time I tested it, the multiplayer part seemed like a very generic FPS game.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is a game that simulates what it's like to be a gun-for-hire in some war-torn African country.  And it is very good at that, for better or for worse.

And from what I've experienced of it, it's for worse.  The constantly-jamming weapons, the fact that everyone's trying to kill you no matter who you align yourself with, a map interface that's clunky at best, and the malaria...oh, god, the malaria.  You have to take malaria pills every half-hour in-game, or you die.  And you only get four doses at a time - you replenish your pills at one specific in-game location.  It's all very frustrating, and all in the name of a realistic experience."

Let Far Cry 2 remain as an example of how realism doesn't always make a game better."

reviewText:
Pros:
-Open World
-Variety of weapons
-Environment interaction (light on fire, explode, break, etc.)

Cons:
All Pros are limited by poor implementation of each. The Open World is indeed open world, but all you find are more people that want to kill you. There is absolutely no suprise when you run into a Non-Important town and they all attack you.

The weapon variety is nice, but most of the weapons are about useless when you are bombarded by snipers and mortars. There is no reason to not use a sniper rifle which reigns supreme in all situations.

The environment interaction is a novelty at best. If you are caught in fire it DESTROYS you, but the enemy sits down and lights a cigarette then jerks off when they are covered in flames all at the same time they are shooting at you.

I played it simply because it was the next in the series. I played for about 5 hours and disliked this game. I forced myself to beat it because I'm stubborn and it took about 23.

Ending sucks, skip this game.

And the opening scene is god-awful long.

reviewText:
Far Cry 2 is a game that simulates what it's like to be a gun-for-hire in some war-torn African country.  And it is very good at that, for better or for worse.

And from what I've experienced of it, it's for worse.  The constantly-jamming weapons, the fact that everyone's trying to kill you no matter who you align yourself with, a map interface that's clunky at best, and the malaria...oh, god, the malaria.  You have to take malaria pills every half-hour in-game, or you die.  And you only get four doses at a time - you replenish your pills at one specific in-game location.  It's all very frustrating, and all in the name of a realistic experience."

Let Far Cry 2 remain as an example of how realism doesn't always make a game better."
